div.p: Imprimatur
Birinthea, A ROMANCE. WRITTEN, By J. B. Gent.
LONDON, Printed by Tho. Mabb, for John Playfere at the White Bear in the upper Walk of the New Exchange. 1664.

div.head: THE PREFACE.
div.p:
ALthough it may perhaps, be onely an affected, or a pretended Modety in many others, yet it is a mot evere Truth in me, when I profes I had not Publihed this Romance, but at the Requet and Commands of ome choice Friends, being
enible that a piece compoed in my greener Youth, and mot of it during the intervals of a harp ditemper, cannot be o mature and ound in all its parts, as it might have proved, if undertaken in a more advanced Age, and healthful Leaure. And therefore, to decline the Vanity of uch as make the Preface rather a Panegyrick to their Books, then an Advertiement to the Reader; I declare, that this is onely to deire thoe that hall perue the following Story, not to impute the Printers Faults to me, ince there
will be enough beides upon my own core, to Exercie the utmot of their mercy.

p.hi:
Yet do I not intend by this Ingenious Confeion to ubmit my elf to every trivial Cenurer: For though I hall acquiece in the Judgement of the Wie, yet have I too much Spirit to endure the ignorant reproof of uch buie Drones as make a humming noie, indeed, like Bees, and often light upon the weetet Flowers; but yet want the faculty to extract the leat drop of Honey thence reembling uch ill Contituted Bodies
as convert the mot wholeome Aliments into corrupt and contagious humors.

div.p:
From thee, I therefore jutly may appeal to ounder judgements, uch as examine with as much skill as equity, and conult with reaon and undertanding, not admitting either giddy Folly, or bepattering envy to bias them: before whom I dare affirm, that if I deerve correction in ome places, I merit no les approbation in others; For if my expreion be not very Eloquent, neither
is it very Languid; and if novelty be therein pleaing, I am confident ome will finde atisfaction; for though my tile may eem to limp, compared to the more Polite and Smooth Language of ome others, yet does it not fall into Ruticity or obcenes; nor leave uch uneven furrows as to make the Readers tumble, unles their prejudice or Malice lay an unhandome block in their own way.

Such as can relih no Romance, that is, not forced with
Extravagant Impoibilities (no les Ridiculous then improbable) will find little Guto and cold entertainment here; wherefore I wih uch to top at this Preface, and make no further Progres, for I have endued my Heroes with no greater trength or courage, then may reide in generous perons; nor do I fill their Veins with treams of blood greater, then thoe mal channels hould contain.

I know, indeed, this were an eaie task, if that were all, that is required to gain
applaue; it being without dipute more facil to rough-draw a Gyant (with a fening quil) who hould ingly rout whole Armies in every page, then really diarme the veriet Coward that dares but tand in the leat defenive poture.

And who ees not the fair advantage I might now take to et off the actions of my Heroe by heightning and exagerating them with welling Hyperboles, ince he is lited one of the greatet Conquerours in the Rolls of Fame; But treating of a real
Hitory, for the mot part, though it be controverted by ome, I keep cloe to probability, and give him the Character of a man, who was indeed inriched with a more then vulgar Soul, but whoe body was not above the Standar of Mortals, nor diproportionate to that condition.

For, in Truth, how currant oever Fictons may pas, yet can it not be allowed widome to compoe uch as only pleae and humour extravagant and irregular fancies, but that predominant
faculty of the Soul, the judgement; hould limit them within the naturall bounds of Reaon and Poibility; And o Romances hould be no other then the fairet Pictures and jut reemblances of Truth, from which it is as blameable to deviate, as to add Tinctures to the Roe or Lilly, uch aids being onely an ugly and gros paint, that intead of encreaing their beauty, blurs them with deformity.

But it may be Objected, that I am my elf guilty of thoe lapes, I here condemn, and chide o much in others; ince I have feined the adventurers of o many perons, and principally Birinthea, never mentioned by any ancient Auther.

To this I Reply, that my deigne, being not only to trancribe former Hitorians but to take my rie from thence for freh inventions; I think them very pertinent and excuable, o long as they are within the compas of
probabillity, and are not found impoibilities. In fine, it may uffice to tell you, that this is a Romance accommodated to Hitory, to whoe Text I have added thoe Auxiliary Embellihments rather to Illutrate, then Diguie or Corrupt it.

div.head: THE FIRST BOOK OF Birinthea.
div.p:
IF the night had not come on and urprized them, the battle had not been o oon ended: but the Sun, which contributes to the life of all things, eemed to precipitate his coure exprely with the greater peed (as if unwilling to be any longer a Witnes of the death of o many men) and reign'd it's Empire to the gloomy hades, that during the obcurity, they might be forced to a truce, the
Combatants looing both the ight and knowledge of their enemies.

Never did Bellona exercie the fury of her Arms with more rage then in this occaion; thirty thouand of the Ayrians were lain, together with their King Labynetus; and all the remainder could do, was to fly by the favour of the night, and teal themelves away from the victorious Perians and Medes, who eemed to breath nothing that day but laughter, and ought to triumph over the lives of Men, rather then over their liberties. The King of Lydia perceiving likewie, that the Asyrian Troops had all foraken the Camp, thought it vain with a feeble reitance to adventure the deperate hazard of an utter defeat and ruine; Wherefore giving command to all his men to eek their afety by a timely flight, of all that grand equipage which before attended him, he only took epecial care to ave ome women which were extreamly dear to him.

On the morrow, at the firt birth of day, Cyaxares King of the Medes, and Cyrus his Nephew, were already preparing themelves to aault the enemies Camp, when preently they found they had a pillage to make rather then a fight. Nothing appeared to their ight, but the horrid pectacle of wounded, or dead bodies: and ome whoe dying groans eccho'd in the Souldiers ears for pitty, called but a merciles hand to trip him of his cloaths and end his life the ooner.

The fruits of this victory relihed o weet to Cyaxares, that contenting himelf with thee firt favours fortune had betowed, he exhorted Cyrus
to tate them in a quiet repoe, and not hazard the looing them in a econd adventure But, that generous Prince, in the heat of that youthful courage which made him hope for, and apire to the Conquet of all Aia, earnetly implored his permiion to perue the enemy, to whom it was not afe to allow a breathing time, let they hould et thoe puiant Armies on foot again which were o formidable for their numbers, and perhaps light on ome advantage to tear thoe Palms of Victory out of their hands again, which they had newly gathered with o much weat and blood. He obtained in fine, the liberty to give them chae with thoe Perians which he commanded; and uch Medians likewie as would go voluntarily, had free leave to ait him: the chiefet amongt them very Nobly accompanied him in this expedition; and he was advanced already very near the Enemy: when ome Officers advertied him of the arrival of ome Hircanian Embaadours, who aid they were come to treat with him concerning an affair of great importance: He commanded they hould be brought into his Preence, and undertood by their Credential Letters, the deign their Prince had to quit the Ayrians party, by whom he was wronged, and to joyn with him.

Cyrus, that he might not be urprized by too much credulity, inform'd himelf by them of the poture his Enemies were in, and everal other particulars, which gave him the fuller aurance of their reality: after which he refued to take thoe Hotages they profer'd; and when they
pre'd him to retain them, he generouly reply'd, that he needed them not, having power enough to punih their perfidiounes, in cae they hould deceive him; as he had alo ufficient means to reward their amity by a retribution of his own, which he promis'd them inviolably, if they prov'd faithful and contant.

He had no ooner concluded with the Hircanians, but he immediately placed ome of them in the front of his Army to erve for Guides, and o marched the whole night; at the end of which, finding himelf in fight of the Enemy, he dipatched a Hircanian to his companions who were in the rear, to advertie them by a word of command to rank themelves beides the ret of their Party, which they peedily performed with acclamations of joy, which much augmented, the fear and terrour of the Ayrians. Cyrus no ooner beheld the Hircanians in their due places, but that he might lead them on to fight during that heat, and the Enemies confuion, he aembled all his uperiour Officers, and after he had ued ome particular ceremonies towards his new confederates, he harangued after this manner.

q.p:
Dear Companions, it were needles to advertie you, at preent, that we mut fight: As it is the caue that made you come from Cyaxares with o much hate and reolution; o I promie my elf, my companions, that none here will refue the preent occaion, which now preents its elf o fairly to us. Yea, I hould wrong you, hould I exhort you to that thing, for which you followed me with o much cheerfulnes, and which you have already
begun with o good ucces. This Battle fellow Souldiers, and worthy Officers, will be but the compleating of that Crown, which the firt victory hath prepared: It might lip from us if we hould give o much repite to our Enemies as to reume their trength and pirits; Or if the fear which but now affrights them; hould be let alone till it turn'd into depair. Yet do I not indeed quetion, but you would have as much ucces, as you have true valour, though they were in a poture to reit you more vigorouly than now they can. But not to expoe you to the hazard of fortune, who refued them the advantage of a victory he might have betowed on them; and which they cannot now obtain, but by your unmanlines. Let us hew dear Companions, that we have no valour nor trength now, which they hall not be a full witnes to aert is irreitable. And now that they are in diorder, having already lot the bet part of their Army, with their King; And that the Hircanians the toutet of their friends are on our ide. Come on Friends, you hall conquer if you follow me, and by their firt flight you may judge how unable they are to reit you.

div.p:
Thee words being pronounc'd with an extraordinary vehemency, the Officers and Souldiers returned to their own places; Cyrus drew the Hircanians up to the Front, and on each Wing two bodies of Hore. He had not advanced far, but he was on the Enemies skirts, whilt there was yet but light enough to dicover them: never was Army more urprized with fear and dread than this of the Ayrians, at their approach. The weaknes and diorder they were reduced to by
their firt defeat, made them uncapable to utain the attaque of the Perians and Medes, who charged them with o much precipitancy and mettle, that running here and there, allarmed they oon fell into a mighty confuion; ome to oppoe, others to ecape, bridled their Hores, and the nimblet mounted and aved themelves: ome took their Arms as their bet ecurity, others threw down theirs to fly with the les incumbrance. In fine, the greatet part of the Ayrians and their confederates being lain without any coniderable oppoition, this Victory was only ignaliz'd by the illutrious names of ome of the dead: The King of Capadocia, and the King of Thrace were killed upon the place, with many other coniderable perons, both for their valour and qualities. In this action the Hircanians gave infallible proofs of their fidelity and courage; they were the firt at the onet, and lat in the retreat: few of the Enemies that had aved themelves from Death, could ecape from Captivity; mot of them being made Prioners, and thoe few that fled, and drove the richet of their booty before them, were o cloely perued, that the Hircanians returned laden with riches, and with a great number of Chariots full of Women. Creus was almot the only man whom they could not overtake, who having taken the advantage of the whole night before with all his party to hun the next dayes hock, retired, being winged with fear, out of their reach.

Amongt the prioners that were preented to Cyrus, Sybaris his Lieutenant General, the choicet
of his friends, betowed upon him by the gods for a Companion in his fortunes, took notice of one he knew, and intantly embraced him with tetimonies of o particular an amity, that all the beholders were amazed: And Cyrus asking him whom that was he did o much caree; My Lord, replyed he, If this Prince were treated according to the merit of his valour and birth, you hould behold him rather with a Crown on his head, and Palms the trophies of Victory in his hands, then in this preent unhappines of a Captivity, which nevertheles cannot but be glorious to him, ince it cannot but be an effect of his courage.

This Elogy which Sybaris made of his friend, render'd Cyrus the more curious to know whom he was, and having heard his Name and place of birth, with the gallant deportment had been taken notice of in the fight, he approached him with all the civilities that were due to o illutrious a Captive; and having dicoured with him ome time, this Prioner anwer'd in o brave a manner, that it plainly appeared to him, thoe praies which Sybaris had poken, were rather the tetimonies of incere truth, than of any particular affection.

Their Complements being ended, Sybaris to whoe care Cyrus epecially recommended him, conducted him to his own Tent, where he was nobly received; and having given him for ome time the liberty to repoe himelf alone; the impatience he was in to learn by what adventure he was drawn into that action, made him return and intreat him to relate the tory of his life, ever
ince he had left him in Margiana. Merame, who could not refue to unlock that ecret to Sybaris, with whom he had o long ince contracted a real friendhip, began in this manner.

div.head: The Hitory of MERAME.
div.p: I Can give you no particular reaon of my unhappines, and the occaion which brings me here, but that alone, which as I beleeve, generally caues the misfortune of all men, I mean Love.

At that time when you reided in Margiana, I did not yet know the puiance of this deity, becaue I had not then felt his piercing darts; and I may ay, I then lived in content, though in the Court it may eem a thing next to impoibility, amidt the Monters of Ambition, and Envy, whereof the one flatters with its deluive hopes, while it conpires and plots our utter ruine; the other bytes and knawes our hearts, becaue that ome are happier then our elves. I can aure you, nevertheles, that I was not at all tainted with them, whether my blooming age were yet too green and innocent, or that I were reerved to ome more rugged Fate. But ince that time, all thoe dayes which other men have injoy'd with ome tranquillity, have been o many hours of misfortune to me; Or if I have tated ome momentory intervals of happines, I have been ure to pay for thoe little pleaures, at the dear rate of more continued ufferings: but I am
tranported too much with the reentment of my mieries, as if it were my task only to make my moanes, forgetting that you deire to know what has hapned ever ince our eparation, which that you may the more fully undertand, it will be very neceary that I tep back a little in my dicoure, and begin it farther off.

You know that I was born in Margiana of a family, which, being of the ame blood of thoe Princes that are the Soveraigns, is not a little coniderable in that Country: and beides this advantage, the more then ordinary care of my Education was added, I being the only child after twelve years marriage 'twixt my Father and Mother. As oon as I had pat my date of infancy, a learned man was ent for from Peria to be my Governor, and to intruct me in thoe Sciences which are very ordinary in your Country, but omewhat rare in ours: He had the charge to enrich and polih my mind with learning and judgement, whilt another Mater had the care to teach me uch bodily exercies as were fit for a peron of my quality. The great pains they both took in my behalf, was not altogether fruitles. And I may without vanity affirm, that I profited much by their learned intructions: which induced Balden, Our Prince who had a particular eteeme for mee, to oblige my Father to let me be alwayes neer his Son Senira; and, as there are few at Court that refue uch favours, it was accepted of as a great honour, that I was choen to be a companion for the young Prince: and whether it were the equality of our Age, or
the aiduous devoirs I rendred him, or only his fair and free inclination, I cannot tell, but he expre'd o great and fond an amity, that he would hardly be an houre without me: We paed our time in all kind of divertiements: But one day, when Senira, being poeed with a profound adnes, would needs injoy himelf, without the importunate throng of Courtiers which uually beeiged him, we retired to a Catle called Coupava belonging to my Father. In that vat olitude the Prince began to be acquainted with the nature of his Melancholly, and found that ome new entertained thoughts which perpetually invaded his mind, was the ole caue of it; and as he cherihed me with much tendernes, he would needs impart this diquiet to mee, and did me the honour to reveale, that ince the late aembly and intertainment at the marriage of his Siter, where all the Court Stars appeared in their brightet glory, Themira was till preent in his memory, that indeed he had beheld her with more admiration, and entertained her with much more content then any other: that ince having een her again accidentally, he had not been able to guard his heart from a particular inclination it reented for her beauty, nor could he part from her, but with I know not what contraint, which fill'd his boome with diquiet, whilt he was abent from her.

We were both of us yet o young, we could not gues the name of this new breeding paion, but in a very hort time after experience fully taught it us. The hort abode we made in that
Catle augmented the Princes trouble, and gave birth to mine. I chanced to ee amongt the Captives that were in the Keepers cutody, a young Maid, whoe handome meen, and the Majetick features of her face invited me particularly to conider all her actions; the more I tudied her peron, and demeanour, the more I found her rare, which caued me to bewail her condition. From this compaion prung up the curioity, which made me enquire of her Mother of what Country he was, and the ad diater that brought her into lavery. All that I could then learn was, that at the taking of Sina, he fell into the hands of ome of our Souldiers who had old her to this Keeper, and that her condition deerved no regrets, ince it had never been much better than at preent. I could not be atisfied with this account, but rather wiht he might have lot many things of advantage and importance together with her liberty, that might have poken her of a greater quality, though I could not have heard that neither without orrow; and bearing to the Court, as well the remembrance of her miery, as the Image of her beauty; I conidered them both a long time, only with a ence of tendernes and indifferency.

In the mean time, Senira at our return was fully acquainted, that what before we had been ignorant of, was called Love; and whatever other paion he eteemed that trouble in his oul, he found it anwer only to that Name; and in this knowledge he eagerly ought the opportunity to meet Themira: But the firt time he came into
her preence his tongue was tyed up in an unuual ilence, which put him into uch a trouble, as never till then had befaln him, inomuch that he could not alute her without a tammering impediment, and his udden change would have been eaily remark'd, if ome Ladies had not put him upon the dicoure of his hunting, and thoe other divertiements, they imagined he had been to eek in the Country. He indeavoured afterwards in many other encounters to behave himelf more confidently in her preence, and went ometimes prepared exprely to entertain her in particular, but immediately a udden inward diffidence controuled his tronget reolutions, o that in two months time all he could do, was rather to expres his grief upon his face, then proclaim it with his tongue. He often complained to me, that he knew not what repect hindred him from declaring himelf openly. In fine, conumed inwardly with a flame, he could not handomely bring to light, he reolved to extinguih it abolutely, by not eeing her, knowing her preence only nourihed that heat. But when the pleaant eaon had invited his Mitres to return into the Country, not being able to indure her abence, whoe only memory excited uch troubles in his breat, he asked me, if I would accompany him to Coupava, that Catle being not far ditant from Themira's: I told him it would be a very great honour to me, when ever he would vouchafe to go there, & to receive him in the bet manner that could be; I ent my Father notice of his deign, & two dayes after we went, only with uch attendance
as might not too much dicover us. The whole journey he entertained me with his Amours, and complained of the cruelty of his Fate, in that he fore-aw his Father would never condicend to it, though Themira hould fairly correpond, which he likewie placed amongt his doubts: I mildely told him, he ought to attempt all means and remedies before he yeilded to dipair, and that I could not believe Themira would refue the honour of his noble affection, he having too great a tock of wit not to dicern the infinite advantages might follow, provided he could clearly penetrate his jut and honet intentions.

Ariving with the entertainment of thee dicoures at Coupava, we were omewhat urprized finding Themira there, who accompanied her Mother that was come to viit mine. Senira was extreamly joyful of that good fortune, but it being already late, the mall portion of that dying evening pas'd in uual Complements and civilities. The next morning all the Nobility and Gentry that inhabits near thoe parts come to pay their obedience to the Prince, and they already talked of nothing but hunting to divert him: when having told them, that he was deirous to tate the weeter repoe of that olitude, every one retir'd to their dwellings, leaving him the free liberty to compleat his deign. The firt time we attempted to viit Themira, was with my Mother, but their ceremonious repects, and the plended treatment they made for him, hindred him from making known any thing of his paion. The next time we waited on her, he began
to dicover ome parks of his great flame, though paringly; and my Mother and Themira's being retir'd, we remained alone with that beauty, who had the charge to perform the honour of the Houe, and hew us all the rarities, of which Senira took o little notice, that although there were very many which deerved a curious urvey, and might have challenged our admiration, yet he could hardly be o much the Mater of his patience and reaon, as to vouchafe to look on them. Themira who quickly perceived his mall complaiance, told him he was extreamly orry there was nothing worthy his view; yet he wondered not he took o little delight therein, becaue as it was unworthy of his nobler fancy, o it was an abue to his patience to trive to entertain him any longer in that dull olitude, it being eaie to judge his more choice contentments ummoned him back again to Court.

This complement wakened the Princes ilence, which his oft paion had rocked into a muing lumber, and obliged him to a reply, rather that he might not be thought incivil, then to hew himelf amorous; yet his paion favourably over-biaed his will, and perwaded him to hape his anwer in thee words. If, as you tell me beauteous Themira, my atisfaction were rather to be at the Court, than in this place, I cannot ee what reaon could oblige me to leave it; the interet which called me hither, be it what it will, mut needs be mot powerful till detaining me here: but I know not what trange enigmatical Fate mine is, that having o happily found what I exprely
came to eek, my melancholly is nevertheles augmented. Truly reply'd he, It amazes me to think how it is poible you hould be troubled with too much contentment, for I cannot believe you came to eek out trouble. Alas! Madam, anwered he, 'Tis the nature of that charm which poees me, to find no more repoe, amidt my joyes, than my afflictions.

I hall wonder now no more, reply'd he, ince it is a caue not to be found in nature; You have reaon, aid he, it is altogether divine; if it were an ordinary thing I might withtand it: but withal Themira, if the Sun be not guilty of their blindnes, who too boldly expoe their ight to his bright rayes; if the Sea be not culpable of the wracks of thoe many veels which voluntarily throw or launch themelves into its watery Empire, what caue can I have to complain of that trouble which I have my elf courted and cherihed, without the leat of its allowance? It belongs to you, alone then, reparted he, to eek the remedy; but, aid he, my Cure, as well as my Malady depends on the ame Subject; So that although I alone have brought my elf into this traight, yet does not the remedy thereof reide within my elf. If it be o, anwered he, then dicloe your grief, perhaps 'tis not a thing inenible like the Sea, or Sun: True, aid Senira, yet nevertheles it is more bright and replendent then the one, and more unbridled and tempetuous than the other; in fine Themira it is Love, Love! But — he topt at that word, proceeding no further, and he reum'd the peech miling, and aying: But
what Sir? Goe on I beeech you—yet, I mut condemn my own curioity, ince it may well uffice me to know, that if this place does not contribute any thing to your delights, no more does it adde to your Melancholly. It is true, anwer'd he, omewhat troubled, the place of it elf would be indeed very indifferent to me, if it did not contain omewhat that might be the bleed ubject of my joy, as it is now of my griefe.

The Prince finding himelf in o fair a path, endeavour'd to expound his thoughts more intelligibly; and let her know all this dicoure pointed at her: But he having a very ready wit, harpe judgement, and preent memory, ever turned the ence of his peech another way: and whether he feigned that he did not rightly undertand him, or really believed he only poke this out of Gallantry and complaiance, he o handomely warded all his complements, that when we were returned to the Catle, having examined all her behaviour, we could not fathome any thing of her deign, or lay hold of the leat illable that might eem to ound favourably on the Princes behalf.

But, not to detain you any longer by this recital of a Hitory, of which I hall mention nothing, which does not ome way concerned me, you mut know, in fine Sybaris, that Senira at another time, made an ample declaration of his affection for Themira, who yeilded not immediately; That fair lady reited for ome time, till he found his love was as reall and honet, as it appeared violent:
afterward he conented to entertain his noble affection with all the mutual correpondency that honour would allow of. But for my own part, that paion, that made me igh for the captivity of the fair lave, inpired me by degrees with a deign to lighten her ufferings. To this effect, I deired the Keeper to treat her les rudely then the ret, and not dare to put her to any unhandome or ervile labour, and to make the fellow the more obervant, I cau'd an old woman who had been my nure, to tell him, that my Mother had an intent to take her to her elf.

During my reidence there. I delighted much to be in the Hall, where he was often working with many others. The pleaure I took in beholding her, made me inenibly wate much time there, whereof Senira many times asked me the reaon, which hame obliged me to conceal: Though I had often told him, how much the beauty and modet gracefulnes of this Captive urpaed the ret of them. Themira returning to the Court drew us with her, for my part, I left not Coupava, but with much repugnance, and before I went, I would needs be acquainted with the fair Captives name, and learnt that he was called neria. At that word Merame, interrupted his dicoure, cating his eyes up towards Heaven, after he had et two or three deep ighes at liberty, and then again went on with his relation. That weet name came as often into my mouth, as her fair Idea into my mind. I often retyr'd into my elf to forme it the more lively, and when my imagination had done it's utmot,
I entertain'd my elf with thee oft whipers, all that I can imagine of beautiful and perfect, is neria; but what? neria is a Captive, this reflexion brought no les orrow, then the brightnes of her Image brought content.

A while after my returne to Court, I was informed that a lave belonging to the keeper of Coupava, was come to the City to provide things neceary for his Marriage with neria. I was more urprized at this novel, then I hould have been at a thunder-clap, and as if I had already declared my elf for her, I reolv'd abolutely to oppoe this match, and not conidering any further what could interes me o powerfully, I tole from the Court greedily, and being wing'd with love and anger, rode all that night towards Coupava. I was Infinitely atonihed, at my arrival the next morning, to find the Catle empty of all its inhabitants, and my atonihment weld to depair. When it was told me, that all the people were in the Temple, aiting at the Ceremonies of neria's Marriage. I was alighted from my hore, but, as if it had been a long journey thither, leaping into the addle again, I preed him forward with the greatet peed, towards the Temple, where being hatily entred, I aw the aembly neer an Altar laden with victims, and one of the Priets of the god of Marriage, claping the hands of the intended husband and neria's together. I knew not whether the ceremony were already compleated, for the fear I had contracted hindred me from minding that inquiry; but perceiving the Bride melting in tears. I would
needs know the reaon, and it was told me, that it was impoible to perwade her to a conent to accept of him, he not giving any other anwer, then ighs and tears: and as I would have asked her the caue, he fell down at my feet, and folding her uppliant arms about my knees: Ah! my Lord, cry'd he, protect me againt a Tyranny, from which neither the Sanctity of this place, nor the Deity that is adored could defend me: I know the condition of my Captivity obliges me to receive what Spoue is alotted me, upon fair terms; but I do not believe they can contrain me to take an infamous vilain, whom my Keeper hath hired to this purpoe, that thereby he may compleat his own ugly deigns, deiring to gain the ame power over my untained Chatity, as he hath over my Liberty. The Deity's are Witnes of the truths I tell you; and I hope for that protection from your goodnes, and authority, which I now conjure you not to refue to perecuted innocency.

If thoe words in that mournful accent he pronounced them, were capable to move the mot indifferent Spectators, who now began to plead for her, I leave you to judge what deep impreions they made in me; and whether he had need of uch powerful Advocates as her eloquent tears to implore a mercy, which I had a more eager deire to grant, then he could have to beg for: I raied her intantly up, and telling her the ubject of her orrow and complaint was too jut not to be allowed of; I caued the Ceremony to be abruptly broken off, after I had highly menaced
the Keeper, if ever he gave neria the leat caue to complain hereafter; and putting her into his Wives cutody, told her, he hould give me a evere account of her. Then my devoirs which called me again to Court, forced me with infinite regrets to leave Coupava, and I got home again the next morning that they might not examine or gues the caue of my abence and journey. But before I parted, I received thanks from neria's Mother, for the inetimable favour I had rendred her daughter, and promied her to continue my Protection and bet ervice as long as ever they hould remain within the Precincts of our juridiction.

When I came to my Mothers preence, I related all this tory to her, but in uch a diembling manner, that he could not perceive the leat interet I had, or that I harboured any other thoughts, but only of equity and charity; which nevertheles moved her to remove them from that lewd fellow, as indeed he oon after did. And—when my Mother took neria into her houe, I received and entertained her in my boome and heart entirely, and Love oon made me know he was my Soveraign Mater.

You may have perhaps learned whilt you were in our Country, that we have a natural antipathy againt the Scythians who are indeed born our Enemies: beides the frequent quarrels betwixt Princes for their interet foments that imbred hate; o that if we ometimes put up our Swords, it was but to unheath them with the more fury afterwards: It eemed, however, that at this time
there was a mot firm Peace etablihed; yet, as it is impoible long to mother the flames of a natural fewd and antient animoity, o the frontire Garrions of either Nation began from ome particular differences betwixt their repective inhabitants to blow the covered parks into an open fire of contention and War, which having • een cherihed and upplied with ewel from either party lats even to this day.

Balden our Prince, knowing the mighty preparation the Scythians made againt him, finding himelf alone too weak to reit thoe formidable numbers of men which they do ordinarily amas together, ent Ambaadours to the Prince of Sogdiana, to put a period to all their own private differences, and ecure their States by a timely union and conjunction of their Forces, which might defend them againt the common Enemy, to whom their former unhappy dientions had given many great advantages, which they had found to their ad prejudice. The Sogdian Prince opened both his arms and heart to welcome this propoition; and to tye up their amity with the mot indioluble bands, he profered his daughter, a beautiful and vertuous Princes to Senira for a Wife: So that our Ambaadours propering in their negotiation above their hopes, laden with Preents, returned with thoe perons whom the Sogdian Prince ent to ee the Articles of Peace ratisfied, which we eteemed very advantagious, and particularly for the profered Match betwixt their Princes and brave Senira. But he, who expected no other but the publick interet in this
agreement, was much atonihed that they had engaged him in a buines that concerned him o particularly, without ever communicating it unto him: and finding himelf driven to this great traight, either of reolving to looe Themira, or renounce this Match; he did me the honour to ask me what coure he hould take for the etablihment of his repoe and atisfaction; but I was not in a capacity to give him any olid counel at that time, having my own heart burdened with as great a freight of trouble. The day preceeding, one of my Uncles came to viit me, and having led me into the Palace Garden; after a hort preface, which promied me the highet felicity I could wih for in the world, he told me that Balden had o particular an amity or affection for me, that he would needs have me find out a Mitres for my elf, that o we might be harers in the bleings of his Sons triumph and olemnize our Nuptials on the ame day. And if for that end, I had any inclination at Court which were uitable to my quality, I might freely declare it, that they might ue their endeavours and care to atisfie Baldens commands and my deires. I was not readily furnihed with any other anwer, but only that I had hitherto beheld the Ladies at the Court with too much indifferency to have any particular inclination, and that if they would allow me time, I was yet young enough to pas ome years thus ingle, and it would not be too late hereafter to think of uch a weighty buines; Think of it then on your part, aid he, and we will conider of it on ours, and o left me. Thee
words filled me with more dipleaure, then he had flattered me before with hopes. Amidt the trange diorders it caued in me when I was by my elf; I nicely examined all that he had poken, and reflecting on the Ladies of my acquaintance, neria only came to my thoughts with pleaure, he only inpired me with entiments of Love, and did eem to me mot worthy of affection.

With thee thoughts I was carried, where I might behold her to confirm my elf in this truth, and I was by her preence fortified in the high opinion I had conceived that my eteem was very rational, and that there was none could deerve o truely to be cherihed and prefered. In fine, I reolved with my elf to give no atisfaction to my Uncle in what he had propoed, nor to lend any more an ear to uch dicoures; and o far was I from making any particular addres to the Ladies at Court, that I left off that freedom and familiarity I had otherwhile practied amongt them; I was ever of a more ullen humour, and avoided even the converation of thoe with whom I had mot intimacy.

This change of behaviour was oon taken notice of at Court, where mot men are rather apt to pry into others actions, than to regulate their own: every one admired at me, epecially knowing it was put to my choice to elect any he I could bet fancy. My dearet friends were hugely concerned at my black melancholly, and could not poible imagine that to be the caue of my affliction, which they judged rather might be a jut reaon to make me rejoyce, but my dipleaure
was utterly concealed from them all. Senira was the only Privado to whom I uncaed my mind; but, I found him as enibly tormented as my elf: for having lived hitherto very well atisfied in his affection, he was now fallen into dipair, becaue his dearet Themira, when he lat went to viit her, had nothing but reproaches for his infidelity in her dicoure, wherewith to entertain him, intead of thoe delightful amorous accents he was ued to ooth his paionate oul withal at former meetings: And, indeed, in the hot fits of his reentments he would often ay, Would to God Merame we were yet both of us free from this Tyranny of Love: you would not then have a Mitres that is a Captive, nor I a Subject, whoe haughtines or cruelty tramples on my affection and ubmiions; 'tis thoe alone that thus divert both your devoir and mine from running in the due channel of filial obedience, we owe to our Parents; but your condition is happier yet then mine, you have not yet been treated unhandomely, or at leat unkindly by neria, as I have by Themira: For having lately undertood my Fathers Will touching my Marriage with the Sogdianian Princes; I was o infinitely urprized, that conidering how much it travered my Love and deign for Themira, I durt not attempt to viit her for three or four dayes, not deiring to acquaint her with it, till I had found ome way whereby to aure her that my fidelity was unalterable: at lat, amidt that hurry and ditraction which had beet me, not being able to lay hold on any other upport but my
own reolved contancy, the only pillar I could ret my hopes on, I went to ee her. But, O gods, what a change did I meet with from her; She received me as her Princes Son, not as her fond Lover. I found her in a temper of uch cold civility, as made my blood turn even to Ice. This urprize and atonihment, intead of proving my true innocency, appeared to her ditrutful eyes, as if it had been the face of guiltines, which made her anger ucceed in thee harh words, which he utter'd in a dicompoed tone. Your viage, Senira, betrayes your intentions, it's alteration and often hifted colour peaks your peridiounes; nor can your concience which writes its elf upon your changing Countenance, uffer your deluions to be hid any longer, which to perit in were a weaknes unworthy of any lave, much les a Prince. But what then? I have been as highly preumptuous in my eaie faith, as you are reproveable for your hypocriie: had I never conidered you as my Lover, but beheld you alwayes as my Prince, I hould have no jut caue to wonder, as I do now, in vain, that your heart can adore and pay the full tribute of affection and veneration to this tranger Princes; yet have I reaon for complaint however, that you forake Themira, after you have o olemnly engaged your faith to her; But this is ome conolation and retribution, that I can trive to correpond with you in every particular; and it hall uffice me, that you cannot but know, it is the noble heart and vertuous dipoition rather makes a Gentleman a Prince, then his Birth or empty Title;
whoe blood if tainted, and whoe pirit if degenerate, tumbles him beneath the meanet of his Subjects in the records of Fame and Honour. I would have anwered her, but that cruell and unjut Lady topt her car againt all my peeches, by which I might have wiped away the aperion of ingratitude he tuck upon me; and then uddenly quitted me in a place, where I could neither conveniently follow her, nor be moan my elf.

The Prince entertained me with this his misfortune, when Balden his Father entred into his Chamber, and pake thus to me, well Merame, what preparations doe you make againt Senira's wedding? you are ad me-thinks, may it not be, that having a long time aociated with him, as his mot faithful compagnion, and eeing him now provided of a Mitris, and your elf without any, you mourn your olitary condition. But if o, or not, I doe not intend that you hould only be an idle aitant at the ceremony; but rather help to make up one of the weetet parts in the full harmony of joy and pleaure, Come follow me, he went forth as he pake thee lat words, and lead us to his wives Chamber, where catching me by one hand, and taking Geroe the Daughter of his Favorite Hylebas by the other, I doe not believe aid he, that you have any objections to make againt my deign, and your Parents conent; The choice could not be more equal then by this match, nor can you, according to the opinion of every one; live happier then together: may the gods bles you with as much felicity as your hearts can wih.

Neither of us made any other reply, but a profound obeyance, and I was very glad the many complements we received from thoe that were preent exempted me from thoe I hould have been obliged to make in particular to Geroe, on whom in common civility I was obliged to waite upon to her own lodging, where I quitted her coldly. Being returned to my own apartment, and freed from the importunity of thoe that did exalt and bles my good fortune, I hut my elf up within my Chamber; where, what I either thought or aid, during my firt tranports in that Melancholly Cell, were too tedious to relate. My reolutions, in ine, made me decree to give a cleer dicovery of my paion to neria, and profer her Marriage if he could but conent to love me, as I did her fair elf. I left my chamber with this intent to eek her out, and though the night were very much advanced, and mot perons retired to their repoe, I decended into the Garden by a back way, and oftly tealing along the wall to a place cloe by neria's chamber, whoe windows gave them the full propect of a long alley. I there made a tand, hoping at leat to have the bleing of being neer her peron. What can you think, in fine, Sybaris if the effects of my paion? Though the night were muffled up in its thicket clouds, yet I pryed every where hoping to meet the favour of ome mall beam of light, whereby to dicover her: and hearing a voice. I litned attentively and undertood it was her Mother, who was thus dicouring to her. I thought, Daughter, that Fate had no more wayes left to afflict
us; and that we were arrived at the lat Stage of all our mieries; But I perceive cruell Fortune is not yet glutted with our ufferings. He that had declar'd himelf thy Protector, is become thy enemy, and if he epoue (as 'tis to be feared) the Fathers quarrel, with the daughters peron, we mut reolve to perih. Wherefore, replyed, neria? If you have been but as religiouly ecret as my elf, we have nothing to fear. Ah my dearet Daughter, anwer'd the Mother, thoe two families being united together by that trict alliance, thou cant no longer hide a face, whoe features, though truly innocent, are too too dangerous for thy afety. Mother reparted he, we mut commit all to the goodnes of the deities, who have preerved us hitherto. We mut not pry into the book of detiny, the Characters are not legible to Mortals, and we find every day, that what befals us, is contrary to what we either feared or gueed. Let us live, in the mean time, in hope; and ince our arms are too hort to unty this marriage knot, thoe knots, its aid, being all made fat in heaven, we will reerve our complaints, if it mut be o, till we ly under the Evil that hall fall on us. Her Mother, could not bar her tears from falling at this dicoure, and reaching to embrace her, as I perceiv'd by a faint light, he aid, Ah worthy Daughter, no, I cannot beleeve, that heaven has given thee uch a full tock of vertue and courage, to let thee continue long in this condition.

They aid omething more afterwards, but whipered it o oftly, it did not reach my eare
perfectly: then uddenly after they were wholly ilent. Yet I remained fix'd in the ame place, with a mot greedy attention till day break, and then fearing dicovery I return'd to my Chamber: Being thrown upon my bed, I reflected on their whole dicoure a thouand times, without being able to comprehend or fathom the depth of it. What, aid I, hall I dare believe he poke of me? and may I flatter my elf with this vanity to have had the raret jewel of nature in my protection? No, no, thee words were meant of ome other, it being impoible but that I hould love her alwayes tenderly, o that if her Protector is become her Enemy, they cannot be addreed to me. Nevertheles, I am he, into whoe fortunate arms he cat her bleed elf at Coupava; and I am alo commanded to marry Geroe: But, what is that particular interet that makes her apprehend this alliance o much? Thus was I weather-beaten 'twixt thee everal troubleome fears and doubts, when a oft lumber, caued by my over-long watching, and deep penivenes, tole unawares upon me, and made a happy truce in my minde for ome few hours.

'Tis, aid Sybaris, the only thing that is not an enemy to us, all nature ele declares it elf againt the unhappy lover, when leep as a courteous friend many times renders him contented with a pleaing dream, which awake, the whole world denies him: But, alas! 'tis too imaginary and hort liv'd a joy, to recompence thoe daily mieries.

It grew omewhat late, peru'd Merame, and I
was yet bound fat in the eaie chains of leep, when my Father commanded ome to call me, that I might prepare myelf to receive Hylebus together with his Wife and Daughter whom he had invited to dinner. I had carce the time to lip on my cloaths, when ome of the company arrived, and the pretended Mitres with them, whom I received with the greatet civility and the leat affection imaginable. I was forc'd, however, to wear out that day in diimulation, nay, and many more beides: whilt the frequent bluhes that invaded my cheeks, ent thither from my heart as the Meengers of its trouble and perplexity, though imputed to my juvenile modety, opportunely concealed the indignation, and didain which a paler face would have told them, filled my breat againt all Love for her.

Many dayes lipt thus away er'e I could have a happy tyde of opportunity to entertain neria in particular; and I took notice that ince Hylebas frequented our houe, he endeavoured to keep out of our preence and Society. The impatience I was in to peak with her, taught me to end her Mother word by a ervant of whoe fidelity I had many proofs, that I had omewhat to communicate to her; this Meage allarmed her, and brought her quickly to me, omewhat affrighted, where I waited for her, with a no les troubled pirit; but her atonihment grew above both our fears, when I enquired for what caue he and her daughter were of late o cloely confin'd, and eemed to be the only two in the whole Family, that expres'd no igns of joy for the hopes of my
udden Marriage, with Geroe? That, for my part, I would continue to be till the ame I had promis'd them to be; and if any dicontent were the jut caue of their retirement, I would engage to procure them all the atisfaction it was poible for me to make them. I had before decreed to break the ice altogether, and acquaint her further; but, then, had not the power to pronounce the bleed name of neria, o that without any fuller dicovery, I left her, after he had anwered me, that they had received many favours in our houe as great as numerous, and that if they had been o unhappy as not to attend for ome dayes pat, the ervice of the Family, and their jut devoirs, her Daughters indipoition was the ole and unavoidable caue of it. I was vext that I had not abolutely dicloed my intention, and fearing leat what I had told her, might redouble her upition, as oon as he had left me, I approached their window to hear what report he would make to neria, to whom he adly pake in this manner. Well, neria, had I not reaon to fear the initer adventure I conjectur'd, and couldt thou think the gods would have indued thee with o much contancy, and generoity, but that they knew thou houldt one day tand in need of it? Merame would never have poken of his alliance with that Family, in uch a manner, if he had not known the certain reaon why we evaded the fatal preence of Hylebas o carefully. If Heavens indulgent goodnes had but at leat preerved Soixa, perhaps he might have found out ome happy Stratagem, whereby to have releaed us
from this Captivity. 'Tis in vain, aid neria, to contend againt Fortune, whatever doome the deities have pronounced is no les jut the irrevocable; we mut ubmit without reluctancy; and then we hall have this conolation at the leat, that although our orrows like a trong net entangles us on every ide, without any hopes of releae, yet we doe uffer innocently. The event will declare the will of heaven more clearly, and ince there is no griefe o bitter, which the leat bleing from above cannot turne into joy and happines, let us not dipaire, our wounded pirits may yet be cured? and for Merame I eteeme him too brave and generous to lend a hand or heart to the unworthy deigns of his Father in Law.

I would tay no longer there, but thought my elf ufficiently inform'd wheron to ground a fuller inquiry afterwards, and if I were hitherto very indifferent to Geroe, this inpired me with a mortall averion for her, as being contrained to act the feigned part of a Lover towards her, who was the daughter of my neria's capitall enemy. This neceity of diembling to her did o dipleae me, that I fell ick of a mot violent Feaver. Which kept me prioner fifteen days together, during which time, the bet meanes towards my recovery, was the comfort of Geroe's abence, and the pleaing remembrance of the beautiful neria, whoe interets became extremely dear to me. One day as I walked in the Garden, under a pretence of taking the freh ayr to perfect my dawning health, but indeed to
have the opportunity to peak to neria and her Mother. I tept aide, and tole into their Chamber, when there were none, but themelves; and finding them urpriz'd, doe not apprehend my preence aid I to them, you have a econd Soixa in my peron, and I engage, out of a true affection only, to render you all the ervices that he could poibly pay you: Let not the alliance with Hylebas diturb you, if it oppoe your interet, it does no les thwart my inclination, and if the unparralell'd neria vouchafe but to accept my faith and hearty ervice, and doe no longer make the caue of her misfortunes a ecret to me, I hope I hall not be uncapable to procure her happines.

They were both o urpriz'd with this propoition and requet, that they could not for the preent contrive any anwer, o that renewing my dicoure and courthip, Is it your diffidence, or wonder at the unexpected novelty of what I tell you, that makes you wrap up your mindes in ilence? Ah neria, if you upect my entiments, doe but examine the heart that conceived them, it is in your poeion, and you hall evidently find it contains nothing but affection for you. The Mother would have cat her elf down at my feet to have anwer'd, but having prevented it, he aid, we never doubted Sir, of your more then ordinary generoity, we have already found the benefits of it, in many happy trialls, but you may be pleaed not to wonder, if having falen already into o many unexpected nares, we feared that which menaced us o evidently.
And ince you have o much curioity and noble care, as to enquire the reaons, I will reveale uch things which if made known to any other, but your worthy elf, might hazard our very lives: But I doe gladly find, that heaven has placed us under your protection, as the Tutelary Angel of a family broken and ruin'd by Hylebas, of whom, as I beleeve and have too many reaons to fear, we are at preent the only ad remainders.

Sina is the place of our birth, neria had the Prince of that great City for her Father, and I for my brother; If you have ever heard by what accident it fell under your Princes power, you may know, that the Army which beeiged it was commanded by Hylebas, who for his private interet, and to revenge ome corrections for his youthful inolencies, engaged Balden in that war. He had formerly made a vovage into Peria, to learn in their famous Academies thoe vertues which he never put in practie. At his return, be made ome tay in our City, where his condition being known, he was very civilly treated in all companies, As then he was but young, and truly more compleat in garb and peron then in judgment or wit; for manners obliging him to waite upon the Prince Dizman, and his wife Mayrem, he intantly trangreed in that repect that was due to them both. As oon as he beheld that Lady, whoe rare perfections had gained this general acknowledgment thorow all Aia, that nature had never brought forth o great a miracle there, as he was, he was inflamed towards
her, but with o impure a heat, as that glorious Planet had never produc'd in any oul, but his. For the Majety of her adored face, had ever imprinted and inpir'd as much repect and veneration as love: only the heart of Hylebas was uceptible of that unlawful wild-fire; and he brute man, had o much preumption, as to beleeve what ever he undertook in that deign would proper as he wiht it. This made him abide there longer then he intended, during which time, he diplaid all his wit and gallantry which nevertheles was no better received or eteemed then at the highet rate of pride and folly. Perceiving, in the end, that his confidence had deluded him, and that Meyrem had o evere a vertue, as would not toop or give indeed the leat audience, to his deires and paion; to attain his pernicious deign, he reolved to take in the aitance of inchantments to allure or quell that vertuous Lady's heart, as full of honour as his was of lut.

As there are many in that Country who make a particular profeion of Magick, it was eay for him to come to the knowledge of an old woman, who was reputed to be very skilful in that Art; to whom he dicover'd his black oul, that he might the better uit her black experiments to it: and that orceres having, in fine, promis'd him the effecting of what he o greedily deired, by her witchcraft, he thought to eal up her lips with a gold ignet which he betow'd upon her: but his profuion by which he thought to conceal his plot, was that which brought it firt to dicovery:
For this old covetous witch imagined, that if o much were given to hide a ecret, others would be as liberal if he reveal'd it: and conidering with her elf, that what he had already in poeion was her own and could not be retir'd, it would be both more afe and profitable now to gain a new Fee by detecting him, and aving her elf from danger, into which poibly the performance of what he had then undertaken might let her fall. She hatned therefore to a publick Magitrate of the City, and informed him that a tranger of quality had been to olicite her to contrive a michief as much beyond her power as well to perpetrate; but becaue he might probably addres himelf to ome other more cunning and les honet to bewitch or charme Meyrem to love him as he deired; her tender heart had moved her to give him this honet advertiement, that o he might acquaint Diman and prevent Hylebas. The interrogatories they more particularly put to this woman, oon brought the whole mytery of iniquity to light; but the buines being tetchy, and his condition too lofty to proecute him the ordinary way for uch dicoveries: They judged it more politique to lay hold of that woman, then to charge it upon him, whereby he finding his deign dicloed, might of himelf quit the Town, fearing the jut reentments it might awake againt him. All ucceeded as they had judiciouly conjectured; he left the City, but did not give over his unworthy project. At that time he made war upon the Scyth • ans, and his Father in its firt beginning
was general, to which high command himelf ucceeded. Your Enemies, who were already advanced far into our Country, taking their advantage pillaged us mot trangely. We made our jut complaints, but for atisfaction returning us no other anwer but this only, that our neutrality was upitious to them, and that they would till treat us as Enemies, unles we would openly declare our elves; This violence quickly obliged us to take up Arms, but it was to ide with yours; and our Forces being thus united decreaed the Enemies much, o that for four years ucceively, we counter ballanced that conquet which manifetly inclined to their ide before.

Thee Martial employments how ever, did not take Hylebas off from the thoughts of attaining his impure deires. He attempted to teal away Meyrem by the aitance of ome Scythians whom he had hired to that end, becaue it might not be upected he was the Author of o unhandome an enterprize; but he being ever attended with a numerous Guard, all thoe Setters forfeited either their lives or liberties in the attaque; and one Officer of the Crew, hoping thereby to obtain his freedom, confeed they were et on by Hylebas, and had acted nothing but by his appointment and order. Dizman was preently made acquainted of it, who had already found much backwardnes and dicontent amongt his • ouldiers, who though they were till et to cut out the toughet work, had alwayes the leat pay and plunder, which your General retained to himelf.
Though he had much ado to quell and keep in his indignation, yet he would not pull off the vizard of diimulation till he heard you had a clandetine Treaty on Foot with the Scythians, then he thought it tamenes to bridle it any longer; wherefore waiting with Hylebas to confer about their Warlike affairs, he complained that his good affection was very ill requited; that they ought not to treat their aociates as if they were Stipendaries, but that all hould hare equally as well in the benefits of Treaties and Agreements, as in the Troubles and Dangers they had participated largely in: Hylebas, anwered him very coldly, that having never done nor treated any thing, but what he was a Witnes of, he could not but wonder at this dicoure. Nevertheles, reply'd Dizman, you cannot hinder the change in your countenance from witneing againt you, nor had I voted in the deign of urprizing Meyrem, to which purpoe you employ'd the Scythians. This made Hylebas bluh yet more, how ever with a quaint expreion he reply'd, I undertand not what you mean: you hould do well to be aured of uch things before you give any credit to them: if you peak with more truth, you would allow it more ingennity and plainnes. Say what you pleae, return'd Dizman, but I have poken no Enigmaes but what you may unfold; nor can you deny the verity of thee reproaches without a manifet falhood, which this hall vindicate when we meet in a place convenient to dipute our interet, aid he, hewing his Sword. Thoe that were preent could not prevent this
diorder, though they calm'd their welling paions from flying higher for a time. Two dayes after, the Generals quarrel had interreed the Souldiers, and that put them into dientions. This diention provoked them to words, and thee injurious words begot blows. The Officers hatned to appeae the tumult, but Hylebas, finding himelf well accompanied, intead of appeaing the broil, charged ours o furiouly that they were fain to give ground, till Dizman put them forward by his preence and example: whoe courage and heat did o quell your men, that they had much ado by their retreat to ave themelves, or their General Hylebas, who received many wounds from our Princes own hands This affront out deeper than his Sword, and therefore dipatching a Meenger to Balden, he o diguied the whole action, that we were charged with all the guilt and blame, as the ole Authors of this mutiny: and your General received expres Orders to conclude a Peace with the Scythians, and by their aitance to take a full revenge upon us. Dizman, who well foreaw what would befall, had caued our Army to retire, and gave udden command for freh Levies, to be in the better poture to receive his Enemies. But before he could prepare what was fit, Hylebas marched with his Army, and the aitance of three thouand Scythians, and laid cloe iege to Sina. Though we were unprovided, yet he lot much time, pains and men, and nothing but his treachery had ucces. The Daughter of that old Hag, whom he would otherwhile have employ'd to enchant Meyrem, was
then o beotted with love of Hylebas, that her paion and ignorance made her imagine, his affection to Meyrem was the only obtacle that did hinder his return of love to her again, o that he beheld that Princes as her rival only. When he aw Hylebas o near the City, her deires grew hotter at that her amorous Planets approach, and her hatred became o violent againt Meyrem, that he had the confidence to undertake the delivery of the Garrion into his hands, upon condition he would atisfie her wihes, which he preumed he partly deerved long before, but much more if he atchieved that exploir.

Hylebas, who had often felt the fury of our allies, was very eager to redeem his bleeding honour at o eaie a rate, and therefore willingly promis'd all that her longing heart could prompt her to demand of him. The Gold Signet her Mother had received of him, and the addition of wealth betow'd by Dizman for their dicovery, had o well furnihed her, that he was married to the Officer who kept the keyes of the City Gates. Whoe priviledge did much facilitate the means her paion had uggeted to her, to let in ome of the Enemies Troops into the City.

Though he were married, yet was he very amorouly perecuted by a young man, whom he began to ooth with hopes, and in hort to promie him what he ued for if he at an appointed time, could but find the means to cat her huband into a ound leep, which ince the iege began he eldome gave way to. Love, as you may take ome notice of, would be the only fatal Miniter
of our ruine. This fellow immediately procures a trong omniferous draught, which he firt made trial of on ome other, and being now provided, he ent word to Hylebas that he expected him punctually at midnight, at the Eat Gate, which he hould find open and no Guards to oppoe him.

At night to make her promied treachery good, he mixed ome of that potion in her Husbands drink at his upper, and was as careful to betow ome of it on the Souldiers which had that Port that night: and at the time appointed he waited at the place aigned whilt the whole Guard were in a profound leep. Hylebas failed not to end a party firt to make ure of the Gate, which being poeed and he advertiz'd of it, he advanced with peed commanding his Troops to follow with the tricktet ilence imaginable: and being enter'd the Town by this wile, he gave orders to put every one to the word that hould make the leat oppoition.

The Inhabitants and Souldiers were o urprized at the terrible alarm, that eeing no body make head, he eaily marched directly towards the Palace, whither Love, Hatred and Revenge, led him with fury and precipitation.

Imagine a Troop of enraged Wolves, that had trangled the drowzy dogs et to guard a flock, ruhing into the old, where thoe timerous, but innocent creatures, thought themelves as afe, as they were trongly guarded: uch was the poor Peoples confuion, the Souldiers diorder, and the Princes amazement, who nevertheles caued
the by treets to be intantly chained and barricado'd, but to no end, the multitude that hurry'd towards his Palace as their lat refuge and Sanctuary, broke them oon down again, and left the way open for his men to draw up in a great place which faced it. There Hylebas began to cry out Victory, and that his blacket actions might be apparent, though Heaven had hid its elf with the thicket curtains of Clouds; that ignoble General, caued the contiguous buildings to be fired, that the obcurity of the night might not hide from him the objects of his vengeance. Dizman, finding the los of the City was inevitable, and willing at leat to ave what was dearet to him in the world, ran to Meyrems Chamber which looked towards the Sea, where but a few dayes before, he was delivered of neria: and conjuring her to embarque her elf immediately in a Ship which lay at Anchor jut before them, he promis'd to follow her immediately. That generous Lady, anwered him, no otherwie, but that whatever he did, he neither would fly or ave her elf but with him: and if he mut dye, he would as chearfully dye, as he had lived with him: that he would not complain of her own Fate how evere oever, provided her children were but afe; and hatily putting neria into my hands, with a hower of flowing tears, and her on Zarif, a child of two years old, into her Hubands, go, aid he, to us, embracing us with tendernes mixt with courage, and o much love as cannot have its full expreion, ave thee dear and innocent creatures at leat; and would to
Heaven this might not be the lat of our adieu's! The noie of thoe that enter'd pell-mell into the Chamber unty'd thoe ad embraces, and drove us down a pair of ecret tairs to the Ship which received us. Meyrem, as I have been ince informed, notwithtanding her weaknes and indipoition diguiing her Sex, armed her elf that he might go and relieve her Husband, who expired before her face, pierc'd with a thouand wounds.

That woful object which had doubtles been able to blunt the highet courage, did but whethers, grown indeed les vigorous by ome blood exhauted from her, precious veins, o that hearing Hylebas, who had dicovered her give command to take her alive, he forced her way thorow thoe that were about him, who in obedience to the command their General had given them, fearing to kill her, hindred her not from joyning him; and ruhing upon him with the like fury as a Lyones would do on him who had rob'd her of her whelps: Traytor, aid he, triking at him, dot thou command them to ave my life, that I may take my jut and full revenge on thee; know at leat, that though I cannot redeem my Husband from death, yet I can dye with honour for his ake: two full blows he dicharged upon him, which made him tagger, and dipenc'd his Souldiers from longer obedience, who preently flew on her in multitudes, yet could they not hinder her from making way till he came to her dear Husbands dead Corps, on which he made a ad hift to cat her elf and die.

We being now in formed by certain other mall
Barks, that we were cloely perued, and that to glut his rage, the bloody Hylebas had given trickt orders being come again to himelf, that we hould be ought for every where with diligence, thought it afet to go on hoar at the firt place we could make land, which we did changing our habits, and uddenly parting from each others, that we might not be taken altogether, in cae they hould hear of us. But as the decree of Fate is inevitable, neria and my elf fell into the power of ome who were ranging about the Coats for a prey; and we were afterwards old to the Keeper of Coupava, whilt my Husband, who had more trength and agility, aved himelf in a little wood near hand with Zarif, whither they likewie follow'd him, but how they fared I never ince could have the leat tydings.

And this, Sir, is the ad hitory of our misfortunes; the remainder of our diconolate lives is not unknown to you, and we are now more happy in your goodnes and eteem, then our bet hopes could ever fairly promie, ince after o long a ilent and mournful Captivity and concealment, you have unpinion'd our retraint and given us leave to breath our orrows by lending o curteous an ear to this doleful relation.

This tory mov'd my very oul to compaion, but I was yet more tranported by thoe tears the fairet neria let fall, whilt her Aunt made the relation of it. Nor could I keep mine from breaking prion, before I had expret my elf thus to her: Ah! Madam, what caue have I given you to cherih o ill an opinion of my peron; why did
you not ooner make me acquainted with your ufferings, ince you could not be ignorant how much I might have lightned the too too heavy chains of your Captivity. Can it be poible you hould not have perceived the vehement heat of my love for you? though I have kept it till under the lock and key of a timerous ilence; yet my flame having been as bright as chate and dicreet, might well have been gues'd by you: and ince you knew that I have acted nothing for neria, which any indifferent Judge would not have contrued more an effect of paion and affection then common charity, why have you made your fear or corn the caue of your own ufferings, and thoe torments my own retraint has put upon me? But I hould never mention my own troubles, did I not lye under the guilt of having left her, who was the bleing of my heart, o long under Captivity in my own Fathers houe: and then, perfidious Hylebas, do not believe, thou hat caped the jutice of the gods, Heaven has defer'd its punihments only to make it fall the heavier on thee, for though Divine Jutice comes but low, yet it comes ure, and I believe and hope that I am choen the jut Miniter of it, which I hall inflict with o much the more ecurity, as the interets of neria are dearer to me than thy Geroe. It depends but upon you my Princes, aid I, addreing my elf to her, to allow of it; and if you will not command me to execute it, for my own repects, yet let me do it for jutice and your illutrious Parents akes: a deep igh, which he fetch'd from her heart, as the Prologue
to her following dicoure, impoed a willing ilence on my tongue, whilt he pake thus. Merame your promiing goodnes, which perwaded my Aunt, to tell you the ad tale of our misfortunes, does likewie encourage me to accept of thoe fair proffers you have made to me: I hall not therefore demur, but accept of them in the bet manner my unhappy condition admits of now, I meane, rather under the notion of protection then of ervice. And yet, reply'd I, if you would but conider your preent condition in relation to me, you will oon find it peakes you mitres and Soveraign of my oul; but perhaps, you find it an unhappines, that perons of more power and greater quality then my meannes are not preent to erve you. Not o, anwer'd he, for beides that I am too well acquainted with humility and my own abaement to harbor o uncivil an inmate as pride, o I have already received too great a um of obligations from your bounty to be o ingrateful; and I aure you, that if I cannot make you a full retribution for your favours, you mut impute it more to my want of Fortune, then good will.

This happy declaration and condecention to love was concluded with as much atisfaction as I had ambition or love; and I took a reolution to earch out ome confiding friend, who might ranome this illutrious Captive out of her thraldome. Her confinement infinitely troubled me, yet was I forced to defer it a while and cloak my griefs. During this retraint, all the happines
I could reap, was to entertain her daily with my reiterated vowes and promies, and this omewhat abated the dipleaure I uffer'd in the neceity of eeing Geroe, towards whom he enjoyned me, not to expres any averion, nor could I afford her any illable of pretended affection.

In fine, the Age of winter being much increaed, I undertood of the preparations were makeing to receive the Princes of Sogdiana, whom Balden was to end for by extraordinary Ambaadours. I intreated her to let me cat about for ome meanes whereby to free myelf from Geroe, whom I was already bid to look upon, as her, that was to be my wife, within the hort date of two months. The buines pres'd us equally, and this urgent neceity made me oon vote the reolution to declare myelf openly an Enemy to Hylebas, thereby to unty the chain of Marriage and alliance with his daughter. He had a Son name Zadarem, in whoe company I was to goe to meet the now young Princes: His humour was as little pleaing as his Fathers, being nothing but a meer timpany of Pride; he had few friends at Court, as being one whoe favour any man would have eteemed too dearly purchat at the cheap price of a complement: yet thought himelf too eminent to be o familiar as to receive them in quality of friends or aociates. He had been otherwie extravagantly amourous of Themira, and becaue he had treated him beneath the merits he fancied in himelf, his angry love was turned into hate, which made him take occaion to disoblige and affront her all he could.

Whilt Senira tood fair with Themira, the leat concern'd had taken notice by thoe aiduous addrees he made to her, that he took a more then ordinary delight in entertaining her; but his decreet behaviour rather made them gues then certainly know his purpoe and deires; Only Zadarem, who lookt upon't thorow the Perpective of love and jealouy, had more perfectly decried his mind; and led on by his paion, he wrought o far by his impotures upon Themira's pirit, that he at lat was poeed with the belief of her Princes infidelity, as you have already undertood: and he likewie had informed Balden that the inclination his on had to Themira, was the only caue he expret o little joy and willingnes to have the Princely virgin. Balden having exactly informed himelf in this particular of o grand concernment, had prohibited Senira upon the penalty of his everet dipleaure not to ee Themira any more, whom he alo exprely commanded to confine her elf to her country habitation, to which her own troubled fancy had already caued her to retreate.

The ame day we had paed the confines of Sogdiana, about the evening I accoted him, and having led him to a private place, where I before had ent a gentleman with two weapons, I deired him to make choice of one, and I would take the other. The unexpectancy atoniht him more then the danger of the combat; but as he was truly valiant, after the preparation of a few words, we proceeded to blowes; he defended himelf with as much skill and courage as I aaulted him; I received and gave everal wounds, but, in fine, jutice being in my armour, I gain'd his word with this advantage of being able to goe off my elf, whereas he lay extended with mall hopes of life, which made me end to his ervants to goe and fetch him thence.

In the interim, to ecure my elf, I poted back from whence we came that day, and ecured my elf in a Catle belonging to a Sogdian gentleman, whoe friendhip I had purchaed by ome civilities in his Princes Court. The news of this duell which brought atonihment to every one that heard it, cut deeper in my parents minds then
any accident that ere befel them, they having promied themelves the bet of fortunes in my alliance with Hylebas: whereas now Balden having examined the ground of our quarrel, vow'd he would atisfy the jut reentments of his favorite by our utter ruine. I ecretly made Senira acquainted with the place of my retreate, and the ame moment wrot a letter to neria, by which I conjured her to bles me with her preence at an appointed place, within ten dayes time, that o my troubles might not be without ome allay of hope and conolation; and that from thence we would goe to Bactriand: But becaue I was to goe thorow a part of Baldens Territories to reach this place, I hrowded my elf in a diguize o trange, that I blinded all upition and dicovery. Being at the exact time mot properouly arrived I lighted on a peron whom he had charged to give me notice that he was repoing her elf in a place but very little ditant thence, where he had borrow'd the benefit of a friendly hade, till the exceive heat of the day were wated, and being big with impatience to reach thither, I hatned to hore and in my deires flew wiftly towards the place.

What think you now, Sybaris, of this meeting? doe you not preume I mut be very happy in it? yet ô gods, how are you mitaken? if you gues o, you wander in a mitake; and mis the truth, as much as I did my hopes; I was oon alighted indeed, and approached her with a becoming ceremony, and he advanced to receive me in her bleed arms; when the tranget accident imaginable,
natch'd her away, before I had the time to be let into her imbraces! a Troop of villains iuing out of a neighbouring wood, greedily ceazed on thoe were neeret to them: neria was the firt prey they lighted on, and her they hurried away before my eyes. Pardon me Sybaris, that I cannot keep in thee unruly ighes which interrupt my dicoure. The ad, yet weet remembrance of that fatal enterview does almot ting my oul by the remembrance of it now, as it did when it happened. The tranport I was in, wing'd me with hat and fury after thoe wilde ravihers, with my drawn word, but being then on foot, they galloped into the thicket of the wood, which oon heltred them from my longing eyes. I ran amazedly ometimes one way, then another, according as their doleful cries directed me, often hearing my dear ditreed neria implore and ummon her Merame for aitance. That voyce hatned my pace, but oon after, when the greater ditance had lot her to my Ear, as well as Eye, my breath and trength took flight after her, and left me to fall under my own weight: where I lay without motion, till the noie of ome hores which pas'd by, having rowz'd me, I perceived turning my head that way, that one of thoe fellows fled with a woman in his armes, whom I dicerned to be nerias Aunt: He paing back again neer the place, where I was uneen by him, I caught his hores bridle, and at the ame intant gave him o full a blow with my word, that he oon tumbled off with the woman, whom I was triving to convey away in the wood to helter
her from the ret: when they came ruhing o uddenly upon me, I was fain to leave her to provide for my own afety. I made all the reitance a deperate man could levy, but was at lat pres'd down under their numbers. I fell betwixt their hores feet o full of wounds, they thought that to take me up, was but to burthen themelves with a dead carkas: o they only took away nerias Aunt, whoe fear and amazement had kept her in a continual fainting. I remember the effuion of o much blood as I lot o enfeebled me, that the cryes and languihing lookes I endeavoured to end after them, were oon wrapt up in a deadly woon together with the ret of my ences. Some of nerias, company, who by a generous reitance had aved themelves out of their hands, entring the wood to eek more unhappines then they deired to find, lighted on me in a condition that promied but little hopes of life.
