How-ever, they bound up my wounds to tanch the treames of blood, and took me up to carry me to the Citty, and as they feared, to my grave at once. Whilt they were going, the agitation having a little reviv'd my pirits, I ent forth a igh, which faintly told them there was yet ome remainder of life dwelling in me, but no more, then to hew I was till dying. In this beleef, as oon as they entred the Citty, they took councel about my interment, and endeavour'd no longer to conceal whom I was. The Governor heard by their publick regrets that 'twas Merame they mourned for, and preently dipatch'd away a Meenger to advertize
Balden of it, who after the death of Zadarom had given orders to all the Frontire Garrions to ceaze me.

Amongt thoe whoe curioity had invited them to ee me, there hapned to come a very expert Chyrurgeon that had formerly been my Fathers houhold ervant: This man deired leave to earch my wounds, and not finding any of them mortal, judged that it was only the los of o much blood at once, had brought me to o feeble a condition; wherefore finding ome parks of life and warmth till in me, he aay'd to revive me by ome potent Cordials, which he employ'd unhappily for me, ince his conjecture had not deceived him. He felt my heart begin to beat a little, and ome mall dawning appearances in my face, which made him proceed to uch further applications as retored me once more to my ences. The firt apparent ign I gave them, was a languihing look, which I ent as my only readiet Meenger to eek for neria; and that was econded by my tongue which at its firt motion call'd upon her Name: but when I had gather'd a little more trength and found my elf in that condition amidt o many trangers, and began to remember how I had lot her. Oh gods, cry'd I, can I be yet alive, and he that is my oul be ravihed from me? Then turning my eyes on thoe were helping to dres my wounds, who deired me to be quiet, Friends aid I, you are more cruel than thoe Villains that hurt me, it was not without ome reaon they would have lain me, after they had deprived me of her for whom only I
lived; And you, whoe mercy has les pity than their cruelty, you would force me to live without her, who alone can make my life a • leing to me: Retore me my neria, or all your care is uperfluous, and what your Art can do is only to keep my unwilling oul for ome few moments in this ruinous body, which cannot long ubit being epar • ted from its better elf: do not make me languih therefore, if you truly love me, but uffer my pirit to quit this troubleome abode, and being uncaged take its flight, where only happines without diturbance can be enjoy'd for ever.

Notwithtanding all thee requets and moans, their care and remedy's brought me by oft degrees to trength again; When finding I mut live, I reolv'd to bend all my endeavours to a reearch of the lot neria: and was already conidering the way to et about it, when all my hopes were again natched from me. Hylebas had ome correpondants in this City, who gave him notice of my begun recovery; and that Traytor, whom I may jutly tile the plague of my life, did immediately renew the Governours Order to lay hold of me, who came himelf, and hew'd it me ign'd under Baldens own hand, excuing himelf that his office obliged him to execute this Commiion, contrary to thoe real deires he had to do me ervice.

As oon as they thought me healthy enough to undergo the fatigue of a journey, they conducted me with a Troop of Hore to Bacheher, where I was thrut into a Tower, in which they ordinarily kept their prioners of quality. My Father and
Mother with my nearet relations had once the liberty to come and viit me: Senira, who was now married to the Princes I formerly mentioned, could not obtain it, and what ever endeavours he made to procure my pardon, they could not bow the angry Balden to pitty; who notwithtanding had not declar'd how he would deal with me, but whoe concealed fury, hook my friends hearts with fear, having indeed ome more then ordinary reaon to fear that clap of thunder, which o long threatned to break forth againt me, yet kept its lightning till cover'd with a Cloud.

During the afflictions of my imprionment, ometimes the lively remembrance of my beautiful neria invaded my melancholly thoughts and gave them caue to make me rejoyce; but when from her bright face, I let fall my thoughts on her black detiny, turning the other ide of the leaf to read our misfortunes, my orrow well'd above the power of comforts to allay, and then my ighs and tears were too abundant to be expret in words. What hall I ay more, Sybaris, when as if there had yet wanted one weight of orrow more to ink me to the bottom of miery and dipair; One of thoe that were taken with her, having made his ecape came into this diconolate Prion, to tell me uch ad tydings as utterly extinguihed the leat glimpe of hope I had yet remaining in me. He aured me, that thoe Thieves had found neria o rarely handome, that they had conulted to make a glorious preent of her to their Prince, who had a Pallace
filled with beautiful laves, in which they were confined to atisfie his wanton pleaures, and that neria having undertood their • eign, conceiving o piercing a orrow, that it converted into an accute Feaver, which quickly caued her death, for whom the Scythians had o much eteem and veneration, that to expres their regrets for her los, they had erected a very tately Monument for her, which he had often een and lamented over.

The recital of this funet adventure, truck me into the deepet ilence poible for a long while: It ceaz'd upon my reaon too, and made me o much looe the helm of judgement, I was like to run and Shipwrack upon dipair: o that I ought for ome weapon, wherewith to put a period to that heap of mieries, which I could bear no longer on my tortur'd boome: But finding that means was deny'd me, I had recoure to my complaints: Ha! what aid I, does Balden withhold the execution of his vengeance only to make me linger in my mieries? Is his cruelty become o witty, to make me tate a thouand deaths for one? mut I yet live upon this wrack of torments, and not be allow'd the mercy of a udden death? Cruel and inexorable Butcher, you have now found out the way of full revenge indeed, by uffering me till to live in a condition that has more of horrour than many deaths could frighten me withal; and thou, blet oul, do not thou charge me with backwardnes and want of Love and courage; thou eet I earch out all the wayes I can to follow thy too haty flight: and ince I
am yet bound under the ad neceity of taying longer than my oul deires, comfort me with thy bleed pirit, that I may not be left thus till alone with thoe wild thoughts: and here again my griefs came flowing in o fat, they quite choakt up the paage of my peech: I was thus a long time mute, and that Gentleman taking at lat his farewell, left me rather in the poeion of my orrows than my reaon.

A few dayes after Senira ent a Gentleman to comfort me, whom I intreated to tell the Prince, that the only favour he could procure me, would be, not to follicite any longer for my pardon, but to joyn his purutes with thoe of my Enemies to haten my end; and that, as this was the lat, o it would be the greatet favour I could implore, and the mot welcome honour his mediation could confer upon o mierable a peron.

Contrary to the prayer of this Petition, that Generous Prince, fearing ome initer accident from this dipair, beg'd of his Father o earnetly, that he obtain'd permiion to give me a viit He found me in a poture which begot as much wonder as compaion in him. My Chamber was very obcure, having only the faint light of one little window which I had half vail'd over with a Curtain. I was thrown on my bed, my arms croing my breat, my eyes fixt upwards and o weather-beaten with the torms of tears that bubbled from thoe prings, and my viage o melancholly, wan and dicompoed from its natural dres, that he might well mitake me, as he did, and think his feet had led him unawares, into ome doleful
Cell, where only grief and mourning kept their diconolate Court; my thoughts had buried my mind in uch a deep ence of my Calamities, that I did not perceive when he entred into the Chamber, o that he came cloe to me without dicovery; and after he had gaz'd ome time upon me, I turn'd my head that way, and look'd upon him with an eye o full of trouble, that he believed it furious. Being firt amazed to behold me in o woful a condition, and perceiving me immoveable, his pitty made him firt alute, then call upon me, when finding I made no reply, he proceeded thus to rowze me by a gentle check, Is it thus Merame, you mean to receive and light the viit of Senira, and is it o importunate as to deerve this ilence and thee forbidding looks? thee words brought him to my knowledge, and triving to alute him, I hardly had the trength to hew it, by a little inclining of my head: which I follow'd with thee languihing accents, Noble Senira, the infinite orrows that overwhelm me, are the caue of my incivility: but what Ceremonies can you expect from a man equally in dipair of life and death, who during the violent agitation of this perpetual agony does neither live nor dye? a combat o much the more cruel, becaue it continues o long in one poor heart, and does not yet quite burt it. Gods! how merciles are your decrees againt me; why hould you thus delight to oppoe all my happines, and will not end death, after you have curt my life, and blated all my jut deigns, which how unhappily they have ucceeded you can judge: I drew neria
from my Mothers houe with the fond hopes of delivering her from a Captivity, which was more advantagious, then that liberty afterwards prov'd to be: If I jutly revenge her injuries on the detroyers of her worthy Family, and her own weet repoe, that becomes the ground work of all my misfortunes; when I imagine I am going to embrace her, and grape the highet felicity in my arms, I find it rudely natch'd away, and he hurry'd to her fatal end, whil't I am left the port to Detiny, and example of the greatet ufferings mortality ever tated of and lived under. Cruel thoughts, orrowful remembrance, which tings my very oul with bitternes, that I my elf hould be the ad caue of hers, and thereby my own utter ruine! had I not better have continued to love and adore her in ilence? But oh — Here the Prince interrupted me, and mildly aid, Ceae from becoming yet more guilty by your loud murmerings: you mut not blapheme againt o age a conduct as that of Heaven; Are the gods tyed to let fall properity on all our actions and purpoes? no, they more wiely do dipoe, of what we commonly propoe mot wildly to our elves: Nor hould we think our elves o harhly dealt with, did we but well conider, how lamely we go about mot, if not all our deigns, and how we werve from thoe trickt rules of Vertue precribed us to walk in, to attain our jut ends: Is it poible, Merame, that when you intended to fight with Zadarem, you hould not plainly foreee, my Fathers heat of paion and anger, ince you o oon fled from it? and who had enured neria's
afety in her journey to meet you? the attendance appointed to convey her, did not that hew what fears you had he might fall into thoe mifortunes, did afterwards unhappily light on her? Believe me, Merame, you do ill to complain o much for having reap'd thoe thorns your elf had planted: your miadventures cannot be unravel'd again, I mean thoe that are pat, do not kick at Heaven, but mildly ubmit to what Fate and your elf have cat upon you: 'tis better yeilding obedience to the gods, than call more anger down by a rebellious impatience. I, you know, made ome oppoition againt my detiny, but in vain, we mut bow down our tubborn wills at lat, therefore trive to content your elf with what Heaven does. The love, the Prince hew'd, in his affectionate and rational dicoure recalled my reaon back to her firt temper; I found, indeed, I gave my elf up to dipair unnobly, and with much weaknes; and before he parted I promis'd him to uck at every flower that could but promie the leat probability of yeilding any comfort to me. He, afterwards ent very often to viit me, and had obtained o much favour, that my chains of cloe retraint were drawn out to uch an extent of liberty, that I might now walk freely in a wide Park adjoyning to my Prion, where frequently my friends came to give me comfort, and helpt to wear out the tedious hours I pent in my confinement. One day, whilt it was yet very early, a Gentleman came to me from Senira, and told me, with a miling countenance, which gave me hopes of ome approaching
joy, that it was time to chear my elf, ince that black news of neria's death, was dipel'd by a mot certain news dicovery how he was till alive, to witnes which, he preented me a Letter deliver'd him the foregoing night. This udden tranport from a depth of orrow, to uch a height of joy, had almot made me looe my elf in wonder: and, not minding or caring, indeed, how, or by whom this Paper Embay was come to hand, I kis'd it many times firt, and then tore it through impatience to read its Contents. I yet keep that precious pawn of her affection, which, I may ay, was igned with her blood. But ince I cannot behold or read it without a prologue of tears, oblige me o far Sybaris, as to eae me of that orrow by reading it your elf. Sybaris, having unfolded it, found thee words,
UNERIA to MERAME.
The opinion I am poet with of your death, may be as fale, as that which I apprehend you have of mine. I live yet Merame, thanks to Heaven, but 'tis only to dye within four dayes: which are the remainder of as many more were given me to reolve either to forfeit my life or honour; of which time I have wated this one half only in eeking an opportunity to give you notice of it. I now expect the hour patiently which hall make me triumph both over your enemies and mine! And if you would not have me regret my death, ince 'tis for yours and Vertues ake I fall, comfort your elf, Merame, I conjure you by this lat and highet tetimony of my Love, and live for her ake, who thus reolutely reolves to
dye for you, as being unalterably either in life or death,

Gods! Cry'd Sybaris, how has this Letter deluded me! I expected a quite contrary ucces, and had no place to doubt, but it would have etabliht your happines mot firmly. Indeed, purued Merame, the affliction this Letter brought with it, was by o much the more enible, as it was unexpected, it cruh'd down all my young pringing hopes, and the weak props my reaumed confidence had borrow'd, and o infinitely oppreed my heart, it never could have rien from under the weight, if Senira, having ucceeded his Father, had not quite knock'd off my fetters of retraint, and ued all the noble endeavours poible to perwade me, not to throw away my life o cheaply, but try to carve out a brave revenge for my neria. To this purpoe he made up a reconciliation betwixt Hylebas and me, whom he afterwards commanded to quit the Court, and doing me the honour to admit me to the ame degree of favour, as my Antagonit had enjoy'd under Balden, he committed the dipoal of all offices to my Father, whom he elected for the General of his Army.

Mean time, the Scythians, who hoped for ome advantage in this grand mutation, broke out into an abolute War, which their daily pilferings and mall incurions on either ide had long threatned. Senira, finding the army his Father had levy'd,
in a condition to march, commended my Father to prevent the Enemies hat, on whoe Frontiers he appeared before they could have leaure to imagine it: I was impatient till we came to blowes, and as oon as we had newes of them by our couts, I went out with a party to dicover, or rather to attaque them. That firt enterprize ucceeding happily, for thoe I engaged were all either cut off, or taken prioners; there was not any one of thoe whom I had ubdued, of whom I enquired not particularly concerning neria; who, I told them was that fair Captive in Margiana, they had put to death a few days ince. One only of them all, told me omewhat, he affirmed that their Prince and his on had both been mot paionately in Love with her, but that the Father prompted by his jealouie had caued her to dye, to roote up the ons hopes of injoyment. Since himelf could not allure her to his own deires, her noble vertue having bravely repuled the hottet of his lutfull onets.

The report and the love I had to neria, together with the hate againt her enemies & my reentment reulting from both, made me perform uch acts, as without their impule, I hould never have undertaken; but thoe coniderations did o animate me, that in that dreadful Battle we gained, though o dearly, that the victory was written in Characters of our own blood and innumerable wounds, I had engaged my elf o far, in the greatet hock of it, amongt the Enemies
hore, that being unable to cut my way back again, the numerous herd flying to ave themelves hurried me away in the throng with them. The richnes of my armes and habit hew'd me to be of a condition which promis'd them a fair ranome, which made them treate me civily enough, and ecure me in a Catle very trongly guarded, which faced the Capian ea.

My imprionment was not o clos, but I had ometimes the liberty to breath the freh ayr in a large encloed pature, at the other end whereof there tood another Catle, where I was told they kept thoe fair Captives, choen, for their more then ordinary beauty, to atisfy their Princes lut; which awakened my thoughts and memory of my lot neria, whoe cruel prion I fancied it to have been, and cating up my Eye with great attention towards the windows which were ecur'd with Iron grates, my mind repreented that fair Planet to me with all its luter and beauty: whilt I was feeding my elf one day with thee ad contemplations, I heard a feeble voyce knock at my Ear, which as I thought call'd me by my name, this made me hatily gaze upwards, from whence I perceived a note falling down rowled upon a little tick, which I oon natched up and reading found it was nerias fair hand which thus expres'd it elf.

body.head: To MERAME.
body.p:
The Heavens, in fine, Merame, are I hope weary of
perecuting mee; after all my afflictions, they eem to promie pitty, I have found within the walls of this Prion, an officer that proffers me my liberty, and expects no other recompene, but what reults from the act it elf; your interets are o dear to me, and I have evinc'd they are o ineparably tyed to mine, that he hath engag'd (to make his obligation the more complent) to et you free, the ame day with me Meet therefore at the place he hall appoint you anon by a econd note that hall be thrown down to you. Adieu

div.p:
Gues, Sybaris, for I cannot cloathe that joy in words, which then fill'd my heart, knowing neria to be yet alive, and who to tetify the true love he till cherihed for me, endeavour'd to retore me to that liberty, which I had made her looe, when I thought to have procured it for her elf and me. Notwithtanding amidt this hope, and freh aurances of her faith, I reented ome little grudgings of jealouie and ditrut againt him that thus undertook her freedome: and this ecret upition would have tifled all my joy, if the over eager deire of eeing her, had not quite thrut it out of my mind. I thought no more on any thing but thoe happy meanes and moments which were to guide me to my nerias preence, and during this impatient longing, I watched under the window expecting the paper that was to give me directions, which was oon after hurld down. By reading it I undertood, that about midnight a Man would come and conduct me down a pair of private tayrs, which led to the ea ide, where I hould find a mall
boat waiting for mee, all this was punctually performed, at the houre aign'd one came and guided me thither, and no ooner was I imbarqued but the Marriners tretched away amain, making the bet ue of their Oars and Sails all night, to be by break of day at the place where I hould land, which was cloe by a Fihermans mall cottage, where they inform'd me I mut goe to find ome certain perons who were waiting there for me. Having et me on hoare, they made away from the place with great peed, and I with as much precipitancy, hated to the Cabbin to find my dear neria; whom I oon aw indeed, but in what condition doe you think Syba • is? alas! that mot beautiful creature lay extended at her full length upon the gras, weltring in her own precious blood, which guhed from her left bret! The horror of o gatly a pectacle hot, uch atonihment into my oul, that I remained a long time as motionles as he, with my melting eyes fatned upon her wound! and my hard Fate denying me the mercy of a udden death, made me endure the agony of many: yet was I ummoned by an hollow igh to look up; and approach neerer to her with a tottering pace; when finding no viible ign of life remaining in her, why my neria have you brought me hither, cry'd I, to be o ad an eye-witnes of your untimely and violent death? Could you believe I hould prefer it before your clos captivity? or if you deign'd that I hould follow your example, why would you not tay my coming? what has occaion'd uch a udden change, was
your neceity o urgent you could not hun it one moment longer? ah heavens, why mut I behold this funet object, were it not better to have left me till in the uncertain but more happy opinion of her former death, then thus to blat my ences by the horrid fight? But my eyes, what is't you ee? where are thoe blooming roes, and fairer Lillies which created o excellent a beauty in her Face? Where are thoe living tarrs, whoe luter was les offenive, but more glorious then the Suns, and kindled kinder he • ts in my poor boome? Can this be fair neria, and all thee beauties wither'd? yes, 'tis neria, but death has cropt thoe curious flowers, and cat a cloud over thoe brightet tars! Weepe therefore, weepe, till you are blind, as he for this ad funeral of all your happines! The violence of my grief cut of all further complaints, and unk me down upon my knees beide her: where oftly kiing, ometimes her cold cheekes, then her colder lipps, and bowing my head down in a dejected manner ighing and hedding floods of tears, I gently took up one of her white hands, which he had lockt together, and perceived a Dagger in it, and a peece of linnen in the other, which he had torne off from her neck, upon which thee words were charactred in blood, To keepe my elf intirely thine, I mut dye Merame. Ha! well aid I, ince only I am guilty of thy death it is but jut I hould be punihed: and I am willing to expiate the crime by offring my own heart thy acrifice: but would to heaven, you rather
had hated me, than given uch woful tetimonies of it! I hould have no regret in dying for you, were it not after you are dead for me, which is o tinging a conideration, I doubt it will not leave me quiet in my grave. Too, too dear pledge of her immortal love, purued I, kiing the Sacred relique; whereon her blood had left ome bluhings for my demerits; Receive the impreions of mine alo, which I reolve to ingrave. And then taking up the dagger, thou fatal intrument of our dicourteous detiny, bathe thy elf in my blood, to wah that in off thou hat contracted by letting out of hers. Then having again kis'd my neria's pale lips and reeking wound, and noted where abouts it was made, I tabed my elf as near my own heart, as that was to hers, and with the firt drops wrote thus upon the ame linnen, Merame dyes for Uneria who is dead for him. 'Tis trange, me thought that blow gave me the greatet eae I ever felt, by disbanding that dipair and load of grief that o oppreed me: and feeling my trength decay apace, I laid my elf down cloe by her, on the ame bed of earth, embracing her as trictly as I could, reolving to be united to her at death.

All my ences were now taking their lat farewell and flight together. When he preed that hand wherewith I held her fat; I trugled to raie my elf again, and willingly would have thrut death from me, ince neria yet lived, to have aited her: but the los of o much blood as guhed from my deep wound, caued me to faint, o that I was wholly deprived of all entiment.
Whilt I was in this trance, the owner of the little Cottage, a good antient man, hapning to come by, was moved with compaion, and ued his bet means to recover me again: by his care and helpful charity I came at length to my ences again, and as oon as I was Mater of o much trength and reaon as would guide my tongue, I enquired for neria, whom he told me was conveyed away by certain trangers he never had before beheld, he being much amazed at his return from his fihing to ee a horeman bear away a woman from thence, and to find me on the cold earth wiming in blood.

I confes I had much ado to refrain quarreling with the old man, for uffering any to ravih her away. The uncertainty, balancing my mind betwixt hope and fear, whether it were a friend or enemy had taken her thence, trugled o long with my dipair which olicited for death, that it, in fine, made me deire to live till I could know the certainty: conidering it would be time enough to take that Sanctuary, when I was ure he was utterly lot, who had been as miraculouly as often preerved above all expectation.

To this purpoe, I conjured the good man to tranport me to ome uch concealed place as might ecure me; who was o enibly touched with the relation I made him of ome feigned diaters had befaln me, that he oon conented to put me in a place of afety, before any one could have the time to be informed of my flight. So he, accordingly, conveyed me to a little petty Iland, where he had found within the hollow womb of
a Rock, a place large enough to lodge in conveniently, when he minded not to return to his other habitation. His Wife was there at that time with a child or two, who received me with the ame kindnes as he had brought me; and they there took uch pains and care to advance my recovery, that within fifteen dayes, I had acquired a great deal of trength. In the interim, this honet fellow brought me intelligence, that certain perons, had made inquiry for me at his Cabin, asking him whether he could give them any notice of a man whom they decribed much of my reemblance: but they not mentioning either the Lady, or the misfortunes I had related, he thought it might be ome other. However he was reolved and did keep me hid, till thinking it convenient to remove, I got him to conduct me to the chops of the River Oxus, not far thence, where being afely landed, I went directly to Sina in the Province of Derbices, the Governour whereof was one of my mot intimate friends. I went afterwards to wait on and pay my duty to my Father, who being at Court, I had the opportunity to attend Senira at the ame time; who having formerly lot his firt Wife in Child-bed, was then preparing (after he had worn out a competent time in mourning) to be at lat married to his dearet Themira. Senira, made me a thouand expreions of welcome by his carees, and openly declared his more then common joy for my return: He had the goodnes and patience to hear the ad relation of my misfortunes, at which he truly grieved, and gave me encouragement to
eek again for that lot treaure, of whom they had heard no more in thoe parts than what I told them.

I made a careful reearch all over Margiana, and Bactriana, but in vain; w • en hearing that one of her relations was in Labynetus Army, I purpoed to find him out, hoping I might from him meet with that intelligence which I had o unprofitably ought till then. I fortuned to reach the Camp, jut when the two Armies were ready to give Battle, and being wholly guided by neria's interet, who had one of her kindred in that party, I thrut my elf amongt the Voluntiers, and was made a Prioner by the Hir • anians, but mot happily for me, ince by my Captivity I have obtained this honour of convering with the brave Sybaris.

text.p: Morame having drawn all the black lines of his ad hitory to this concluion; Sybaris expreed how much the ad Epilogue touched his generous oul with compaion: and having ratifi'd their former protetations of friendhip with many new and hearty oaths, the eals of an inviolable amity; Sybaris returned to his apartment, charging his people to attend Merame with the mot diligent ervice, who uddenly betook him to his bed, the fittet place of privacy and retirement to entertain his thoughts with thoe images of orrow, which his o late relation had brought more frehly into his mind, as to the many divers accidents that had betided both him and his dear neria in their amours.

The next day Sybaris imparted ome of thee
diaters to Cyrus, whom from the beginning had cherihed his Prioner with a particular eteem: and whilt this entertainment yet continued, Merame came to alute him, as he did alo the Armenian Prince with Artabaus, Chryante, and all tho • e perons of Quality, who were at that time met in the Generals Tent to wait upon him.

Thee illutrious friends had carce put an end to the Ceremonies this new acquaintance claimed, when ome advertiz'd Cyrus that a Meenger jut then arrived from Media deired to peak with him. He commanded them to admit him, and finding it was Abracome, he led him into a little Cloet apart, to have the greater liberty of dicoure with him. This truty confident of his affections, whom he had left in Ecbatane to have the more punctual information of his Princes, feigned at firt that he came not from her, but to acquaint him how his Uncle Cyaxares being paionately enamoured with her, had convey'd her to his trong Palace at Julier, where he was o trictly guarded, it was hardly feaible either to peak with her or ee her. But perceiving how much diquiet this novel brought with it, by the many little quetions and diordered exclamations he made, he calmed him again, for the time, with a letter he preented which he had contrived to end him by means of an Eunuch, whom he engaged by Oath not to deliver to him till he hould find him readily dipoed to erve her.

Cyrus how ever eminently couragious and victorious, could not receive this Embay without a kind of trembling; and having ript it open, his
eager impatience made his eyes lip ever all the firt part unread to ee whether it were really igned by Birinthea, who wrote thus to him.

body.p: your generoity which otherwhile made you preerve my Fathers life at my requet, gives me jut hopes to believe you will not deny that ame protection to recue my own which, I am now in hazard of forfeiting, ince your nole Cyaxares deires that of me, which he hall never obtain; though I Prognoticate from his wild humour, that finding his perwaions and cajoleries vain, he will make force and violence become the Miniters of his paions, whence you may gues in what an extremity of danger I am I do not acquaint my brother Tygranes with it, becaue you only ought to free me from this Tyranny, ince it was you alone that delivered me into his hands, and you only are conjured to ait ditreed,

text.p:
He repeated the Lecture of this Meage three or four times, as though he had not rightly comprehended its Contents, but what might eem his difficulty was indeed only his exces of love for her, and wonder at his Uncle, and then aid, with a oft voyce: 'Tis true, I put you into Cyaxares hands, but, cry'd he, I hall have no les power and reaon to fetch you out again; do not doubt of it, my Princes, you need not only hope, but fully promie your fair elf any thing you can deire of me, which though I am bound too by the immortal obligation of jutice and my devoiur,
yet I hall undertake it with more affection than they can prompt me to, being heated by your nobler commands.

He aid no more, but mothering the truglings of his paion, and not willing to fret away the time with empty words, he called for Sybaris to whom he imparted the buines. That choice friend intantly profer'd to go and et her at freedome, but Cyrus could not uffer any other hand hould render her that ignal ervice, which love and repect olicited him to act peronally. He was a long while in upence weighing his reolutions, for the greatet concerns of his Princes, and his affection called him into Media, but his fame and honour bid him not quit the Army o oon: in fine floating upon thee waves and different tydes of irreolution, an expres came, which being from his Uncle Cyaxares, did for a while interrupt his former thoughts.

Cyaxares the night that Cyrus parted from him, amuing himelf with mot of his Nobility in a grand debauch of Wine, had not yet taken any particular notice of the great number of Lords who had abented themelves to follow Cyrus in his more generous employments, but the next day, miing that numerous throng of Courtiers who alwayes attended at his riing, and undertanding they had left him, to accompany Cyrus, he was tung with that poor envy, for this young Conquerours vertue, which uually ceazes on thoe, who cannot revere that in others, which they are uncapable of themelves.

This knawing jealouie had uggeted the enuing
Letter, which he addreed both to him and the Medes, as follows.

body.head: Cyaxares to Cyrus and to the Medes.
body.p: I had thought, Cyrus, you were too well acquainted with the repect you owe me, to entice away the chiefet of my Court: And you Medes my Subjects, that you would never have been o perfidious as to forake me to follow him. If my Nepveu, according to my advice, do return hither, return alo with him; But if he perevere in his obtinacy to purue the Ayrians, and you deire not to incurr my highet dipleaure, quit him and be at oonet with me.

text.p:
Cyrus having by this Letter encreaed the upition he had conceived of Cyxares his ill will towards him, reolved, however to communicate it to the Medes and Perians, and having ummoned them together, he read it aloud to them. After which the Medes wavering a while in a upence, whether they hould return back to their King, or adhere to their General, conidering the glory they had acquired under the properous ucces of the one, and the duty incumbent upon them towards the other; caued Cyrus to peak, who gave free leave to uch as urged it to go, but intreated the more indifferent to wave their reolutions till he had given a full anwer to his Uncles Letter. Till which time he detained the Envoy that came from him, to be a Witnes he acted
nothing againt his Uncles interet, or his own devoir.
Which propoition having their general approbation, Cyrus wrote his letter, which he afterwards let them ee in thee expreions.

body.head: Cyrus to Cyaxares, King of Media.
body.p:
Your Majety will, I hope excue me, if I tell you, that it was never the intention of the Medes, or my elf to forake you: ince, thanks to the gods, having left you triumphant at home by the victory over the Ayrians, you enjoy at preent the properity of a Fortune, which can never leave you detitute of Friends, o long as it lats. And if to give them chae, we have been contrained to eparate our elves a while from your Majety, and that be the only caue of your dipleaure; we deire you to conider that this hould rather tand as an argument to evince our fidelity, greater then theirs who yet remain in your Court; ince we endeavour to drive thus far the Enemy from you, that we may keep all dangers at the bigget ditance we can poibly from interrupting your repoe and Peace. But not to relye on thee coniderations ingly; I beeech you to call to your remembrance in what degree I have the honour to belong to you, and, thereby you may eaily judge me uncapable of ingratitude, or elf deigns to your prejudice; Or if you can vouchafe to credit the tetimonies I have already given of my willingnes to erve you, you cannot with any ground entertaine the
leat upition, that I am wanting in that repect and faith, my birth and quality binds me in towards your Majety.

What reaon then, good gods, can your Majety have to command your Subjects away from me now, ince you exprely commanded ome, and gave your gracious permiion to others freely, to follow me, whilt I was preent, and had brought a puiant Army out of Peria into your dominions without any other hotage or ecurity, then the requet you made of my Father? Nay, be pleaed to give me leave to ay further that hould I treate you, as you doe me, I mut then beg, you would retore to me thoe Palmes of victory remaining in your hands, which the valour of my compagnions lately reaped, and which I bound up in wreathes and garlands, and preented you withall: But to evidence the incerity of my deigns, I am deirous you would be pleaed to take notice, and give me leave to make ome new levies in Peria, which I beeech you to dipoe of abolutely, according to the order I have left with my Lieutenant to tender you all the obedience and ubmiion your Majety can deire.

Withall, I intreate your Majety, not to take it ill, that I preume to give you this humble advices, not to revoke thoe favours you have already granted, becaue thereby you would make more Enemies than friends, or obedient ervants; and if, by your menaces and commands to returne, you would affrighten uch as are here, with the apprehenion of your dipleaure, it will not be proper to let them know, you are left with o thin a train, ince the knowledge that mut give them of your weaknes, might make them careles of obeying
you? 'Tis not that I deire to retain thee Medians that are willing to returne, I have granted them all their full liberty; but as for my elf, I conjure you before I return, to allow me only o much time, as will be mot neceary to compleat that conquet, which we have o happily begun, and from which you may expect as much advantage and increae of Dominion and Glory, as is wihed by

text.p: Diapherne had Commiion to haten to Media with this anwer, and Sybaris undertook to make the levies in Peria; and withall to procure Birintheas releae; they parted together with Abracome, whoe orders were as cloely covered, as the caue of his comming had been hid from them.

Not one of the Medes would return with them, and Cyrus, the more to chain them to him, becaue they made up the bet part of his Cavalry: ditributed the richet of the poil, which had been taken from the Enemy, amongt them; leaving the care to themelves to reerve that which they thought fitting for their King. The Hircanians, Armenians, and the meenger whom Cyax ares had ent, did partake with them likewie: Only the Perians took what the others lighted, for being accutomed to hard uage and frugality, made no account of uch trifles as
only contribute to vanity and outward parade, but are not abolutely neceary to uch as quare their lives according to the everity of that dicipline they had lived under in their renown'd Accademies.
text.trailer: The End of the Firt Book.

div.head: Birinthea The Second Book.
div.p: WHilt they were yet haring the booty, the vigilant entinels dicover'd a great body of hore that advanced directly towards them. They were already going to alarm the whole Camp, when three or foure cavaliers leaving the gros behind them, hatned to aure them, that their troops deired rather peace then war.

The Prince that commanded them, was a venerable ancient gentleman called Gobrias, who cauing his man to make a halt, advanced, only with a mall party to attend him, demanding to peake with their General; the Majety of his countenance imprinted repect in all thoe that
beheld him, an eminent officer having received him, conducted him to Cyrus Tent, at whoe feet he preently cat himelf down, but being intantly raied, and imbraced with a more then ordinary civility, he began to expres himelf in this manner.

I would not, Sir, that you hould beleeve I preent a traytor, or perfidious man before you, if my revault were an act of baenes, I hould not dare to cat my elf into the armes of the mot generous Prince in the world, but the Subject of it having the appendages of jutice and honor to warrant it legal, I hope when you are made acquainted with the reaons of my deerting the Ayrians party to embrace yours, that I hall find a noble reception from your infinite goodnes. Cyrus having intimated how glad he hould be to know the occaion that urged him to come in uch a manner, Gobrias went on thus.

I am an Ayrian by extraction, the eldet of one of the mot illutrious and puiant families, from whom their Princes are decended, I have the Soveraign command of the Province of the Garameens, where I have many places of great trength and plentifully tored. I came from thence with a party of thirteen hundred hore to find out Labynetus King of the Ayrians, who was lain in the firt battle they fought againt you. I was one of the mot intimate friends, and had erv'd him divers times in his armies in quality of General, with o much happines as to merit my favours from his noble acknowledgement, amongt all which, the mot advantageous was the
deire he had to allie me to his family. He hat one only on, and a daughter, and I was bled with a like paire: So that to make our kindred firme by an indioluble knot, he ordain'd his on ectorez, the ame that does now ucceed in his Empire, to epoue my daughter, and mine reciprocally his Melzune. So was my deare on named, to render his jut aiduities to the Princes, was alwayes at the Court, where I was likewie obliged to reide to accompany my daughter, whom the Prince entertained every day, being intirely affected and inamour'd with her.

The time was neere at hand to celebrate thoe nuptialls, and all things preparing for o illutrious a ceremony, the Court expecting the conummation of it with much impatience when a trange accident uddenly ruffled this calme of promiing joyes into a torme of unhappines, which then wallow'd up my dearet on, and ever ince all my content and felicity. The whole Court being pres'd with a general gladnes, the two young amorous Princes appointed to take the divertiement of the chace; the firt beat they rouz'd out of a little wood was a bear at which ectorez cat a javellin that mis'd, and my on by an unfortunate addres couching it dead at their feete, every one tarting into acclamations for that ucces, the Prince was netled with dipleaure, as if my on had given an affront, yet making the chace continue to redeem that credit, he lanc'd a econd javelling at a lyon, which preented it elf, but with the ame
fortune as the firt, and my on purr'd with as generous emulation having given this it's death wound alo; ectorez coud no longer bridle the initer effects of his rage, thinking thoe praies, the company betow'd upon my on, reproach'd his want of skill, and being inflam'd with this jealouy, natching a lance from one that was next to him, he furiouly truck it quite through the body of my on, who was the dearer to me, becaue an only on, and whom in a few dayes I hop'd to ee in the bleed armes of his faire Princes, whoe daring valor and Heroick pirit promis'd no les then Crown's and Scepters to my family by this alliance; and who in fine was the only conolation of my life:

But, Sir, the rage of this degenerate Prince, was not yet glutted, though he aw him weltring in the treames of his own blood, he would not uffer them to carry him to the City, fearing leat, his wound not being o mortall, as his own cured hate there might be a poibility of his recovery: and therefore to prevent all my endeavours, and deprive me of the ad conolation to behold him once again, he caus'd him to be cat into the river Tigris.

The King his Father, immediately after he had learnt this woeful accident, came to me peronally to tetify the reentment he had of my jut griefe, complaining with much tendernes, of thoe coniderations which hindred him from punihing the Author, and eriouly proteted that if he had but any other on to inherit his Crown, he would have made him the object of
exemplary jutice by acrificing him to my revenge. The Kings compaion, and the real orrow he had for my affliction, moothered that hatred which I hould otherwie have kindled againt that abominable aains Father: But I remain'd his friend contantly till his late death canceld that obligation and was now going to ait him with my bet indeavours againt you: but having been inform'd how that unhappy King was lain in the firt ight; I am come (generous Prince) to cat my elf at your feet, imploring the honour of your protection againt the tyrant that ucceeded him, who is o far from any ence of pitty, or repentance that in tead of denying his reaon, to have conented with his rage to perpetrate that horrid act, be triumphs in his cruelty, with as much glo • y as if he had bravely defeated the tallet of his Enemies. Judge therefore, S • r, if my intentions be not faire and equitable, and whether I can doe les without reproach of tamenes, and traying from the path of nature, and affection, then eek a retaliation for his blood. 'Tis from your valour that I expect my vengeance, I hall remit it to your own dicretion to dipoe wholy of my interets and life, with all that does concerne me

Cyrus interrupting his dicoure, aur'd him of that aitance he expected, with much civility and cheerfulnes, and Gobrias reuming his peech, continuing thus: But, Sir, that you may have no caue to doubt the verities of what I proffer you, two dayes journey will bring you into Garamee
where you hall take full poeion of all the Towns and fortrees at your own pleaure. My daughter the generous iter of Melzune, who was detined to be that Tyrants wife, will gladly receive you, whoe pungent orrow will challenge no les pitty then my own. I bred her, as I have already aid, to be the Ayrian Queen, but though I had pointed out ectorez to be formerly the object of her love, he now coniders, him only as the Subject of her deepet hate, and and whatever that Traytor has projected to appeae her indignation, yet he had o much pirit in her, as to tell him one day aloud, before his Father, Sabinetus that he more then admir'd he had the confidence to hope for any affection, or repect from one whoe brother he had baely butcher'd, that the mourning vail he wore was an evident tetimony of his blacker crime, and that as he could never hew too much regret, by her continual griefe, for what he had lot, o conequently he could never manifet too great a hatred againt him that had o ignobly ravih'd it from her, and further he would never uffer that man, though a King, to be her husband that was her brothers aain, but he hould rather expect the udden effects of the everet revenge her mortal hate, and anger could levy againt him, then the leat inclination from her extinguih'd love.

If fine, to hun the importunate puruites of that unworthy Prince, he banih'd her elf voluntarily from the Court, and returned with one of my iters into Garamee, that
he might be no more oblig'd to have that detetable object in her ight. I prais'd that contant reolution of my daughter, which econded my own reentments, and by the firmnes of her indignation perceived he did inherit the vertues of her noble ancetors; but I was utterly ignorant (and never hould have given way to it; though my revenge clamor'd my oul to wih it) that he had conpired againt ectorez life. She had given a private commiion for this enterprie to a Prince called Emuin, who long before had been my daughter willing prioner. This unhappy lover, who during ectorez faire correpondency had been contrain'd to keep his paions under ahes for the repect, & diffidence of uch a puiant rivall, was ravih'd to find an occaion whereby to rid him thence in erving her, hoping by this attempt, to cut his way to his own blis, this being the only tall cedar that hindred the full propect of his happines, he having told him that the performance of this important ervice hould give him a jut claime to her affection. In fine this jut murther was undertaken, but by misfortune not executed, the number of thoe that attended ectorez hindring the fatal blow of vengeance. Emuin was taken in the attempt, who was mater of o much contancy and reolution amidt the tortures of the inquiitors, and imprionment, that he never reveal'd my daughter to have had the leat hand in it. None could imagine that love and hatred had combin'd in this enterprie, nor would he declare upon any interrogation, for what caue he was mov'd to take away the Princes life, and intead
of imploying his friends, who were very potent, to ue his pardon, he perited to declare, that he deired not to live but to performe that by a econd attempt which he had o unhappily mis'd in the firt, it being a deign too jut to be thrown by. If any other but a Prince had appeared in it, I might perhaps have fallen under their upition of being confederate, but it was above conjecture to imagine that a peron of his condition would be but anothers intrument, and therefore he alone was adjudged guilty

He was condemn'd to pay down his head for the price of this treaon, and becaue this peece of jutice was to be exemplary, the execution was defer'd till the Kings returne, who was at that time within a dayes journey of Ninus, that the whole Court might be aitant. My daughter in the interim was made acquainted with the entence pronounced againt him, and feigning as if he were to goe a hunting, as he frequently did, being well mounted, he went directly towards Ninus, where he arriv'd (jut the evening before the fatal day, which Emuin reck'ned as the lat in his unhappy Calender disguis'd under the hrowd of uch a habit, as was not uuall to her ex.

The day following all the Court being aembled, with the herds of common people, the King and his on being there preent with their extraordinary guard of oldiers, they drew the mierable Emuin forth of the prion, to end his life and mieries at one blow, but whilt every one had their eyes fixt on him, decanting diverly
on his misfortune, they were uddenly taken off to behold a freh object which preented it elf in that black Scene, it being a peron vail'd all over, making way through the croud with two Trumpeters marching before.

It was the cutome, of a long tanding, amongt the Ayrians, that if any one could reveal omewhat, which might aggravate the offenders crime, or could fully clear and dicharge them, they were to come thus diguied, to preent their information. According to this order the Judges intantly upended the execution to know what this might be, they carried the written information to the King, who was amaz'd that the peron which brought it, accus'd himelf as the ole author of the attempt, and fully dicharged Emuin, as having only undertaken the performance of it, out of a blinde obedience to that perons command.

Many had formerly been known to bring in aggravations, but hardly ever any preented themelves o voluntarily to certain death. In this general conternation, they caus'd the unknown peron to approach near the King, who was no ooner within reach, but before he gave o much time as to examine a word, natch'd off the vail which concealed the admired peron None could at the firt intant dicover who it was, and truly it were difficult not to be extreamly urpriz'd with uch an unlook'd for object as a Lady o generouly out-braving death it elf. 'Tis my Daughter Azimea, who as I aid before under colour of hunting tole away from me, with a full
reolution to ave that Prince, and who with an incomparable courage addres'd her looks and words thus to Vectorez.

Thou wouldet pretend, infamous man, not to know me becaue of this diguie, thou find't, my preence like thy own concience the Monitor to reproach thy bloody cruelties, and an authentick Witnes of the jutice of my enterprize to take away thy life, which is o clear an evidence that I would almot think Heavens jutice lept when I mis'd of my hopes in punihing thee, for a retaliation of my dearet Brothers life. Ah degenerate man, do not turn back thy ight, maintain that bloody action, thou hadt then impudence to commit, thou tremblet, Traytor, to ee her in thy preence from whom thou didt expect the oftet carees, avouch he is thy deadly enemy, and wih he could have buried a dagger in thy heart: but, tell me, what wonder dot thou find in this change, hat not thou oblig'd me to it, can I manifet les revenge, and hate againt my Brothers aain, and be a Princes till? Tell me what crime there is in this attempt? or rather what jutice does not authorize it? can les than thy ignoble life atisfie for that worthy oul? or dot thou think me o tame and cool to pas by uch an injury, and not reent it. If I be guilty 'tis only for my want of due revenge, and leaving it to be committed by a hand that was too weak, when I hould rather have undertaken it my elf, which Heaven, without doubt, would not have diappointed o unhappily: but thou dot make no anwer, and thy penive ilence gives a trong
aent to thee indictments, and are alone ufficient to make good the jutice of my intentions againt thy guilty peron.

Thee publick reproaches dy'd with uch harp and vehement language, did o atonih the Prince and gall his oul, that he had not the power to anwer her one Syllable, whom he yet dearly lov'd; but the King his Father perceiving his confuion, tood up and poke, to take her off from tretching her bitter reproofs out further againt that horrid crime o openly. He ent forth Emuin to confront her, who confirm'd the whole information, and all that he had poken, after which he was return'd to the Prion again, and Azimea was carried to the Palace, where he was trongly guarded till my arrival.

Labynetus, as I told you before, affected me extreamly, and ent for me, whilt I was in the greatet fears in the world for my abent daughter, to come to Court and hear news of her; According to this meage I hated with the mot diligent peed, and having preented my elf full of perplexity before him, he ent for Vectorez and Azimea, and related, in the preence of his choicet Nobility, all that had befallen; and told me, that notwithtanding all the reaons of State and interet of his Crown, he found it equitable to pardon my Daughters attempt, ince he had been oblig'd to leave his own Son unpunih'd; and that his regret was the more enible, becaue his Succeor by this unhappy accident, was expos'd to the jut hatred of our generous family: but as a atisfaction of my Sons los, he now retor'd my
Daughter, pretending by that means to bury our quarrel in oblivion.

I accepted the Kings mercy to Azimea with all the tetimonies of acknowledgement my duty bound me to, without relinquihing the hate I had conceiv'd againt his Son. I had forgot to tell you, that his Daughter was preent at this enter-view, who being no les paionate of my Sons memory, than he had formerly been of his Peron, upheld the interet of my Family toutly, and confes'd openly that if Vectorez had not been o near of blood to her, he would not have been o bravely prevented in the deign of revenge.

During the little abode I made at Court, my Daughter in her agreement making a uperficial reconciliation with the Prince, obtain'd his rivals pardon, whom they were content to banih, and withall made the Prince renounce his pretence of Marriage with her, by an abolute refual of that proffer'd love he often made, which poes'd him with as much violence as ever.

Our affairs being thus handomly compoed, I return'd to Garamee, where I was no ooner arriv'd, but Labynetus ent an expres, for me to go and joyn my troops with his, to carry on the War commenc'd againt Cyaxares. I was already on my way to this purpoe, when I receiv'd tydings of his death, which made me change my reolutions, and turn my coure towards you, to whom I fly for Protection againt that bloody Tyrant whoe cruelty, not fully gorg'd with my Son's innocent blood, has often made him profes, that if he ever came to be Soveraign, he would
by force contrain us to repentance, and make my Daughter flexible to the lat of his deires.

Gorgias having thus wound up the everal threds of his dicoure, Cyrus again repeated his embraces, and the promies he had made for his revenge, proteting he hould find in him the readiet peron in the world to econd his reentments and his Daughters extraordinary generoity.
This converion was not broken off, till the Medes came in a joynt body, to preent him with what they thought he would eteem the richet of their purchae lately taken.

It was a woman of Suiana, whoe miraculous beauty darted atonihment and dangerous wonder into every eye that gaz'd upon her, he appear'd ad indeed, but yet that adnes was mix'd with o much conquering Majety, that it was eaie to be read how little power the unhappines of her Captivity had gain'd upon her pirit, Cyrus himelf, who had no eyes but for the bleed object he ador'd, could not refue them uch a grateful ight, he tood till a while wrapt with the admiration of her peron, and after he had receiv'd her with all thoe high expreions of civility her condition eem'd to claim, he undertood he was the Wife of Abradate Prince of Suiana, whom the Ayrian King, had ent to the King of Bactria to make a confederation of their Armies. The knowledge of her condition put him into the ame terms of repect towards her, as her beauty had of admiration, and therefore unwilling to detain her in a prolix dicoure, which could not
but dipleae in uch a condition, he left her the full liberty of returning to her own company, with whom he might condole, and try to dimis her orrows, only giving charge to a young Perian Lord, nam'd Arape, to have a particular care to treat her with that honour which was due to her birth, and merits.

Arape had from his youth been bred up in the Perian Academies with Cyrus, to whoe fortune he had ince particularly ty'd himelf. It eem'd that Cyrus impoing the Commiion on him to guard this Woman, had conulted with his inclination, for before he was preented to him (inpir'd by the ecret motions of that fatal detiny which none can avoid) Arape had already ought her out amongt all the other Prioners, and being only invited to a compaion for her Captivity, he had look'd on her with a more then ordinary curioity.

Panthea (o was the name of this beautiful Princes) at that preent was but meanly clad, itting amongt her maids, who hew'd her no repect, more than to any other, thereby to hide her quality from dicovery: but raiing her elf before Arape, whom he judg'd to be ome extraordinary peron by the great throng that follow'd at his heels, he preently imagin'd that nature had not plac'd o much Majety, as he remarked in her action, and port, to one of ordinary birth and beauty.

His opinion did not deceive him, for the civility he expres'd, having oblig'd her to unvail that Divine face, which he till then had alwayes hid
behind that cloud, his eye not only met with uch a ravihing complexion, and weet feature as did urpas the power, and liberty of fancy to imagine: but he reented the vertue of thoe charms (whoe ecret Magick had compel'd him to eek her out) diving into the very centre of his bret with love, and all-controuling paions. He had no ooner een her, but he deir'd to eclipe her from all others: but having uch a crowd of Witnees, he was contrain'd, dipite of all repugnancy, to conent that he hould be preented to Cyrus as the Medes had propounded. This new-born paion he had hot into his oul, hook him with apprehenion leat Cyrus hould accept of her, and one may truly ay that he received with more joy, (though not without the allay of inward trouble) the command of guarding her, then if they had betow'd the richet Crowns, and Scepters in the world upon him.

Cyrus who perceiv'd the emotions of his heart; charactred on his tell-tale face, would have known the caue, and wih'd him above all things if he found himelf too feeble to withtand her charms, not to undertake the charge: the combat being the more dangerous, becaue that fair enemy being ever preent, he mut lye at a wary guard to defend himelf each moment, and enjoying yet a liberty that was uurp'd by none, it would be difficult to refue that bewitching Sex, invading it o weetly: he added more-over that 'twas impoible to behold a beauty like Pantheas and not love it, but then he mut precribe that affection within the limits of vertue, becaue it did import
them, very much to preerve the reputation of their victory untain'd, by right of which, the Captives were indeed become ubject to their jut power, but not to their unlawful paions.

Arape having recover'd his etled countenance, anwer'd that it was true indeed he had not been able to eye o many miracles in one peron without atonihment, neither could he believe that any man living could be o dull as to behold her, and not find the like entiments of repect towards her, as he did in his oul; but yet he was not ignorant of the rules of his devoir, and the trouble which might have overpread his face, being only an effect of his admiration, he aur'd him that whatever inclination he hould cherih for Panthea, it hould never exceed that which one ought not to deny to any beauteous peron.

Cyrus in fine recommended the contancy of this reolution to him, and told him at parting that he hould remember, it was difficult to approach the fire and not be heated, that love dealing treacherouly in all his wayes, he mut upect him, as one that never flatters but to hurt. Arape promis'd on his part dipite of all thoe notions in his heart that he would never go beyond an eteem for her. But the rapid treams of his inclination drove him far beyond all thee bounds, and after a few dayes iege, which he maintain'd againt thoe potent paions, he was compel'd to yeild to their violent aaults, upon no better compoition than their uncertain mercy.

If the firt ight and preence of Panthea had o powerfully charm'd him, 'tis eaie to imagine that
her noble converation wholly vanquih'd him: he tudied every day, finding he treated her with uch choice repect, to oblige him by a thouand new civilities, expreing a great care for his peron, and rendring him in fine all the tetimonies of love and amity that he could have expected from a Siter. The effect of Panthea's civility was very different from what he deired, her deign aiming only to gain him for her friend, not perceiving that he ingag'd him as a Lover. This poor Prince tifling the flames affection kindled in his bret, by his dicreeter ilence, that he might not break the promie he had verbally eal'd to Cyrus, conceal'd his paion. But this contagious malady of the mind infected his body, and fir'd that frail Cottage with a burning Feaver, whoe flames brought thoe ecret thoughts to light, which he till then had kept hidden, and though there did appear ome extravagancy in his ditemper'd peeches, yet it was eaie to be known, that the remembrance of Panthea did alwayes feed his imagination. She went often to viit him, and though his fits redoubled at her preence, yet he was ometimes of a more compoed pi • it than when he was not there. One day when he enquired of the Phiitians of his malady, they told her that in the extremity of his Feaver he mot times pake of her, but yet he could not upect in the leat that this was any effect of love, but was perwaded that being often in his ight, the image of her peron might often preent it elf to his fancy.

But coming another time into his Chamber
when he was troubled in his wilder thoughts, he turned towards her, and with a vehement peech; Well Madam, aid he to her, is it not enough to torment me with your remembrance, but you mut come to kill me by your ight? hall I have no releae from thoe deep ufferings? and my recovery being deperate, am I forbidden the leat conolation? Yes, continued he, turning uddenly from her, and whipering to himelf in a ad tone; Lets dye ince 'tis the will of Heaven, for death is the only remedy for my afflictions. Ha! Panthea, cry'd he again, darting his eye upon her, after a little ilence, Abradate is your huband, Cyrus has forbidden me, I have promis'd it, your devoir will not permit you, I hould violate my own: But —I have reited to my utmot, and 'tis you contrain me, is it not true Madam? with thee words which he pronounced omewhat loud, he ceaed from peaking, and cat his looks wihly upon Panthea, who being in amazement at what he had talked with o much confuion, not being able to comprehend it, he approached nearer to his bed, and finding him as he thought in a calmer temper; Is it poible, aid he, Arape, that I hould be o unhappy as to have contributed any thing to your ufferings? what have I done, which is o harh to your remembrance? what can it import you, that Abrodate is my huband? what has Cyrus forbidden you? what have you promis'd him? wherein have I trepas'd againt my devoir? what have I contrained you to do, good gods, 'gaint which you have o much reited: Tell me, Arape, and aure your elf
that if your health depended upon me, though 'twere to be purchaed with my life, you hould not be one moment longer in this languihing condition, and though I am unhappy in my fortune, believe it, I will not lye under the guilt of ingratitude for thoe noble favours I have received, but hall eteem the fortune of my captivity a bleing, if there be any means left me at preent whereby to erve you?

Arape after a great igh, anwer'd her with a oft voyce, I perceive Madam, that the violence of my Feaver has made me dicoure extravagantly, I am aham'd to be o unprovided of fitting excues for it, and beg your pardon, if I have mention'd your elf, or worthy Husband in my ditempers: In that condition you may gues, that being not the Mater of my reaon, I only talk what my extravagant imagination uggets, and that, which it may be, my Devoir would forbid me once to think on. Panthea would not pres him further, and eaily believ'd, that what he had heard was only the effects of his troubled fancy; Therefore after he had a while longer entertain'd him with much mildnes, he left the ad Arape, more turmoiled with his paion than his Feaver, which both together et upon him with uch violence, preently after her going, that the Phiitians began to dipair of his life.

Cyrus, Tygranes, Artabaus, and many other perons of quality being informed of it, came together to viit him, they found him in more danger than he had been, and he no ooner perceiv'd Cyrus, who drew near to his bed, but cating a
furious look upon him: 'Tis you likewie cruel—aid he, that econded the Tyranny of her Devoir; I hould be les unhappy were it not for you, nor hould I meet o many obtacles to my content, were I not contrain'd by your conideration. Hence, cruel, hence, what you are come to perecute me with your preence, and take away the very liberty of complaint. Ah 'tis too, too much! his obs, and hollow igh's blockt up all the paages of peech, and the Phiitians perceiving his tranport, intreated Cyrus to withdraw, with all thoe that accompanied him, to give him a little repoe. He was no ooner left alone but his reaon returned to her eat, and quickly tam'd the tempet of his mind, o that he commanded one of thoe that waited in his Chamber, to go and beeech Panthea in his behalf to come to him.

As oon as he arriv'd he caus'd all the ret to avoid the room, except one Gentleman, whoe fidelity he might confide in, and one of Panthea's Maids, and then eeing himelf at liberty to peak, he began thus: I find, Madam, that you are no les urpriz'd to ee me in this tranquility of pirit at preent, than you were before, when I had lot the helm of my reaon and judgement. The ame caue nevertheles has produc'd thee different effects, and that which occaioned my rude ditempers, does now retore me to o mooth a calm, that I can dicover a ecret to you, which I hould yet conceal, did I not find that the approach of death obliged me to it. This lat extremity, Madam, may excue me if there be any
temerity in declaring it to you, which o far concerns my life, that 'tis the only thing which makes me looe it now. Judge, Madam, whether I may not reveal it without a crime, I know however you will not hear it without ome dipleaure, but I am confident likewie that you are too generous to refue my pardon, which I implore before I dye, together with the permiion to dicloe it. At thee words he made a little paue, to hear what he would anwer in that vacancy, but perceiving his propoition either too melancholly, or too obcure to gain a reply; What, Madam, aid he, do you not yet undertand me, mut I expound that in plain terms, which I would hide in ome manner from you, and will you not take notice of my paion, unles I ay exprely, that I love you? Ah, Madam, that word will cot me my life, I can add no more, and 'tis ufficient for my atisfaction that you know it. He could not command trength enough, either to draw out the thred of his dicoure any longer, or to expect her anwer, his ences taking their flight together with his peech, and Panthea beholding him in this condition, reented the uproar of many paions trugling in her bret together: modety, anger, and compaion invaded her mind, o that he was ome moments in a deep upence, but eeing thoe that were by, o buily imploy'd to ait him, he recover'd o much pitty as to lend her bet endeavours, and truly one may ay that he alone was able to revive him, as he had only been the occaion of his troubles. So oon as he was approached, his nature gather'd up its
trength, and his eyes returning to their firt offices, beholding her in that obliging imployment, his tongue unty'd it elf in thee expreions.

Ha, what, Madam, will you not have me dye after o preumptuous a declaration, do you pretend to cure me, triving to make me live. Yes, reparted Panthea, I will not have you dye, though I do not pretend your cure, having no remedy for your malady, you only are the caue of it your elf, and if you found any inclination to love, you ought not to have undertaken the charge of me. Nevertheles what help I can contribute, without a prejudice to my honour, you may jutly hope for. To love is not a crime, I confes it, Arape, and provided you manage your affection according to the laws of vertue, I conent to it: but do not break the rules which I precribe you, if it uffice you, as you would have me believe, that I hould only be acquainted with it, I hall eteem it ever real, o long as you do not offend my reputation, look to your health only, and make it apparent to Panthea, who intreats you, that your affection being not guilty, is capable to bring you as much repoe and content, as it hath cot you trouble.

If I have ever wih'd to dye, reply'd Arape, to end my torments, I do as earnetly now implore the gods, to uffer me to live, ince you command it, Madam, that I may tetifie by my repects, and ervices, the immortal obligations I owe to your infinite bounty, which does concede far more than my mot flattering hopes could ever promie,
by permitting me to love you: my ambition reach'd no higher but to dicover it before my death, and I hall be, if I may live, henceforth too happy, in my aiduous endeavours to make known that the bent of all my worthiet actions tend only to the honour of your ervice.

This conference gave no les eae and comfort to Arape, than it occaioned trouble, and atonihment to Panthea. She was no ooner alone, but examining in her own chat thoughts all that had pas'd, he accus'd her elf of too much complaiance, as if he had forfeited that evere vertue in which the world does make a Ladies honour conit, and feared leat the permiion he had granted him to continue his fair affections, hould pur him on beyond repect and decency. But afterwards he excus'd her elf of fondnes upon that weight of obligations which he ow'd, and thought he could in civility do no les, than uffer an honet and vertuous friendhip.

On the other part, Arape had quite a contrary opinion, he contrued Panthea's civility o much to his own advantage, that taking the conent he allowed his affection, to be meant a retaliation equal to his pasion, he took a nice care of his recovery, that he might be able to reap the fruits of his deires. This vain preumption had almot lot him, he laid by all repect, which he till then had oberved towards her, and follow'd his own head-trong paions, o that Panthea finding her elf dangerouly perecuted by his inolent courthip, was contrain'd to prefer the bill of her complaints to Cyrus, who weighing how important it
was towards his affairs not to offend a Princes, whoe Husband with his forces might go near to turn the Scale on either ide, whom he pretended to court to a compliance by the mediation of his excellent Princes, he took her out of his keeping, and made her all the noble atisfaction that was poible for her to expect.

About this time Cyrus went into Garamee, hard by the City of Oroba, where Gobrias was making preparations for his reception. He encamped there about, and being attended with the principal Officers and Nobility of his Army, made his entrance, which was as magnificent on his part, as it was proud and cotly on the inhabitants. The peoples loud acclamations declar'd with how much joy he was receiv'd. Gobrias with a great Train of Nobles gallantly mounted, and richly cloathed, went forth to meet him, and conducted him to his Palace, where his Daughter the generous Azimea, and all the great Ladies received them: this ceremony being performed on either part with a thouand civil expreions. They made him preents of a vat um of money, and all the other rarities which the Orient does produce, the which he nobly accepted, but it was only to retore them to Azimea, to whom he profer'd them o gracefully, that he could not refue them with handomenes, after he had long diputed with him for generoity, and that he had proteted more-over that if he commenc'd that War againt the Ayrians for reaons of State, the deires to erve her and to revenge her juter interets hould be henceforth the principal caue to
make him continue and carry it on, to confirm which, having given her his hand, he followed her into many pacious rooms, whoe furniture for beauty, and magnificence gave no les wonder than delight; and afterwards taking his quiet repoe for a hort pace (having contracted ome wearines in viewing the rarities of one of the fairet houes in all Aia, and viiting the fortifications about the City) being omewhat refrehed of that toile, he took his farewell of Gobrias, (who earnetly intreated him to honour him with his preence at upper, and pas away ome dayes in that City) and returned to his Camp, preferring that ober frugality which the Perians oberve in their diet, before the delicacy of thoe exquiite mees which Gobrias prepared at his plendid entertainments.

Amongt thoe whom the beauty of the Ladies of Garamee had inamour'd Hitape Lieutenant General of the Perian Cavalry, was one, being conquer'd by Azimea's, but whatever advantage he promied himelf from Cyrus favour, who dearly loved him, to whom Gobrias had abolutely committed the dipoal of his Daughter, yet he durt not fly his thoughts o high as to pretend affection towards a Princes, who had been elected for the Scepter of Ayria, and o generouly refued it. He propounded nevertheles to erve her, and to become, if poible, the miniter of her vengeance, to merit at leat by that action ome acknowledgement from her goodnes, if he durt not expect it from her love.

In the mean while, Cyrus was full of mot trange
inquietudes, he appear'd o ad, and was o troubled and impatient, that the warlike occupations for the Conquet of Ayria, not being able to divert him from the thoughts of his dear Princes, it eem'd that Sybaris and Abracome were too low in ending him the news he languiht to hear. Gobrias who was unacquainted with the caue of his trouble, and had a great deire to be informed of it, meeting Artabae in a Garden walking with Merame, and the Hircanian Prince accoted them, and having molded his dicoure upon that ubject, it tempted the Hircanian Prince, and Merame with the like curioity of enquiry, who joyntly declaring to Artabae the obligation it would be to intruct them in the happy knowledge of what o nearly concern'd their noble General, being all eated in a pleaant Arbour, Artabae to feed their greedy deires and attentions, commenc'd his dicoure in this manner.

You may have great reaon to wonder at the black melancholly of a Prince victorious over his enemies, glorious for his heroick actions, and happy, in fine, in all appearance, if ever any man were. A Prince to whoe high valour all others yeild their powers, either in eeking his protection, or flying from his preence. The melancholly nevertheles, which is o legible to you on his countenance, is one of the effects of his firt victory he gained in this War, the Lawrels which compos'd that Crown of triumph, were interlaced with thoe Thornes which yet torment him, he having lot his repoe and liberty amongt thoe whom the chance of War had made his Captives:
but that I may entirely atisfy the curioity which you may have to know the compleate hitory of this young Heroe, who in his tenderet yeares perform'd uch actions as are too rare to be pas'd over in ilence, you mut permit me to take my rie from thoe times.

div.head: The Hitory of Cyrus and Birinthea.
div.p:
You cannot but have heard of thoe celebrous Academies in Peria, where vertue alone preides, and where they are o well taught to practice it. 'Twas in thoe learned chooles. Our Prince was bred and intructed, whoe condition did not dipene him from the everity of thoe lawes which they oberve, they gave him no other but the ordinary coure nourihment of bread and crees, and atisfied his thirt with natures plain beverage, a dih of water, thereby to accutome him to undergoe hardhip when he hould come to be more necearily acquainted with it in time of war: they taught him likewie to hoot exactly with a bow, and cat a pear, with all thoe other exercies which concern the agility and vigour of the body. In a word, he was treated with the ame rigour as all the other were, the only difference that could be noted was, the wonderful aptitude, and readines of his attaining every thing with facility. Amongt all his condiciples there was not any that could paralel his activity of body: and for learning,
none ever made a greater progres in o hort a time: and concerning all thoe little intrigues, and differences, which ever happen amongt children, as thefts, rapine, calumny, ingratitude, deceits, and other uch like crimes, he was made judge, and o behav'd himelf, that uch as are mot perfect in the lawes; and have a long time weilded the word of jutice, never pronounced more equitable and judicious entences, nor could the ablet barriter have hap'd better pleas to defend innocency, or have heap'd more preing reaons on the head of guiltines, then he continually did.

Thee rare advantages of body and mind, conjoyn'd to his illutrious birth made him become o famous, that Atiages his Grandfather formerly King of the Medes, the Father of Cyaxarez having heard a recital of o many wonders, was extreme deirous to ee him. Cyrus as you know is on of Cambyes King of Peria, and Mandane the daughter of Atiages. His Mother would needs go into Media to conduct him to his grandfather, who found by him, that Fame, which uually exceeds in her report of other things, wanted both mouthes and breath to proclaime all the excellent qualities of this young Prince. He found him more compleate every way then report had blazon'd, the dipoition of his body and poture, was handomer and more taking then he could poibly fancy, and beyond that, he found o mature a judgement, and uch a parkling vivacity of wit, as he confes'd, that all what had been related, though that were many
teps above a fond beliefe, was yet o much beneath the exquiite indowments he now really met with in his peron, that nothing but the tetimony of his own ight, could ever have perwaded as a truth.
