In a word, the infinite charmes and graces of his peron, and pirit were o many, that it may jutly releae me from repeating them it will uffice to tell you, that in an age o tender and Blooming, which eaily receives any impreion, not having yet tept over fourteen yeares, he had uch olid principles of vertue, that the delicious and oft lives they led in Media could never corrupt his nobler entiments.

The firt time he aluted his grand-father Atiages, eeing him richly habited, having many jewells, and a weet cloud of perfumes about him, he freely avowed that the modet plaines the Perians oberve in their vetments, pleaed him far beyond it, and he prefer'd the ober frugality of his former wholeome diet, before the dainty viands they now preented to his tate. In fine, amidt all that delicacy, he kept himelf up trictly, to that rigid vertue he had practied at home, all that he learned amongt them was to mannage a hore, becaue in his country it was neither o frequent, nor o perfectly taught, as oon as he had attained this skill, he went continually to hunting with Cyaxares the on of Atiages, in which exercie having given many evident proofs of his valour and activity, he added one more alo of his courage in an occaion of war which proffer'd it elf at that time.

Atiages having been advertis'd that the Ayrians
endammaged his frontiers by their continuall pillaging, and frequent incurions, ent Cyaxares with a competent trength to repule and tame them. Then was it that Cyrus felt that generous ardour firt boyling in his youthful veins, which the alarm's of war does ue to kindle in valiant breats. In lieu of following his unckles teps as a volunteer, he put himelf in the head of their troops, as if he only had been their Captain, o that neither Cyaxares nor the Medes had any other conduct but his own, nor could the god of war himelf have inpir'd them with more courage then did his noble examples. He was o heated in the fight, and thrut himelf o far amongt the thicket of the enemies, who already began to fly before the fury of this young Conquerour, that Cyaxares fearing leat he hould too eagerly engage himelf in a further purute, was contrain'd to goe in peron and fetch him of. In fine all his actions bred every day new and deerving admiration, nor did Atiages returne him to his Father Cambyis, but with regret, who coveted to have o inetimable a jewell in the poeion of his own dear embracements, having heard what a new luter and glory his freh victories had put upon his fame. Returning into Peria, he carried all the hearts and affections of the Medes along with him, which they paid readily down in myriads of happy wihes, & bleings at his departure, o generally he acquir'd their love and zealous repects, by thoe good offices he render'd them whilt he reided there, and the
obliging carrees with which he treated all men.

Shortly after his returne from Media, Atiages died, and Cyaxares his on, and his ucceor to the Empire, found himelf dangerouly aaulted by all the Aian puiance at once. Labynetus King of the Ayrians having already ubdued all Siria, rendred the Arabians tributaries, and vanquiht the Hircanians and the Bactrians believed that if he could but hang his chains upon the Medes and Perians, he hould find no more enemies o powerful as to dipute his intire conquet of Aia. He had ambition enough for this deign: but doubting of his trength to carry him thorow, he wrote to the King of Lydia, to him of Capadocia, to the Phrigians, Indians, the people of Caria and Cilicia, cajolling and intreating them to enter into confederation, and undertake a war with him againt the Medes and Perians, whoe trong alliance he perwaded them to feare, repreenting how neceary it was for them to knit, and unite their force together, to invade and diolve them, whom alone they neither would be able to uppres, or reit, This reaon engaged ome of thee Princes to joyn with him, the others being oblig'd alo to conent either as being their vaalls, or their friends.

The mighty preparations which were made in all thoe nations for this war, could not be o ecretly managed, but Cyaxares had notice given him of it, and leat this tempet, which o horridly menac'd him, hould uddenly breake upon
his head and over-flow him unprovided, he quickly caus'd a numerous Army to be levied in his own kingdome, and wrote to Cambyes King of Peria intreating him to joyn forces with him, ince the interet to oppoe thee Enemies was equall to them both, and to contitute his on general of thoe men he would end, becaue he was o indeared to the Medes, and they built uch mighty confidence and hopes on his magnanimity, by thoe early proofs he had already carved with his word when he was amongt them, that they believ'd the greatet helpe that ever heaven could lend them, would be the preence, and conduct of that young Prince.

Cambyes hugg'd the propoition of Cyaxares with the more willing embraces, becaue the glorious eteem they et upon his on concerned himelf o neerly. He caus'd thirty thouand ouldiers to be raied with all poible diligence over whom Cyrus, by the full vote of the Councel of war was elected general, and the very next day having caus'd his army to be rang'd in battalia, he etabliht him in this high office, whilt they were offering the acrifices, uual on uch occaions, the ayre was fil'd with extraordinary lightning and thunders, which eem'd to peak the gods conent to this ceremony, to which the ouldiers repeated a thouand loud acclamations of joy, which they ent up to Heaven for his properity.

The air in fine having recover'd the beauty of its former erenity, Cyrus impoed ilence thorow the whole Army, and tanding in an eminent
place from whence his words might reach their hearing mot ditinctly, he made this following Harangue to his ouldiers.

div.head: The Harangue to the Perian Army.
div.p:
I am extremely glad fellow ouldiers, that heaven by its happy auguries has authoried the choice which Cyaxares, and
• ambyes have made of me, to be your general: but though this office be due to my birth, as being on to the one, and the others Nepveu, and that I find, in myelf, courage, and reolution ufficient to undergoe it, I mut confes, nevertheles, that I hall tand in ome need to be upported by yours alo, and we mut reciprocally, by our joynt valour, econd the fortune which the gods promie felicitous to us: otherwie, ouldiers, if by our unmanlines only, the event of this war hould fall hort of the hopes we have, to make it ucceed according to our own deires, and the gods hould abandon us to all the misfortunes which commonly attend a hameful defeate, we hould not however have caue to complain that they were wanting in the promie of that victory they now proclaim to us by the mouth of thunders: For to judge aright, dear companions, thee horrid claps which eem to be the tetimonies of their favourable conent to our jut deignes, doe advertie us likewie that they have power to avenge themelves upon their Enemies And who, I pray you, are their Enemies, but thoe that turne their backs to honor, to prop and maintain injutice and cruelty, and will
you not acknowledge with me, that if they eem to declare themelves for us againt the Ayrians, becaue that nation aaults us wrongfully, and with much baenes, they at the ame time menace thoe amongt us, who have not vertue or courage enough to defend the honor of their country, their Princes reputation, together with their deare parents lives, and their own families ecurity; but n • t to rove o far to point out the intruments of their threatning vengeance, doe we not know already, that the Ayrians have unheath'd their thirty words, and if by our ignoble cowardie, we render our elves unworthy of heavens protection, may not thoe barbarous people be made the rod to punih us. Let us therefore beware oldiers, of betraying the interet of jutice, and our own afety, let us not pull our ruine on our own heads, ince we take arms but to preerve our elves, lets carry on the war with as much courage as we commence it with fixed reolution; and let us how the Ayrians, that 'tis not without reaon they have confederated o many nations in one body againt us, and et o many thouands a foote, ince they hall find it no weake oppoition: and that they are deceiv'd in their deign to invade us, we going now to prevent them, and turne the bloody treame of war upon themelves.

The whole army anwer'd this harangue with many redoubled houts and acclamations, which poke the ouldiers impatience to be facing their enemies, againt whom they now were uddenly to march. The Captains and all the mot expert offi • ers of war, confes'd they never undertook a voyage with a more promiing aurance
of victory, then now under this young, but hopeful General. The orders in fine, were given to et forwards within eight dayes, in which time Cyrus received the adieus from all the Nobility, and the King his Father, and took his farewel alo of his deare Mother the Queen, with the Princes Azumane his iter. The appointed day being come, Cambyes would needs accompany him to the borders that were contiguous to Peria, (where being arrived a mighty Eagle appeard flying at his right hand) and having taken his lat leave of his Father, and the gods of Peria, at his entrance into Media he adored their deities, and went to Cyaxares his unckle, who was advanced very near the frontires to receive him, and tetified by all the becoming tokens of civility and affection, the joy and infinite content he reented at his arrival.

Cyrus who as yet had let in no other paions to governe his young oule, but the ambition to improve the glory of his courage, hearing the Enemies were yet at a great ditance, imploy'd his time in the continual exercies of war, for which he ordained many prizes which he mot commonly won fairely himelf, with more agility and skill then fortune: but at length being tyr'd with their long tay, fearing leat the idlenes and delights of that country hould rut or enervate his ouldiers wonted courage, he intreated his unckle to give him leave to march towards thoe Ayrians whoe tedious delay hew'd ome unwillingnes in them to come to any blowes, Cyaxares who tudied nothing but to
defend himelf, becaue he knew his numbers les then the Enemies and being ever poes'd with a kind of feare, made the arrival of ome Indian Ambaadors the pretext to tay him, howing him the neceity there was that he hould know the ubject of their negociation before he precipitated his affairs, Thee Ambaadors being appointed audience, declar'd the command they had from their King to peak with him, and the Perian Monarch, to know, what reaons moved them to make war, and acertain thoe that hould proceed mot jutly, of a powerful aitance from him, on their behalf, and after they had learn'd from Cyaxares own mouth, that he arm'd himelf only to withtand the Ayrians, and bridle their inolence, and ambition, they took their leaves of him, and bearing away with them the pretence that detain'd Cyrus, they left him full liberty to pres his march with more eagernes.

Cyaxares nevertheles, who believ'd he wanted as much trength as he did courage, indeavour'd by many coniderations to keep them back till, the cheifet there of being a want of money at that preent, which is the only oule, and life of war. But this which he propounded as an obtacle, pur'd him on with the greater peed, and gave the firt motion to his generous expeditions, which have rais'd him ince to the proudet pitch of glory that ever Conquerour could hope or wih: for being perfectly acquainted with all his uncles affairs, he remembred that he had heard ay Artaban the King of Armenia had refus'd to pay him the tribute of fifty talents which he
ow'd him for thoe Provinces that Atiages had formerly conquer'd, nor was he very haty to anwer their demands of thoe troops he was oblig'd to furnih them withall: wherefore he told Cyaxares that he ought to begin his war firt with his own rebells, that o he might not have any dometick Enemies within his bowels, and that by reducing Artaban to his becoming Devoir, it would cat a bridle on the remainder of his ubjects necks, and keep them in the roade of due obedience.

This propoition having been canvas'd, and conulted on in the Counel of war, was found to be very rational, and they judg'd it convenient to attaque the Armenian, who fed his tubborne inolency, only with the faire promies of protection from the Ayrians, For this purpoe Cyrus made a great match of hunting thereby to draw ome troops, under that colour, neer the mountains of Armenia; and Cyaxares, to take of all upition of any uch deign, feigned that he went to viit the frontier garrions in peron, in each of which he left a good number of ouldiers, which Cyrus afterwards ecretly ent under the command of Chryante to poes themelves of ome paages, in the mountains, of great importance.

Before Artaban could be informed of their enterprie, Cyrus dipatched a Courier to him, by whom he gave him notice that he was entred upon his dominions to receive that money, and thoe ouldiers he was obliged to furnih his uncle with, or to fetch them in peron at the head of a potent army, who would oon wring
this out of his hands, if he refus'd a preent compliance.

Never was Prince more perplexed, or amazed then Artaban at this demand, he never could imagine that Cyaxares having uch puiant Enemies could think of any thing but to defend himelf: the promie he had made to the Ayrians not to end any aitance to the Medes, and the preence of a reolute Army which threatned to force him to his devoir, upended his judgement a while.

In fine having return'd, in anwer to Cyrus, many excuive delatory reaons, proteting an impoibility to atisfy him for the preent, hinting that himelf was in ditres of men, and treaure for his own ecurity, and could not pare any to others. He thought to teale himelf from their pu • uites amongt the forrets, and inacceible mountains in that country, till by the helpe of the Ayriuns, to whom he ent letters of his condition, he were in a poture to drive them out again In this reolution he left the campania open to his Enemies, and having caus'd his wife, and children, with his richet treaures to be helterd in the forrets under the ave guard of one of his ons nam'd Phra • rte, he gather'd as many ouldiers as poibly he could, to hinder his Enemies from ranging about his lands, but Cyrus advancing with his main body, oon dipered thoe that had reited his fore-runners, and contrain'd Artaban to quit the pots he was poeed of.

Cyrus, who would not give his Enemy the leaure to make his own choice of a retreate, purued him o clos, that notwithtanding the difficulty of the wayes and thicknes of the forrets, he never lot his fight. Artaban would willingly have made his ecape by ome concealed path, but the providence of his Enemy had cut of all poibility of an ecape before: o that he was at length hut up within thoe mountains, which debar'd all further flight, and Cyrus no ooner found he had reduc't him to the inevitable neceity of yeilding to hunger and thirt, or throw himelf into the danger of a fight, but he ent him a Trumpetter, by whom he exhorted him to dipute for his liberty generouly, rather then pine away with meager famine, which could not be reited: but the Armenian defferr'd always to anwer him, till he heard the heart piercing news of his wife, and childrens, being fallen into the hands of Chryante.

Thee tydings tab'd him to the oule with griefe, and taggard his former reolution not to yeild till the lat extremity; he came down into the plaines, judging it now better to ave or looe himelf with his diconolate famil • , then by an obtinate and vain reitance to inflame the jut anger of his generous Conqueror, at whoe triumphant feet he came and cat himelf to implore his clemency. Cyrus having received him as King, but yet as a rebell King and prioner, gave order for the troops, that came in with him, to be dipered amongt his own, and without wating further time, according to the expres
command injoyn'd him by his uncle Cyaxares, he aembled the principal of his Army, before whom he ummon'd Artaban to appeare, who having lot his courage with his liberty, preented himelf rather in the poture of a guility peron then an afflicted Prince. After everal interrogations made to him, this unhappy King could alledge nothing to excue his rebellion but the deire to gain an abolute liberty for his ucceor, by haking of the yoke of being tributary, he made him firt acknowledge how unjutly he had refus'd to furnih his uncle with the men and money he demanded, having o good title to them, and how baely he had proffer'd aitance to the Ayrians, with whom he had ecretly treated, and having afterwards asked him how he would chatie a vaal that hould thus betray him, he drew that neceary condemnation out of his own mouth, which entenc'd him to death.

Whilt Cyrus was imploy'd about this ad doom, Chryante arriv'd, who brought in the Armenian Queen and her children as prioners: but to obey the command he receiv'd from his Uncle to put that mierable Prince to death, Cyrus ordered exprely that they hould not uffer them to come together, nor let them in the leat know what was intended, to hun that conflict of compaion which their tears, and the rigour of his duty would raie in his noble breat.

The Armenian Queen liv'd yet in the happy ignorance of her Husbands miery and captivity, but when he from her Chariot, beheld him going
forth from the Tent circled within a Guard of Souldiers, with a viage whereon the expectation of death had already epitomized all his fears and horrors, he threw her elf down uddenly with bitter cryes; and renting the vail which covered her head, with extream violence, he furiouly bent her precipitate teps toward thoe that held Artaban, endeavouring with earnet prayers, and interrupted reproaches, and threats to wret him from their hands; when Cyrus warn'd of the diorder by the ad noie and moans which reach'd his ear, came forth to know the Original of it.

The fury of this almot ditracted woman, whom he knew not to be the Armenian Queen at firt urpriz'd him, and being told by one of the Souldiers who it was, he approach'd to appeae her: but he continued till her fruitles violence, periting in her mournful cryes, that they hould either lead her with Artaban, or kill her preently? till being told that Cyrus was there preent, he no ooner knew him, but falling at his feet, and uppreing her furious tone, changing it into accents of upplication; he implor'd him with all the melting language thoe dolorous paions could ugget to one, who having already lot her Kingdom and liberty, beheld her Husband led away in chains, by whom alone he could conceive the mallet glimpe of hope to be retor'd to any happines again. Cyrus was tooping jut to raie her up when the noie of ome approaching Cavaliers interrupted his civility. They brought him a new prioner, whom at firt ight he had no cognizance of, but which the Queens redoubled
hrieks, and cryes oon made him know. It was the Prince Tygranes, eldet Son of Artaban, who is at preent in this Army, he being then jut return'd from a Voyage he had made, fell into the Perians hands, before he was acquainted that any Enemies had footing in his Fathers Country. His Mother no ooner pied him, but he cryed out o dolefully that it increaed his atonihment, and the beholders pitty; and you dear Son, will you be likewie one addition more to our heap of orrow? the anger of the gods would not be fully atisfied, if their injutice had not drag'd you hither, to compleat the ad catatrophe of our ruine. Come, come, approach yet nearer Son: uffer him, aid he to Cyrus, to ee his Father once before he dyes. Conider, Tygranes, in what a lot condition is Artaban? and how undone your Mother, Wife, Siter, and all relations are, and then, ô tell me wherefore you came hither? but you unmerciful and angry deities, why have you brought him to us? is it to catch the falling Crown and Scepter, and upport the reeling Throne which your injutice batters down o cruelly. Ha! no, 'tis to involve the heyre, together with the other leer reliques of our unhappy Family, in one general detruction, leat any hould urvive our rugged fate. You gods therefore, I do retract my former words, for I perceive there is ome kind of equity in your judgements, it being more jut, if our ruine be o inevitable, that we hould fall together, then that any hould be reerved to weep our ad calamity. Come near my Son, come children, come, cry'd
he in a harper tone, calling thoe who tood at a little ditance, fetter us altogether, aid he to Cyrus, in the ame chain, and if you can be o merciful in your cruelty, let one blow put a period to all our mieries, for this will be a more welcome favour than alone to ravih Artaban from us. Her welling orrows topt the current of further dicoure, and the frequent obs, and ighs that throng'd out of her boome, left her no other power of expreion, but her fugitive tears.
Mean while, Cyrus was wrapt into the greatet atonihment that could be; Tygranes had been otherwhile his particular friend, they having had their breeding together in the Perian Academies.

The unhappines of this Prince, and the Queens tears fill'd his eyes with horror, and his heart with pitty. He knew not whether he hould anwer the Mothers moving plaints, to whom he had already given full aurance of her own, and all her childrens lives, or comfort the Son whom the amazement of o unlooked for an accident had o urpried, that of all his ences he could command the ue of none but his ight, to be the Witnes of that funet pectacle.

His Father Artaban, who had not enough contancy to tand the hock of his own particular mifortune, eem'd to increae it, when he was made acquainted with the mierable condition of his Wife, and Children; and whether his grief were too great for expreion, or that the extremity of his affliction, eeming to ting him beyond the help of conolation, cat him into dipair, which
hardens the mot timorous pirits with reolution, he now endeavour'd to comfort his Wife, and his Son Tygranes, hewing them that Cyrus was obliged to ave the ret of his Family by the ame argument, and jutice which ruin'd him; ince they were no way guilty of that rebellion he had alone been Author and occaion of. That they ought confidently to expect a milder treatment from his clemency than himelf, becaue his death would atisfie the reentments of Cyaxares, and that they hould endeavour by their vertues to regain the glory of his Houe, which he had o ecliped, and tain'd by his perfidious act, proving by their future ervices, and fidelity, how free they truly were from being his accomplices in that crime. He could not keep thoe tears that hung at his blubbering eyes from tealing down his face, nor uppres a multitude of ighs his grief tore from his heart, when he ended this generous dicoure, epecially when he beheld his young Son Phraorte, his Daughter Birinthea, and Artemia wife to Tygranes, whom Cyrus had caued to be brought to him.
Never was any pectacle o mournful, pitty had ingraved o much orrow on each viage, that it was difficult to dicern the Conquerours from the Captives.

Tygranes, whoe tongue was till now fetter'd with his too violent griefs, finding himelf obliged by his Parents tears, and preence, epecially his dearet Arthemia's, went towards Cyrus, who tood mute likewie, and could not hide ome tokens of pitty from appearing, peaking to him in this
manner. Ah Sir, what mut we expect from this deep ilence, is it an effect of the compaion our unhappines tirs up in your heart, or the everity of your entence? what, is it not enough to take away the Crown and Scepter from a Royal Family, and o many Subjects from their King, without depriving a Woman of her Husband, and ravihing the Father from o many children, who deire nothing of all what they have lot, but the liberty to dye preently with them, or to have him remain a mierable Captive amongt them? does this Petition eem to be unjut? what right have you to deny death to us, ince you believe it to be o jut towards him? or if you do conceive him to be alone guilty, wherefore do you punih us more rigorouly than him, letting us live with the regret for looing him which is a thouand times more enible to us then death it elf? but I perceive what 'tis caues his condemnation, 'tis not your elf, Sir, nor the reentment of Cyaxares, that pittiles, reaon of State does murther him, and you fondly believe there is no more caue to fear, after the Leader of a Rebellion is thrut out of the world: a poor conideration, and weak argument of unadvied policy, what then do you imagine the children of Kings, have uch low pirits, and o mall courage that in what tate oever they remain, they will not endeavour to revenge a Fathers death (who was o dear and tender in his affection to them) by all the means that hatred, and dipair can tore them with; 'tis true indeed the head of uch a faction is thereby taken off; but know, Sir, 'tis a Hydra
which till prouts new ones forth, and of all thoe you now behold in your preence, as Artabans children, expect the ame fixt reolution either to dye with him, or ele perpetually to eek a full revenge. Or if, Sir, we are not criminal in your judgement, let your vertue appear in its full extent, do not confine it, generous Prince, within uch narrow and evere limits, let the Father tate part of that mercy your clemency confers upon the children, who humbly implore the life of Artaban, which I perceive your own compaionate, and noble oul prompts you to grant him; vouchafe it therefore, Sir, and bind a King by this immortal obligation, to endeavour by his faithful ervices hereafter, to tetifie he holds the poeion of it only by your extraordinary goodnes. And if you did believe he was able once to prejudice you, you may as well think him not altogether ueles by making him your friend. Take away all the ubjects of your apprehenions from him, place your Souldiers in Garrion in all the places of trength in Armenia, and only leave him and his children wherewith to erve you in their own perons, and to the Armenians (who love him too affectionately to uffer his los without reentment) the power to tetifie the obligation they hall o jutly owe you for their Princes life.

Cyrus preed betwixt the Amity he had for Tygranes, and the obedience he ow'd to Cyaxares, anwer'd him, that he took the gods for witnes, and wih'd they might punih him, if it were not a real truth, that he was as much griev'd for his misfortune,
as it was poible for a man to be, for one he o dearly cherihed, and that without thoe preing arguments he had alledged, the friendhip they had contracted together during their infancy, was but too powerful to obtain all that he could in reaon deire of him, but in this occaion, what he demanded, depending not upon his will, but the devoir of his charge, and birth; he beeeched him to accue his hard fate, and he hould evidently finde by the treatment which the ret of the Family hould receive at his hands, that what he was compel'd to now, was utterly againt the inclination he had to erve him.

He had no ooner ended thee Protetations, but, fore eeing that if he gave ear to their further complaints, which had already awaken'd his heart to pitty, he hould not be able to reit their clamorous petitions, he would have withdrawn himelf within his Tent, commanding thoe that held Artaban to conduct him where he had appointed, and Chryante to withdraw his prioners. But then their cryes and hreeks became mot vehement, and doleful; and Birinthea, who till then had only made her precious teares keep company with their fruitles prayers, broke through the croud which throng'd about Cyrus, and falling down at his knees which he embrac'd in her tender arms, he topt him with thee words: Do not fly, my Lord, nor tifle all the thoughts of mercy in your breat decide, before you go, whether the children hall follow their Fathers doom, or the Father partake of the childrens fortune: or rather, acrifice them all to
your jut anger to expiate Artabans crime, and reerve only him, ince the gods will not gratefully accept a victime that is not truly pure, and immaculate. And we being innocent, hall better atisfie their jutice than he can, becaue he is o guilty. Then toping her peech a while and finding he anwered not a word; Ha cruel, purued he, lifting up the vail which cover'd her face, and looking on him with a countenance whereon o many foot-teps of grief and orrow appear'd, as would have melted a heart of Bras into compaion, thou reply't nothing, and nevertheles the proffer I make is fair to glut thy cruelty, and if thou art o greedy after blood there is more plenty for thee in our youthful veins, than in his aged body parched through time and labour; peak cruel man, and if ever thou knew't what bleing a Father is, or hat the leat entiment of nature in thee, let that work ome ence of pitty in thy oul.

This lat aault could be no longer withtood, it was too powerful not to prevail, and therefore Cyrus yeilded up his everity to the tronger riings of compaion in his breat, Birinthea, had no ooner dicover'd her divine face, though it were bath'd in tears which bubbled from their chrytal prings, but he reented, beides the motions of pitty, all thoe other effects which uch an afflicted beauty can inpire in a mot generous and tender heart. He revok'd the order he had given Chryante concerning the peron of Artaban, and committed him together with his Wife and Children to Chryantes Guard, promiing
them to do his utmot to obtain his pardon from Cyaxares, to whom he immediately wrot for that purpoe.

When the Meenger, whom he had dipatched, return'd and brought him word, that he might abolutely dipoe of the life of Artaban, according as he pleas'd to think convenient, this news did o fill his mind with a particular joy, and he found himelf o puiantly intereed for Artabans preervation, ever ince Birinthea's mediation, that he would be himelf the bearer of it. He went to the place where they were yet detained prioners, where their divided fears and hopes held them in a trembling upence what would be the event concerning Artaban, whom at that preent moment they entertain'd in a converation compoed more of ighs, and tears, then words. His unexpected viit urpried them extreamly, and they were timorouly weighing in their thoughts the reaons of it, which he cleared to them, by declaring the caue thereof: This bleed news notwithtanding did not wipe off their tears, they wept for joy, as they had wept for grief, and in this firt tranport, whilt they tender'd him millions of thanks for his infinite goodnes, with all the ubmiive acknowledgement they were capable, Birinthea mov'd him no les by the reentment he witneed for this favour and grace, then he had done before, by thoe bitter reproaches of cruelty he charged him withall. He afterwards concluded the conditions of pardon, he vouchafed to Artaban, by which the King obliged himelf to pay yearly double
the tribute which Atiages had formerly impoed and to give up all the places of trength into Cyaxares hands, and voluntarily offer'd beides to furnih him, towards this War, with forty thouand Foot, and eight thouand Hore, and for ranome of his peron, and his wife, he intreated him to accept of all the treaure his Father had left him, which amounted to about three hundred talents: and eeing he had nothing left remaining to atisfie for his children, he claped his arms about Cyrus knees, the tears hanging at either eye, and told him he refer'd them to his own generoity, not being able to proffer any thing ele but the aurance to pay that debt, by the continual exercie of his daily ervices, and a plentiful acknowledgement of all his noble obligations.

This manner of expreion touched Cyrus in the mot enible part of his vertue, who could not have uppreed his generoity in things, for which he had les inclination, the Articles in fine were igned, and the Armenian King obtain'd, beides what he had handomely intreated, many choice favours which his hopes could not expect, on condition however that as an aurance of this treaty, the young Phraorte his Son, and his Daughter the Princes Birinthea, hould be ent into Media to remain as Hotages for their fidelity.

It would poe me to tell you whether Cyrus retain'd this Princes, for his Unckle Cyaxares interet, or his own inclination only, but this I am certain of, that after he had dryed up her tears, and recover'd the lutre of her beauteous face,
which thoe clouds of grief and orrow had dres'd in mourning weeds, he was firt contrained to admire thoe freher graces, and then to diget his admiration into this open acknowledgement that notwithtanding the everity of thoe doctrines he had learnt in the Accademies of Peria, which denyed a Conqueror to look upon his Captives with any other eyes than thoe of a Victor: yet it was impoible to behold o imperious a beauty and not efform rather entiments of ervitude and worhip, then of triumph and Empire. This declaration, nevertheles, paed only for an expreion of galantry, and perhaps himelf as then, believ'd it prung from his own mind on no other conideration. He invited the Royal Family that ame night to a umptuous Feat, and afterwards requeted the Prince Tygranes (amidt their other pleaing dicoure of former acquaintance to which Cyrus had engaged him with much affection) to relate the Hitory of his life ince the time they were eparated, from whence he now came when he was taken, and particularly in what alliance he had found o fair and vertuous a Princes as his wife, Tygranes atisfied his curioity to the full, and told him all the marvellous accidents which had hapned in their amours, which Cyrus heard with infinite delight, and perhaps you would find as much content in the recital did I not fear o prolixe a digreion would tyre you.

The Hircanian Prince Gobrias, and Merame having told him they hould rejoyce exceedingly to be made partakers of it, he was dipoing himelf
to tell it them, when perceiving Hypocratides walking in the next Alley, he propounded to hear it rather from his relation, as being one who alwayes had a great hare in Tygranes fortune, and who was more fully acquainted with each particularity.

They went joyntly to intreat him, and that Gentleman being glad of an occaion to entertain o noble a ociety, firt intreated them to excue him, that he was oblig'd to commence with the Hitory of Arthemia's Father and Brother, becaue it was abolutely neceary for the intelligence of the other, and then began after this manner.

div.head: The Hitory of Tygranes and Arthemia.
div.p: IF you were not already well aured by your own experiences and every days examples, that of all paions in the oul, love and hatred are the mot potent, the recital of this Hitory of Tygranes and Arthemia would be ufficient evidence to prove it.

This Princes is Daughter of Cteiphon Prince of Colchis, whoe Mother Laodice, five years after he had brought her into the world, was contrain'd to leave her by a malady, which uddenly natch'd her from her husband and pretty children Cteiphon was not very young, and nevertheles after he had worn out four years in widdow-hood which he thought were due to regret his dear wife, he took a reolution to marry. He
cat his looks for this purpoe on all his neighbour Princees to find ome object uitable to his condition; but whilt he was thus in quet, his unhappines met a woman, who under the bewitching appearance of a florid beauty, cover'd the poionous entiments of a mot vicious oul. It was the cruel Erixone, whoe lutful flames kindled that diention which hath caued o much misfortune to her Family: having ifted out his inclination, he knew o well how to gain that Prince by her affected flatteries, that in fine, he married her maugre all thoe reaons of State which oppos'd his affection, all which he trampled under foot. The blindnes of Cteiphon's love, and Erixone's ambition, forged this ominous match: but this unhappy woman loving nothing in his peron but the vain quality of Prince and Soveraign: being atisfied now with that, reolv'd unlawfully to eek elewhere for greater pleaure, than Cteiphon could feed her inatiate brutality withal; inpir'd with thee detetable thou his and deires, he hot her poionous glances at every one in whom he pied any lovelines; her apiring vanity oothing her with the fond belief, that none could posibly reit her piercing eye, when it was edg'd with o much pasion, nor refue the weeter correpondency with her temptations: yet fearing leat the unwary indicretion of ome, or the too reerved prudence of others hould unmaque her wanton deignes, he thought it mot ecure to ingle out one alone, and he could find none more deerving to be doated on then Theramene.

She was not mitaken in the judgement he made of the peron of that young Prince. He was then but eventeen years of age, his body, of an excellent hape, was but the habitation of a more noble oul, and any others pasion but Erixone's, would have challeng'd its excue from the catching charms of his brave qualities, but that infamous woman intead of conidering him as her own husbands Son, believ'd him the fi • tet peron with whom he might practice her incetuous projects mot afely, becaue Theramene was ever in her eye, and the familiarity which he ued towards him, perwaded her he might facilly convert the carrees of an indulgent Mother, into the trickter embraces of a dearer Mitris, and that he was not o green in experience, but he would oon dicern and approve of it. This pecious pretext was a long time the cover to diguie her pasion, and though he were mot ubtil in her behaviour, yet could he not make Theramene take notice of any thoughts beyond his Devoir. Not but that he dicover'd her elf apparently enough ometimes, as he related ince; but becaue the purity of his oul being incapable to let in o ungrateful and horrid affection, he could not upect o bae an ambuh then. Every one perceiv'd evidently that Erixone had a particular affection towards Theramene, even Cteiphon declar'd he was obliged to her for it: but never any could imagine her more then ordinary tendernes was the Pander to her abominable lut.

In fine, after the vain purute of a whole year, finding her itching deires could not be thus atisfied,
he conceiv'd as much violent hatred in the beginnings of her dipair, as he had cherihed love for him in her oul, he reolv'd to oppres the Princes vertue, if he could not corrupt it, and in the means he fought to ruine him, he found the atisfaction of thee two different paions which trugled in her bret, becaue he fixedly intended to throw off all diimulation and diguie, and break through the bahful laws of Scruple, and nice decency, by making a manifet declaration of her love, to which if Theramene gave a willing ear, and correpondency, hers hould be fully glutted in the fruition; and if he hould recoile by his too cold denials, he voted uch a deep revenge, that he hould ink under her enrag'd dipleaure, if he became not flexible to her more oft deires.

This Princes extraordinary civility furnihed her with frequent occaions to execute her ignoble deigns, there was not a day pas'd wherein he did not ee her, he reorted every morning to her Chamber as oon as decency permitted him a becoming entrance. One time above the ret Creiphon being omewhat indipoed, ent Theramene to give her the bon-jour, and communicate certain affairs to her, he made her maids and women retire, and though he were yet undres'd, led him to her Cloet under a pretence of telling him ome important ecret, and forbad any one to interrupt her. There was he aaulted with the everal paions of Love, and Hatred, Hope, and Dipair Confidence, and Fear, and after ome moments ilence, in which a buie eye might have
read her thoughts in her countenance, which though not truly undertood by the Prince, did omewhat raie his atonihment, and invite him to beg the knowledge of the trouble he perued in her face, (o often hifted from its natural weetnes, into betraying bluhes) he et two or three ighs at liberty, and darting her looks upon him fuller of Love, than Anger. Ha Prince, (aid he to him) What do you expect more! would you have a clearer evidence, or more apparent tetimonies of that which I have endeavoured o long time to reveal? are you alone inenible in the world? and nature that has enjewel'd you with all the exquiite qualities that can render a man admirable in a Soveraign degree, has he depriv'd you of all entiments of Love, as well to the perons of others, as your elf.

The Prince was o amazed with this dicoure, that he could not get his troubled thoughts to hape out any anwer, he heard indeed he mention'd the name of Love, but could not comprehend from whence this declaration proceeded, or why it was addres'd to him, and therefore they tood gazing a long time upon one another without pronouncing a illable, but he recovering her pirits again, went on thus. You are urprized methinks, as if it were news for Love to raign in a young heart, or that a woman as I am were capable to affect, and adore a man like you, have I now explained my elf and broken the Ice enough? do you now undertand my looks, and thoughts, or mut I bring more light yet to dicover o fair a flame? your ilence which cannot be in you a ign of tupidity, is it a mark and effect of the didain you have for me? am I too poor in beauty? or is my
Age too tale, and does your buy eye, urveying me from head to foot, meete o many defects in that hort travel as to ditate and light the correpondency I begg? Ha Madam, anwerd Theramene having recollected his diturbed fancy, is it to try, and ound me that you make this dicoure? yes certainly, you have too great • tock of eminent vertues to be capable of uch a criminal love, but tell me Madam, what is that grand micarriage, which has o falely perwaded you, I harbord any entiments o contrary to my devoir The repect I have ever rendred you, can that have betrayed my intention, and can my exces therein tetify any thing beyond what I doe owe you? jut heavens you know at leat the purity of my oule. Erixone interrupting the current of his dicoure told him, no Theramene you need not wander o far for tetimonies of that, there never was in you the leat parke of love for me, I have but too long watched to epie that, doe not complain of the exces of your eteem ince I reproach only your want of it, had that been but true in the mallet portion you could not have been o inenible, and you might well have judged that though I had not merited your affection for any handome quality in my elfe, yet I at leat deerv'd it as a retaliation for mine to you. Inenible, or ingrateful man, which of the two hall I reproach you of, hall I excue one, to accue of th'other, declare it Theramene, and acknowledge the verity of my paion from its exces,

The Prince, who could no longer find the leat haddow of doubt after he had uncloath'd her thoughts o nakedly, reply'd, Madam, I now
find that true which had been ever aid of love, if it be poible that you love me in uch a manner as you have expres'd your elf, the blindnes of that paion has o hood-winkt your ight and memory, that you have quite forgotten who I am, you do not remember, Madam, that I am Cteiphons on, that Cteiphon is your dearer husband, and you his lawful wife: this is enough, and this weighty conideration alone were ufficient to intruct you that I have been as little capable of ingratitude as inenibility on your behalf, ince I ought not to be uceptible of any love for you, as I mut needs beleeve you do but feigne towards me: but, Madam, it was unneceary to repreent you thee coniderations, to make you ee a fault of which urely you are no wayes guilty, 'tis only I am o by thoe unhappy upitions you have tarted, that I hould be o rahly inolent to hatch uch bae deires contrary to my duty, and repect; this declaration mut be only to try me, I hould wrong your vertue to beleeve otherwie, for you have too much judgement. Say too much love, reply'd he interrupting him, cruel; what then mut I give faith to it, aid he: what reaon anwerd he, hould make you doubt it; nay rather, reply'd he, what reaon would not condemne uch a beleefe, the opinion I have of your vertue, Madam, your devoir, and my own, doe not all thee forbid my boldet thoughts to let in the leat haddow of uch a upition; is this all, aid he, that thou cant oppoe, doe I trangres in my devoir by loving
you, ince the gods having created you o lovely, inpire me with a ecret paion towards thy peron, beids that which all the world is bound to cherih for their mot perfect works?

She topt her peech a while to fix her looks more tead fatly upon him, hoping by thoe hot glances to melt his frozen boome, at which he had o vainly knock'd for entrance with her alluring words, but finding the weetnes of her amorous beames had not that powerful influence he presum'd, and only excited more averion in him, he reum'd her peech again, and tuning her tongue to the recover'd gaiety of her miling countenance, aid to him in a cajoling accent; And wherefore would I not love you, ince the devoir and vertue you object are, but bugg bear Chymera's, which the bae jealouy of men invented? I being more forcibly oblig'd to obey that fatality which ordains me to love you, then their poor fancies; Cteiphon is not wrong'd in this, I love him enough to correpond with his affection, and how little o ere I have for him, young as I am, I doe but atisfy, too much the paion of an old decrepit man. Then 'tis in earnet, reply'd the Prince, & far from acknowledging your fault, you would couple acriledge to incet, and make the gods accomplices of your infidelity: ha doe you charme my Father with your fale carees but only to betray him; and are you o perfidious in your deigne as to deire his on, for your compagnon in the crime you have addres'd your elf unhappily Erixone, you'l mis your ayme, Theramene will act the duty of a
child better then you doe of a wife, and I could almot trangle thoe coniderations which tye my hands up from peedily revenging the affront you cat on Cteiphon, did I not cherih his honour more then you, my exaperated indignation hould immediately light on your head. He went out hatily after he had ended thee words, and though he indeavour'd to compoe his countenance, yet every one perceived his trouble and alteration.

Erixone deeper gall'd with hame for having been rejected then at the foulnes of her crime, follow'd him till with her eyes, and looked tedfatly on the door which let him out, when one of her maids whom he mot favour'd entred into the cloet, and found her yet in the ame poture as Theramene had left her; but with farr other entiments. Love had reign'd its throne to hatred with which intantly uggeted a thouand wayes to ruine him, of which her rage choe the mot bitter, but the mot expedient for her purpoe, intending to imploy the Father as an unhappy intrument to detroy his own on, as he before deign'd to make the child in againt his Fathers honor. She reolv'd to anticipate the complaints which Theramene might make, and the ame moment this came into her mind he left her cloet to prepare her elf to goe ta Cteiphon.

During the little portion of time he wated in dreing her elf, he conulted how he might mot cunningly prepoes her husbands mind: flattery and weetnes eem'd the mot catching, and deceitful, and o he having decreed that, and
being come in his preence before he could have time to note the trouble in her face, he prevented him by a mot earnet prayer whereby he deired him to grant her one favour.

The particulars which I hall now tel you, were dicover'd to me by one of my friends who was then preent, whom he was glad to have for witnes to publih her rare vertues, and the crime he fatned on Theramene. Cteiphon who was not accutomed to refue her any thing, nor could deny the leat of her deires, without informing himelf of the particulars of her requet, gave her a full aurance that having an abolure acendant over his will, he might afely promie her elf all that was poible for him to grant. The better to delude Cteiphon, he would not rely on his bare promies, he made him firt olemnly wear that he hould not pretend any reentment for a great injury which had been deign'd againt him, and that what he now deir'd with o much importunity was a full pardon for it. Thee words of injury and pardon atonih'd Cteiphon, he knew not where to fix his thoughts, but Erixone who had as much ubtilty as malice, having proteted by ome tokens of affection, which eemed to be interwoven with more truth then falhood, that her interets being ineparably united to his, he would never have deired the pardon of a fault, which were not excuable in its nature, and epecially in a peron whom of all the world mut be mot deare unto him, he thus prepar'd his pirit as he pleas'd, and told him the crime was
love, the mot venial of all ins, and the ubject Theramene that was guilty, who bet of all men deerved a free pardon, having imprudently uffer'd himelf to be urpris'd with that paion towards her: but the violence of it having contrained him to make an open declaration, he hoped that he had cured his ditemper by thoe remontrances he had made to him on that ubject.

Here he broke of her dicoure to ee what effects it wrought in Cteiphon's pirit, who could not keep in his anger. He loved Theramene indeed, but not o paionately as he did Erixone, the render goodnes which that woman had feigned towards his on, imploring his mercy for an act, which wounded him o mortally, touch'd him with the more fondnes towards her, and vehemence againt him, what, cry'd he Theramene is my greatet Enemy, and my only on? He, he alone will ravih from me my cheifet joy, you have too great a bounty, Madam, for o ignoble a peron: if this crime were pardonable, it would be o in any other but himelf, and if you truly love me, you will permit me to revoke the grace I had conceded at your petition, and hut my eyes on all the entiments of nature, for a on who tramples on them all towards his Father. What Theramene! Erixone who found it not o fitting to let him proceed any further at that time, topt him with her diembled tears, and gently weetned his avage fury with thee words. The gods know, Cteiphon, whether I love you, and without eeking other witnes you likewie know it your elf,
the exces of my affection is ufficiently evident in this occaion, eeing the infinite care I take to preerve your on. 'Tis that inpires me with thee deires for him, though I am far more enibly offended then if he had attempted againt my life, I acknowledge he does wrong you? but 'tis in my own peron, and you mut confes likewie the highet affront is given to my devoir & vertue: nevertheles, ir, if ever you had any eteem for me, and if there be the mallet roote of it remaining, vouchafe the pardon for a fault which he committed involuntarily, ince my unhappy beauty is the caue, and that it is a in of youth, rather then of his peron; and if you doe deny this favour, never expect any content again from Erixone, her griefe would be above the remedy of conolation, if after having caus'd unwittingly your on to love, he hould be likewie the occaion of his digrace, therefore if ere you purpoe to endear me, prevent this lat misfortune. Cteiphon demontrated that Erixone was more choice to him in all repects then Theramene, and as her interets was the chiefe ubject of his anger, her prayers in fine calmed his pirits, and he wrought him o pliable to her will, that he made him vow, he would never tetify any dipleaure unles Theramene hould impudently repeate his bae puruites, which if he offer'd, he promis'd him not to hinder his jut anger and revenge.

You may note in this occaion, that if ometimes jealouy has been more powerful then love, love in this did triumph over jealouy; he
did not intend to moother his reentments altogether, but only bridle their violence for a time. Erixone had o much way over her hubands paions, that he not only fully perwaded him to her mind, but having made him capable to be the miniter of her vengeance, he confirm'd him till the more in his fond beleef of her affection by the interet he diembled in the pardoning his dear on. Some mall time afterwards, which he had purpoely lipt over to hide her malice, having pent in her husbands wrath only to make it burt forth with the greater violence when he thought fitting, he judg'd it would not be convenient to defer it any longer, leat the Princes more evere vertue, who omitted to complain out of repect, being tirred with the importunity of new olicitations hould be forc'd to break his modet ilence, he declar'd to Cteiphon that not being any longer able to endure the daily inolencies of his on, he wih'd him to provide for the ecurity of her honour, and to abue him the more neatly, he councel'd him to imploy, if it were feeible, no other meanes but weetnes to reclaim him.

This unhappy Father whoe judgement was corrupted through his jealouy, and who from his ons countenance, that never could appear in Erixones preence, but with much change and alteration, had falely gues'd it to be an effect of love and not that noble indignation he conceived againt her, reolved to acrifice him to his paion, and ent the Captain of his guards for that purpoe to ceaze upon his peron, with
trickt command to ecure him in a Catle, a little ditant from the City, till he hould further determine how to dipoe of him.

I was with Theramene when they firt took him, that Prince having ever perfectly honor'd his Father, ubmitted without reitance to thoe who had the order to apprehend him, and not being able to imagine the caue of his retraint, told them aloud, that though he knew himelf to be purely innocent, he would freely follow them even to his own death, to atisfy his Father, towards whom perhaps he was too guilty, ince he was o unhappy, as to have given him caue to think o. I accompanied this poore Prince into the Prion, where his guards likewie kept me till they had order for my freedome; whilt I was with him, he communicated all that pas'd twixt himelf and Erixone to me, and not finding himelf fat all guilty of any thing, but the disdain of her bae lut, he knew he could incurr only the hatred his averion had bred in her, and could conceive no other reaon for his imprionment, but that he who had been o wicked, as to entertain o detetable a paion, taking a pique at his refual, had certainly accus'd him of ome horrid crime againt his Father; thee words bred new atonihment within me, for the opinion every one had lived in of Erixone's excelling vertues, eem'd to render this impoible; he had o craftily manag'd her affection, that none had ever dicover'd the leat park: but it was more impoible for Theramene to peak falely; I had a particular eteem for him, and the amity he
honour'd me withal as his Privado, and confident in his mot ecret actions, was capable to perwade me to any thing. After I had made ome hort reflexions on o trange an accident, and had proffer'd him all that depended on my bet ervices, on the aurance he was intirely poet of my Faith, he commanded me to ee Learchus the ame, that was preent, as I told you, when Erixone accued Theramene before his Father, and becaue he was intimate with Cteiphon, and that he alone was his chiefe counellor, he thought I might learne ome thing from him concerning his confinement.

Learchus was extremely my friend, an honet man, and one that had tetify'd as much affection as repect towards the Prince, I went immediately to viit him, and having poken omewhat of Theramene's imprionment, he proteted he was a tranger in the knowledge of it. The little atonihment however which appear'd in his words and actions, perwaded me that he was not altogether ignorant of the reaon; therefore I ifted him more narrowly, and conjured him at lat in the Princes name, to tell me what he knew. Learchus at this, looking earnetly upon me, anwer'd, he much admir'd the Prince doubted of the caue, and ought to learn it from others, becaue he could not beleeve that Cteiphon who loved him o tenderly would treate him o everely, unles he had mot urgent reaons for it, and that his own concience could better informe him, then any one beide. When I perceiv'd he pake o paringly, I
told him what Theramene upected, he anwer'd me, that there was more diguie then verity in that upition, and that if the Prince were not minded to conceale his thoughts, I might as he beleev'd eaily gues the ubject of his disfavour. Not being able in fine to dicover any further at that time, I made a faithful report of all he aid to Theramene, and Learchus was as ready in relating all what I had asked him for Cteiphon.

The Father blinded under the double vail of love and jealouy together, commanded Learchus to goe to the Prince, and reproach him how much his crime was offenive without adding this impudent diguie, and the effrontery to accue her, whoe innocency was fully enough vindicated, by the more then common care and goodnes he imploy'd to excue him. Learchus, peaking to Theramene on the behalf of Cteiphon, punctually dicharg'd the duty of a faithful ubject: his amity towards the Prince could not make him werve, and though it did imprint compaion for his misfortunes, his due obedience and the blacknes of the crime, of which he was accus'd, oblig'd him to repreent, with bitter reproaches, that guilt which mov'd him the more enib •• , becaue he was mot innocent of it.

The mall change it wrought upon the Prince; abated the edge of his everity, he reade the motions of jut anger upon his viage, and beheld the lineaments of perecuted vertue there, but not the leat character of a guilty concience, which uually imprints it elfs condemnation on
the face, and therefore he gave a very willing and patient eare to the dicoure he made in his own defence. And whether, or no, he were before perwaded of Theramenes fault, he now return'd in ome doubt of his innocency, and was moreover inclining to a full beleefe of it, if that imbecillity which o ordinarily prepoees men to credit the firt impreions, had not yet upended his opinion. The relation he made to Cteiphon found not the ame ucces, he rather would faten the crime upon his on, then his wife, and Learchus had no mall a doe to oppoe the reolution he had taken to put him intantly to death, by hewing him how neceary it was to have more certaine evidence, and tronger proofes.

Erixone who well fore-aw, that if he had the leaure to devet himelf of paion, and lure his reaon to her eate again, which now did wildly flutter, he would cent out her ecret projects, and turn the horrid tempet of revenge upon her head, mightily pres'd to have him punihed; Learchus defer'd it alwayes, and knew o wiely to interpoe the importance of uch a chatiement to Cteiphon, that he yeilded to the Princes friends, and epecially, to the Princes Arthemia's moving prayers, to have him confronted with Erixone.

To this effect they brought Theramene forth of his prion, who appear'd before his father, and thoe that were aembled there, with as much noble confidence, as Erixone did with trembling feare: this infamous wretch had woven her ubtill accuation
with o many oft expreions of love towards her husband; and the Prince haped his with uch becoming repects for his dear Father, that as I have already hinted, every one having o faire an opinion of both their vertues, would needs beleeve they were both innocent, and could not tell on whom to lay the guilt. The neceity hoever of deciding this controvery, divided their opinions, and as it is impoible our inclinations hould be balanced o equally, as not to weigh more towards one then another, either of them had partians, who did upect the others crime and defend their beleeved innocency.

Amongt thoe who more particularly interreed themelves, one Tarus embraced Erixone's caue, and Learchus tood for the Princes: the firt inited with more noie and heate, but the econd with more plenty of reaon, inomuch that the difficulty to give a certain judgement plung'd Cteiphon into uch trange perplexities, that according to the various motions of his trouble, he enibly touch'd the Peoples hearts with pitty. What aid he, have I ummoned you here to leave me in the labyrinth of a doubt, I thought your judgements would have oon unravil'd? And if we have no cleerer proofes of the crime and innocency, with what jutice can we chatice the one, and recompene the other? Cruell inquietudes, how am I involv'd what to judge of my wife, or on? Oh ad neceity which fatally ordains me to looe one or other, if heaven would needs find me an enemy, could it not with more jutice have cul'd out any others, but uch as owes me as much love, as I did cherih for them; but what hall we deliberate
in fine? Speake wife, reply my Son? to which of you am I become o hateful, which mut I looe of the two that are o infinitely deare unto me, and to whom I never wanted in my affection. The love I beare to her, makes him appeare as guilty; and when I turne my thoughts on him, he tands a criminal offendor in my eye? • ove? — Nature? Come hither joyntly to defend your rights. Nature thy plea, is firt, but love thine is more preing you, both ollicite with extreme earnetnes: but which mut I obey? The one moves with more tendernes, the other with more vehemency. Shall I bow to compaion? Or give the reines up to my raging anger? Oh gods? He gave paage to three or foure ighs, which top'd the further enlarging his complaints, viewing them both with lookes which beam'd with love and hatred together, whilt Theramene wholly interrupted him aying, Ceae deare Father, ceae thee cruel moanes that torment you, you may at the ame moment atisfy both your compaion and revenge, I am worthy of the one, but am not culpable of the other, and if nevertheles Erixone or Theramene mut perih to appeae you, never make it a doubt to which of thee you are to give the preheminence, though I am clearly innocent of the crime I am accus'd of, yet I will joyfully acrifice a life to your repoe, of which I hold the leae only from heaven, and you my, death may jutly expiate for Erixones crime, ince I am caue of it, and if the conideration of looing a child doe hinder, he is young enough to bring you many more, and perhaps you may never meete another woman that you could love with o much heate of paion.

Erixone would have poken likewie who during his dicoure had by her often hifted countenance given many infallible tokens of her crime, if any one had tudiouly perus'd it: but Cteiphon tarting up, much troubled, commanded the Officers to return with the Prince, and retir'd himelf to his Cloet, whence coming forth again, Erixone who attended him, threw her elf at his feet, and feigning a depair, fearing her life in danger, he ob'd forth thee words before a great number of people. Wherefore do you defer my death, my Lord, if you eteem me guilty? Is it becaue you know, that it would be a more welcome punihment than the upition you have of my infidelity: Yes my Lord, I have plainly dicern'd, that Theramene's artificial plea has gain'd more credit than my ingle vertue, 'tis fit you hould ruine a woman to preerve a Traytor, becaue he is your only Son and heir, I hall appeal no farther, but to give this lat aured and becoming tetimony of my love, I am reolv'd to dye for him, ince in the doubt you dwell, I can no longer be affected by you. Cteiphon would not uffer her to ay any more, but amorouly embracing and raiing her up, he reply'd thus: It is too true, Madam, that I offend your vertue extreamly by not punihing your fale accuer: but pardon a Fathers tendernes towards his Son. I wrong'd my elf mot in this cae, ince I oppos'd my own hottet deires, which makes me languih to deerve as great returns of love from you, as I cherih for you: the evidences which you give me of your affection, oblige me to a full retaliation, and are ufficient to aert the crime of that perfidious child, whoe udden chatiement hall atisfie your vertue, and my provoked anger. He told her a great
deal more, which we heard not, becaue he led her into an adjoyning Chamber, where he pent ome time alone with her.

There he reolv'd poor Theramene hould dye, but the mot ecretly that might be poible, to prevent the clamour, and commotions of the people, and ome Officers who dearly repected him. This black deign however could not be contrived o ecretly, but one might eaily ee it on wicked Erixones joyful face, which he endeavour'd notwithtanding to hide, by a diembled intermiive orrow for her Husbands trouble. Arthemia who watch'd inceantly to preerve her brother, was advertis'd ecretly by ome that Theramene had but a hort pace to live, and that it was high time to et all poible means a work to ave him.

She had dicover'd a clandetine intelligence betwixt Erixone and Tarus, which gave her much apprehenion, becaue he knew that man ambitious in the highet nature, and one capable of any michief. In this treight of neceity, he endeavour'd by everal tratagems to deliver her brother, he tryed to tempt his Keepers with the, eldome failing, power of Gold and Silver, and courted many people of worth and quality to teal him thence: but finding all thoe wayes block'd up with too much difficulty, and that it would but make him more guilty in his Fathers jealous mind to attempt ecape, he decreed to hazard one means, which he did honour me with, the knowledge of the performance, of which generous deign, he hew'd as much judgement, as affection and tendernes to Theramene.

Cteiphon the cloer to conceal his pernicious intentions againt his Son, treated him with les everity then he had done before, his friends had the liberty to viit him, and Arthemia feigning to go for ome dayes to a Country Houe, twenty Leagues ditant from the City, would take her farewell of him. The repect all gave her, facilitated her Noble deign: every one retyr'd when he came to the Prince, and then eeing her elf alone, he in a few words propounded the intention he had to change habits with him, that he might remain in his tead in the Prion, whilt he ecap'd in her diguie. Theramene being at firt urpriz'd with this propoition, would have offer'd ome coniderations on this enterprize, and epecially the perill he hould leave her under: but Arthemia not giving him the leaure to conult his prudence, quickly made him diroabe himelf, and dret him in her own cloaths. If their eparation had not been o udden, Theramene would have expres'd more fully to his dearet Siter, how much this rare effect of love obliged him: but finding himelf compell'd to be gone, after they had embrac'd with infinite affection, he quitted her, and paing through the midt of the two firt Courts of Guard, he acted her part and geture o handomly, that the Souldiers deluded by the perfect reemblance of his viage, which neverthelee he hid in part, and his hape and habit, thought him to be Arthemia.

He was already decended into the firt Court, and now thought he had no more to fear, when
looking towards the Gate he perceiv'd Sitalces coming, the Nepveu of Tarus, who in the Confrontation had pleaded for Erixone: This ight at firt amaz'd him, but quickly recovering and imboldning himelf, he hatned his pace to meet him under the Gate, which being more obcure he judged it would the better cover his diguie; yet he could not prevent Sitalces from abording him before he came to it, who epying him afar off, and thinking him to be the Princes, had imediately alighted, and came with more then ordinary peed to meet him. I am confident you are in as much impatience to know the uccee of this rencontre as Theramene was in fear, however he counterfeited as well as he could poibly the Princee Civility, and excuing his great hate, becaue it was very late, went with a winged diligence to his Siters Chariot, which waited at the Gate, without being dicover'd.

I attended near that Road by which the Princes went to the Catle, with a dozen of my intimate friends, about two miles ditant in a thick wood, where as oon as he arrived, not taying o long as to change his Cloaths, we mounted him on Hore-back, and wiftly gallop'd through many by-wayes to a little Town whereof I was Governour, reaching thither after midnight: And after we had there refrehed our Selves alittle while changing our Hores, we bent our coure towards Armenia, where we were received by Artaban and Tygranes his Son, with all the civil repect we could deire. But whilt Theramene is in ecurity, and puts the whole Court to their
wonder at his rare qualities, let us tep back alittle to Arthemia, and ee in what manner he receives Sitalces, who intantly demanded to ee the Prince, and whom he had dicovered out of her Window when he aborded her brother, not knowing what had pa'd ince. The fear which that doubt had thrown on her, taught her to end him word that being omewhat indipoed, and deiring to take alittle ret, there was no poibility of receiving a viit that day. Sitalces atisfied with that excue, without upecting any further, returned to Court again, with the newes of this feigned Malady: Erixone was preently Alarmed with it, and fearing this icknes might rob her of the Subject of her revenge, he went immediately to Cteiphon and olicited him to end to know the verity. The Meenger could not come to ee her, becaue She made as if She oundly lept, the longer to conceal her elf, and give her Brother the more cope to get away, o that after he had throughly informed himelf of thoe that waited uually on Theramene, he reported to Cteiphon that the Prince was taken ill, but ince the departure of Arthemia.

Erixone who was of an extraordinary malicious and ditrutful Spirit, began to entertain ome doubts, that the Princes indipoition was onely a pretence whereby to forge ome means for an ecape, which perhaps Arthemia or ome other had undertaken to manage for him. The abence of that Princes, mine and my friends together increas'd her Inquietudes and Conjectures, o that he reolv'd either to loe her
hopes of full revenge, or bring it to effect the night following. At the ame moment he ought out Cteiphon, and knew o well by preing dicoures, to repreent the likelihood of her upitions, and hide her own guilt of concience, that the unhappy father conented to put his Son to death before he hould have opportunity to perfect his Intended flight, which they believed was projected, and which the Subtil Erixone had urg'd would be her husbands ruine. Cteiphon gave warrant preently, and Tarus had the Commiion to provide Executioners, and ee it performed; the night was extreamly tenebrous, and I believe the Heavens had pread their blacket Sables to maque their ight from uch a horrid pectacle, and withall ecure Theramene in his Journey: when Athemia heard a rude knocking at her Chamber Door, where none had yet entered ince he diembled leep. This Inolence, and the ufficient time he thought he had procured her brother for his afety, made her fling open the Door immediately: When the Captain of the Guard advancing himelf, preented her a Letter, which contain'd the Sentence for Theramene to dye, ign'd with his Fathers own hand. She had no ooner read it, but ere that Officer could have the time to dicover her, he with a gallant Confidence ask'd for the Executioners which were appointed, and he that had brought the Order; When Tarus approached to make a bad excue, that againt the inclination he had to erve him, he was contrain'd to obey the Kings abolute command, who would needs by this Act
make a particular tryal of his Fidelity. Arthemia could not contain her elf any longer, but was confirmed in the Opinion he had conceived, that the cloe Intellegence this Wicked Fellow held with Erixone was an effect of Love and Inclination: I had reaon, Hang-man, aid he to him, to expect this Commiion ooner from thee then any other, 'tis this thou hat o long been hammering with Erixone, and ure enough thou hat promis'd Theramene's Head to that Lutful Adultree for an acknowledgement of her wanton Favours, but thanks to Heaven and their Jutice, thou art deceiv'd Tarus, thou halt not this day take away my Dearet Brothers Life: But if thy black Commiion extends to Arthemia, fulfill it Traytor, come Command thy cruel Miniters to Detroy me, I will not oppoe, provided I can but ave my Theramene; Here he dicovered her elf, and urprized all that were preent with that atonihment, which you may better guee then I dicribe. Tarus wrapt with amazement at this Accident, and the jut reproaches he aaulted him withal, retreated neakingly without a word, and preently gave information thereof to Cteiphon and Erixone, whom he found together; the one buried in adnes and dicontent for being obliged to murther a Son, the other netled with impatience to hear the certainty of his death, whoe life was o obnoxious to her. It eem'd that Cteiphon, though he were not yet penitent for his fault, hew'd no great ignes of dipleaure for his Childs ecape by Arthemia's aid, but keeping his wonted poture of deep Melancholy, he told Erixone he mut excue a Siters indulgent
affection towards her Brother, becaue it prung but from the root of Nature and Reaon: but that he mut expect the punihment of his crime would fall upon his head from Heaven it elf, ince 'twas not in their power, and he believed the gods reerved this vengeance to themelves to make it the more weighty, and exemplary.

Whilt this diconolate Father, after his trouble had made him chue his bed, began to think of tendernes towards his Children; Erixone's Sentiments flow'd from another Spring, her dipair made her ditracted with rage, he entertain'd no other deignes, but to acrifice all he could to her own afety, and to Authorize her firt crime by a greater, he wrote a Ticket to Tarus, by which he injoyn'd him to come to her, as oon as day appear'd, to ettle their affairs, it being no longer convenient to boggle or diemble, but to ecure their lives and their contentment, to the detruction and cot of all thoe that might oppoe them. The trouble and perplexity he was in, made her utterly forget the trickt order which Cteiphon, at her importunate Solicitation, had given that evening, to uffer none to go forth leat they hould ue ome means to top the Execution of his Son: o that it hapned to be intercepted, though he that carried it had Authorized his Meage with the name of Erixone, and it was immediately delivered to Cteiphon, according to the command impos'd on all the Officers. There was no need to rouze him from his leep, the wracking thoughts which were his bed-fellows
with their unquietnes had ever kept him waking, and when they preented the Ticket to him, the paions he had towards Erixone were newly entred in his mind. He was powerfully urpriz'd, finding uch ecret correpondence twixt her and Tarus, which he was ignorant of before: but prepoes'd with love and fondnes, he at firt imagin'd that he ummon'd him rather to aert her innocency, then to back her crime: but preently thee thoughts were houlder'd out again, to make way for the upitions, his jealouie began to inpire, and till morning was renew'd; he lay in a mot cruel agony of trouble, and then hatily aroe to peak with Erixone, who expected Tarus with a trange impatience.

I mut impoe a neceary ilence on my tongue, and intreat your Judgements to conceive how infinitely he was urpriz'd when Cteiphon entred her Chamber, and accoted her with this demand, What need She had of Tarus for her afety, and if he were not ufficient to protect her from any Enemy, what diorder he apprehended in her affairs, what buines he had conceal'd o ecretly, which the preent conjuncture obliged her no longer to diemble; in a word, who were thoe that durt have attempted againt her life? This dicoure o affrighted her, that being admonihed by her guilty concience, he wanted little of cating her elf at his feet, to upplicate for pardon of thoe crimes he thought he had dicovered: but being extreamly impudent, with the ame bold confidence he had undertaken them, he pleaded excue
for having been obliged to ask the councel of Tarus, whom he knew to be a man o faithful, and affectionate in his Princes Service, to defend her innocency openly, which was the more ubject to upition, becaue perecuted by his own Children, whoe interet he knew his own natural intinct would ooner incline him to vindicate then hers: and that it was not the care to ave her life that troubled her, but to maintain her honour, to prevent his unjut jealouie from charging her exceive love with blame, which he preerved o devoutly towards him. Cteiphon having anwered her diembled expreions of feigned affection with his more incere acknowledgements, returned thence, as fully perwaded and atisfied, as was poible with her dicoure, As oon as ere he had quitted the Chamber, Tarus arrived there, to whom he made ample relation of the ucces of that accident, which o much tartled him that he began to fear he would not have the reolution to perform what he had already projected.

In this apprehenion he courted and olicited him by all the probable coniderations, and epecially thoe of ambition and love, to conent to her deign; and in fine, perceiving he till waver'd, he repreented the danger and lat extremity of their affairs o preingly, that as dipair teeles the mot leaden courage, he engaged him in all her undertakings, and leat his blood hould coole, or his Spirit turn edge thorow long delay, he put him immediately to carry on the Plot, going to her Husband, jut when Arthemia
was come out of the Prion, to jutifie what he had acted to ave her Brothers Life. And ere he gave her leaure to take any notice, he highly prais'd her for the generous amity he had hown to Theramene, eteeming her elf unhappy the evere Laws of honour forbid her the like pitty, Arthemia who could no longer endure the perfidious hypocriy of that Woman, broke forth into bitter reproaches, and had undoubtedly convinc'd her, if Cteiphon who was offended they hould Characterize the peron he loved, o detetably infamous, had not impoed ilence, and told her, he hould be contented to have rob'd her Brother from his jut vengeance, without maintaining his crime o inolently: the obedience he ow'd her father, made her ilent, and Cteiphon having withdrawn himelf into his Cloet, he didainfully left Erixone, who would have entertain'd her, and whom this dicourteie precipitated to that horrid attempt he tudied againt Cteiphon, with the more eagernee and pite.

Of all the wayes he had bethought her elf for her cruel purpoe, the mot ecret eemed the mot facile Her inclination feeding her with the ad delight of michief, he had particularly bent her mind to know many experiments of poyon, and amongt the ecrets which you know thoe of Colchus are very curious to tudy; She found one which he thought mot fit to imploy in this deign, the virtue whereof was to make the peron mierably languih upon whom it was practiz'd, cating them after ome
time into a Lethargy pat cure. None could upect her in the leat to have caued that conumption which daily wated Cteiphon, the world attributing his malady to thoe dipleaures and misfortunes which invaded his Family.

In the mean time the news came, that Theramene was refugiated in Armenia, and Arthemia received Letters by an expree, who informed her that Artaban was ending Embaadours to her Father, either to clear the innocency of his Son, or to obtain the pardon for his offence if any were. Thee tidings did omewhat alleviate the affliction he was in for her Fathers indipoition, who every day enibly decay'd. Soon after the Armenian Ambaadours Arriv'd together with the Prince Tygranes, who would needs accompany them in peron the better to Sollicite for Theramenes favour and return, whoe eminent virtues had particularly acquired his Friendhip.
