Had not Cteiphon been in the extremity of danger for his life, their coming would abolutely have thrown the wicked Erixone into dipair: that unhappy Father began to regret the abence of his Son, and blame his own rah hat, that had condemned him without any other evidence then his own paionate anger, and his Wives interet, who knowing well that if he once return'd, her impotures would be unmasqu'd, and laid open to every eye, was preparing to impede his coming, or prevent it, when the poor Cteiphon by his death left her a power & fit opportunity to maintain that crime, and commit many freh ones.

Every one bemoan'd this los with igh's and tears, but Erixone did o far out-Act a Theatrical diimulation in her regret and mournings, that even Arthemia who perfectly knew her fale heart, and had her own Soul filled with the harpet grief, could not but be moved with it, and for a while doubted if it were poible that a woman could how o many ignes of deep affliction for a husband he had betray'd her elf o treacherouly, and whoe impudent deceit tretch'd o much further, as to intreat the Prince Tygranes and the Ambaadours, to haten Theramene's return withal convenient peed, whom he mot willingly pardon'd, that he might come and ettle himelf in his due Succeion, thereby to eae her of the cares and troubles of Governing the State, which he had took into her management only to keep things in good order till his Arrival: that afterwards in a more olitary retreat, he might have full cope adly to bewail, with becoming Tears and Sorrows, the los of that Dear Husband, who during Life, he loved with all the repect and tendernes that any woman is capable of.

Who ever could believe Treaon hould lurk under uch pecious howes; her Crocodile craft deluded the mot prudent and concern'd. The Ambaadours returned better atisfied from her, then they had been by Cteiphon, and Tygranes remained charm'd with Arthemia's excelling beauties, to whom he had already proteted the aurance of his Love and Services.

How be it when every thing eem'd to be
huh'd in peace, and all their troubles in Colchus buried with Cteiphon, Erixone who continually watched the iue of her projects, being inform'd the Prince was coming from Armenia, ent the choicet of the Country to receive him on the borders, whom Tygranes at her requet, and to oblige Arthemia accompanied with much State and Magnificence: But Oh gods what a Reception, what Entertainment was it, what Treaon more black, or detetable, then he now dip'd her hands in, could the mot cured intrument of malice ever have invented? The Young Prince who thought he was fairly invited to come and take the full poeion of his Inheritance, and that Erixone by a generous and incere repentance had wip'd out her grievous faults, had already drowned the remembrance of all his troubles in the Sea of promied hopes to enjoy a more tranquil Life, when the execrable rage which Erixone and Tarus had hatched againt him, burt forth. He thought of nothing les, and only tudied handomly to anwer the many Tetimonies of his Friends affections, and epecially Tygranes. Here, Hippocratides interrupted his Dicoure, and they were all oblig'd to put off the continuation till another opportunity, to meet Cyrus whom they aw coming towards them through another alley, with an action which had the face of much inquietude and anger.

They were not long without knowing the Caue, Cyrus as oon as he came near them, complained as if Artabae had contributed
omewhat towards his dicontent, becaue Cyaxares had given him that antient Prince his kinman as a pledge of their good intelligence, and faithful correpondence. Artabae aid he to him, Give me an Account of my ncles intentions, tell me pray what deignes had he when he put the word into my hands, and what reaon at preent, whilt he at eae enjoyes the Sweetnes and benefit of that Victory I purchas'd, to blat the Lawrels of my Triumph, and blemih the beauty of my Glory by the unhandome treatements, and ignoble purutes he practices to ravih the Honour of Tygranes Siter.

Write to him Artabae, that his paion miguides him, and makes him forget how I put Birinthea into his hands as a mot vertuous Princes, in quality of an hotage, and not as a lave, and that without infringing the repect I owe him, I will protect fair vertue, and punctually atisfie thoe promies I have worn, to anwer for her fitting entertainment where ever he be. And you, continued he, generous Prince, addreing his Speech to Tygranes: Suffer me to joyn my interets to yours, and leave me the care to preerve your Siters Honour, I hall have power enough, ince I have o much Jutice, and reaon to tame my ncles unruly paion; Yes aid he, Turning again to Artabae, I give all the Medes that will, free leave to returne, I hall not deire to with hold one here; Conduct them, Artabae, to their Prince, againt whoe paion I openly declare my elf an Enemy.

Artabae having proteted he would never forake him, complain'd at the ame time for the ill
opinion he had of him, in that he thought him o weak, as to abandon vertues caue, to embrace vices, as if he wanted judgment to ditinguih what obedience he owed to his Prince to whoe will he mut be indipenably ubject, onely o long as he maintain'd it reaonable. The Medes that waited upon Cyrus repeated the very ame, and they immediately went to the Camp, profeing by their houts and acclamations they would never leave him.

In the mean time Artabae who was ignorant of the Caue of Cyrus's anger, and patiently received his reproaches, was very Joyful to undertand it from a friend who had been in preence when the Meenger that Abracome had ent to Cyrus from Media related how Cyaxares tyr'd with his vain puruits, and Birinthea's contant virtue, was reolv'd to atisfie his beatly paion what ever hapned, and having already raied a doubtfull comment on Abracomes Journey to Cyrus, the further Intelligence of an old woman, whom he had placed as a wary pie over all her Actions, had made him abolutely jealous: and being confirmed in thoe fears and doubts, he had privately ent her into ome concealed place, which could not yet be dicovered.

When Artabae, whoe long experience had taught him much prudence, heard this News, he preently gues'd the importance of that quarrel this might beget betwixt the Uncle and his Nepveu, if the interet of their paions hould foment it, the one having the ubject of the injury in his power, and the other the means
to revenge it: therefore he dipatch'd a Meenger of his own with him that Cyrus ent back to Cyaxares, to inform him by divers coniderations of the many diorders that would inevitably follow, the unwarrantable rahnes of his affection, and the unhandome blemih it would cat upon his Nepveus victory and reputation.

Cyrus cruelly combated betwixt his love, for Birinthea, and choller at her imprionment, o conceal'd, was almot reolv'd under a diguie to goe and learne further concerning it, and if the uncertainty to find her had not top'd him, he had given up the advantage his word had already gain'd upon the Ayrians, to render the homages and ervice to his Princes which were ecretly vowed. He nevertheles, was ballanced a long time on the thoughts of going into Media, the letter from Birinthea preing him o earnetly, and beleeving his preence would have more influence then Abracomes: but when he was in ome manner fully reolved, the incertainty whether it were bet to goe ecretly to releae her, or openly declare himelf her Protector, or rather her lover upended him: he fear'd if he hould hide his peron with his paion, he could not become coniderable enough to perform any thing: and on the other hand, he apprehended to make too cleer a dicovery of his heart to that man, whoe bare upitions made him already jealous, and if he did reolve on either of thee wayes, then a new doubt tept in, whether he hould imploy perwaion, or power for her liberty, though he were confident, amity would never be able to
match his unckles love. In fine, pruning himelf with better hopes from Birintheas prudence, and noble vertue, then any expectation of what he might perform: he deign'd to march towards his Enemies, and divert his adnes by ome other actions againt the Ayrians (on whom he dicharged the effects of a mart anger) till he might heare ome gentler news of his Princes.

To this purpoe, he gave order next day for all his men to be in a readines to march, and being with-drawn together with the Hircanian Prince, and Gobrias on whoe experience he leaned very much, he inquir'd of many particulars concerning the country, that might advantage his deigne of breaking and hattering the Ayrian puiance, who eemed to refue to cope with him ever ince their firt defeate, indeavouring without open force or oppoition, to ruine and moulder away his army by idlenes, which in a trange Country does oft-times come to pas for want of action.

The Counell of thee two great men outweigh'd the generoity of his ambition which blindly prompted him to undertake every thing that eem'd to contribute to his glory, he joyn'd in opinion with them, to tempt the diviion of their forces by enticing away a great party of their men who erved the Ayrians only out of feare and contraint. The Hircanian Prince promis'd to gain the Sacques and Caducians, if they could find the way to approach but neere them, which was full of difficulty, becaue they were to cros a great part of Syria: but Gobrias levell'd
that hindrance, and aured Cyrus that Gadate who was principal Governor of mot part of the Country they were to pas by, would not at all molet them, being confident to draw him on their fide, knowing of a long time that he deired to avenge himelf on Vectorez, by whom he was inhumanely affronted, and this fit opportunity being preented, he nothing doubted, but that worthy Prince would gladly lay hold of it with as much courage as reentment, and that he freely proffer'd himelf to this purpoe to treate with him, but only one obtacle interpos'd, which would be a main rub in this negotiation, for which he aw no remedy but was very hazardous. Gadate was at that intant in Babylon, whoe gates were clos hut up and guarded, into which place it was no les difficult to end letters then men, beides that Cyrus could not well get into his Countries without paing his Army very neer that great City, which encloed the whole Ayrian power within her walls whoe numbers wel'd far above that of the Perians and Medes

Cyrus who could endure nothing, which oppos'd his valour, and took all for affronts that thwarted his deigns, made Gobrias know by many urgent coniderations, that what he reckoned as o many blocks in his way to conquer, were but teps which would the ooner raie him to his noble ends, the Ayrians having lock'd themelves within the bull-warks of that Citty, only out of principles of feare, and this would but augment it doubly, if he drew up o neere them; that their numbers were rather an argument to dipie
and light, then apprehend a danger from thence, becaue as amongt generous oldiers, the more their are of them, the greater is their confidence and courage, o likewie amongt degenerate Cowards, their multitudes does but augment their dread and terror, and he doubted not but their preent fright, would at his preence turn to a general confuion, when they beheld him before their gates, circled with that victorious Army that had already defeated them, when they were in the height of confidence and pride, and far more numerous, it being likely that the ick, and wounded ouldiers, and uch as yet wept the los of their dear friends in the lat battle, made up a greater number in Babylon, then thoe that were in a fit condition to make any coniderable alley upon them at that time, whereby to hinder the preent deigne and expedition.
div.trailer: The End of the Second Book.

div.head: Birinthea The Third Book.
div.p:
THe next morning at the firt birth of day he led his Army directly towards the province of Babylon, & arriv'd at the confines thereof, after four dayes march, & there having reerv'd thoe whom he judg'd to be the choicet, and mot faithful of his troopes to remain with himelf, he commanded the ret to ravage and coure the Country, and not give quarter to any that were found in arm's The poile which thee plunderers brought in was very coniderable, and after the Priets had made choice of what they eteemed mot precious for their gods, and that he had ditributed omewhat to the ouldiers, he betowed the remainder, with the conent, and in the name of the Army, freely upon Gobrias, in retaliation of that noble treatment
they had all received at his hands. He afterwards ranged his Army in Battalia, which he caued to march within ight of that proud City, towards which he dipatched a trumpetter with Gobrias; who being approached neer the walls, told an Officer whom the entinel had advertiz'd, that he came on the behalf of Cyrus to challenge Vectorez to a ingle combat, or if he deired rather to have a general one, the Perians and Medes would be ready to meet him in the next plain. This generous defy did not o much gall the Ayrian King, as the dipite of having it brought by a man that was borne his Subject, and to whom he was o inveterate an Enemy. He return'd him anwer by the advice of his cheif Counellors, whom he traightway-aembled for this purpoe, that concerning the propoition of a Combat, he was o urpris'd, that he found himelf not yet dipoed either to receive, or give it, till a moneth after, at which time he promied to atisfy Cyrus his deire, and that for his own particular, the mot enible dipleaure he felt was to have let Gobrias urvive one moment after Melzune.

Cyrus having heard this anwer, thought that his honour obliged him to give the Ayrians the leaure to be able to make his Victory the more compleat and glorious by a more vigorous reitance, and therefore drew off his Army: but not to let them rut in idlenes, he took a reolution to goe into Gadates Countrys, thereby to oblige him to come out and defend them, and by this meanes find ome opportunity to treate with
him. Gadate who was within Babylon, had no ooner intelligence of the Enemies march, but he traight went forth with thoe forces which he commanded, to oppoe Cyrus; which Gobrias having immediately undertood by his couts, he ent him a Gentleman of a try'd fidelity, who making a how of plundring the Country with ome few troopers, was willingly taken by the Ayrians, who conducted him into the preence of Gadate, by whom he was known to belong to Gobrias whoe intimate friend he was, and having received him very civilly, he inquir'd of his Maters health and affaires, upon which the Gentleman taking an occaion to peak with him in private, preented him a letter of Credence from Gobrias, and aured him by word of mouth of the protection which Cyrus proffer'd him againt Vectorez if he would quit his party, as he had abundant reaon to doe. This propoition preently awaken'd the deires Gadate had to revenge himelf of that Tyrant, and therefore without much conultation, he intantly reolv'd to end the Gentleman back ecretly, to certify Cyrus that he would uddenly come in to him: but not to give my body caue to upect their private intelligence, he craved only the time to dipoe of thoe things which might prove obtacles to his deigne, and in the interim it appeared very requiite to him that Cyrus hould draw neere, and make as if he would beiedge a place which he named, that o getting into it under a colour of relieving it, he might by ome mall alies dipute the delivering of the place, till uch time as he
hould find occaion to urrender it handomely into his poeion: as he very plauibly did after he had made a capitulation that was honorable, feigning that he yeilded out of neceity of proviions, to which they had reduced him. At his leaving of this City, he went to waite on Cyrus, before whom he protrated himelf according to the cutome of that Nation with the mot profound adorations.

If the repect wherewith Gadate aluted Cyrus were extraordinary, the civility that was return'd him was no les; he expres'd o much affability and honor by his carees, that Gadate was fully atisfied and comforted in finding o generous a Protector againt the Tyrant ectorez.

Cyrus after he had a while entertain'd him, was deirous to know the caue which could excue that infidelity and rebellion againt a Prince, whom nature and his birth had made to be his Soveraign. Gadate would have made the relation to him: but Cyrus intreated him to repoe himelf in a Tent, prepared for him after the toiles of his iege, whilt he would heare the tory from thoe of his ervants, who bet knew the ecrets of it. So Gadate taking his leave to retire, commanded his Equire to reheare all the particulars, who approaching neer Cyrus, began in this manner.

div.head: The Hitory of Gadate and Chryeide.
div.p: MY Mater upon les grounds then now he has, might very jutly have dipenc'd with the Obedience he owes Victorez, and you will quickly find, that he is too generous to have foraken that party, if that Tyrant had not contrained him by uch cruelty as is above all example, in not only denying his Subjects the Liberty of innocent actions: but even the mot becoming and Ligitimate deires as will appear by the following dicoure.

You may have remarked, that beides the advantages of his Birth and Condition, there are other very coniderable qualities in my Maters peron, which Nature has with a liberal hand betow'd upon him, which made him eteemed amongt all the Grandees in the Ayrian Court. He was epecially repected of all the Ladies in General: but amongt thoe whoe affection he had particularly acquir'd, he who was the mot pasionately in Love with him, was alo the mot unhappy. She was the Widdow of a great Lord, who had lived but five or ix moneths with her: but Young, and Handome if ever any were. The King Affected her above all the Ladies of the Court, and Chryeide, o was he named, who was prepoes'ed with the affection he had towards Gadate, generouly refued that which o many others eagerly ought to obtain with all the Arts they could.

Vectorez who was as much concerned for her didain as her beauty, firt ought all the means imaginable to make her read and undertand his paion: he imploy'd a thouand grateful pastimes to charm that god, who has nothing of Childihnes in him but his tature, and who in his littlenes may jutly vaunt he is the great Father, and Univeral caue of all things. But finding her entertainment very cold, and at a ditance, and having an opinion, that he hould rather be courted then denyed, he judged that what oppoed his contentment, mut needs be the conideration of ome rival, who had taken poeion of her heart and fancy. Thee thoughts prompted him to ordain pies to uncover that fair Ladies Actions: but what vigilancy or care o ere they ued, they could not lay hold of the leat conjecture of her Love; he having ever conceal'd it with great dicretion, believing it was not befitting the Reputation of a Woman, to anticipate Gadate by a too evident ign, or any Declaration that might leave the Print of her hame written in the bluhes of her Cheeks.

The King having lot a great deal of time without any hope of ucces to his content that way, imagin'd that to make her enible of the worth of his eteem for her, he mut feign it lot as towards her, and betow it upon one of her Neeces, whoe Name was Prinea, with whom he entertain'd a trickt League of Amity: that being moved with envy, and the didain he hould tetifie towards her, he might reent the los of his Affection, and endeavour to redeem his favour
again. This Plot might perhaps have taken effect had it been practized towards any other but Chryeide, becaue that fair Sex, to whom the highet repect is due, are the les able to uffer didain, by how much they challenge repect as a particular Tribute due to them. But it wrought no change in her, only in tead of receiving a enible dipleaure for having lot that Noble prey out of her toyles and chains, he manifeted how much his love was troubleome, and importunate to her that could by no means correpond in the ame terms with him again, though he were a peron to whom he ow'd the greatet repect and reverence of any in the World.

The ucces of this tratagem in fine betray'd the intention of Vectorez, and intead of ubduing the Will and Affections of Chryeide to him by this craft, he ingaged Prinea by thoe fale Tetimonies of love he acted to a mot violent paion for him, and this Bizarre event caus'd infinite diorder and trouble to him, for that his disimulation had produced a real love in the one, & his real love had not been powerful enough to gain a civil Correpondency from the other. This made him dipair, the other was importunate and clamorous, and that which added mot to his trouble was to have raied uch an Enemy againt her, he o dearly loved. Prinea knowing what a bar the remembrance of Chryeide was to her affection, beheld her as a rival who diputed her the Crown and Scepter: So that he perpetually watched to hinder Victorez
from Meeting and Conferring with her; who had not o well diembled, but ome flames of that Love he cherih'd, for Chryeide appeared thorow his fale maque: Inomuch that the unadvied Prince eem'd in this Act to become his own cruel Executioner: himelf having twited that fatal Cord of his own misfortune which even trangled his greatet hopes; for had not he feined Love to Prinea, he never had oppos'd or truggled o much againt his deires and content. He was many times in the mind to dicover his mind, end cat himelf at Chryeides feet to implore her pardon: but knowing her to be extream haughty, and Nobly Generous, the fear to reveal thoe poor unhandome Arts he had practied to vanquih her, which in all probability would but encreae her averion, hindred him for ome time: But as his hame did moderate and curb his impatience, o his Love pres'd and purr'd him with a mot trange violence. And he in fine was contrain'd to declare himelf openly; but not having o much reolution as to preent himelf before her, whom he had eemingly lighted, he rather choe to write a letter, in thee following expreions.

body.head: Victorez to Chryeide.
body.p:
Beauteous Chryfeide, I do not aske your pardon, before I aske your Punihment for a fault, which the excee of my Love might nevertheles excue, ince that alone is guilty: acknowledge it Chryfeide, you having given it Birth, and if the diguie
I have made ue of to cover it, have wronged your merit; do you ordain the punihment and atisfastion, being my Soveraign, and I hall have this one advantage at leat, that you will be obliged to recompence the pereverance, after you have chatized the Crime. Let not that which I feined towards Prinea, offend you Chryeide, thoe fale appearances betrayed the Sentiments of my Soul, and I have already uffer'd enough in the contraint I was engag'd to, rendring her the Tetimonies of an Affection which never were truly addres'd to any but your elf: but if you are not yet atisfied with my Repentance; I will preent my elf in peron before you, my Dear Princes, to receive from your fair Mouth the Punihment, you hall vouchafe to pronounce, and hope by that Submiion you hall find, that I am the mot real, and mot affectionate of all your laves.

div.p:
If Chryeide received this Letter with a great deal of wonder, not imagining the King thought now in the leat of Love to her, he read it with no les dipleaure, finding her elf again perecuted by one, from whoe importunate uite he blet her late hoped delivery. She ent him word, That it eem'd he relied very trongly upon her dicretion, ince he did not fear leat he might, Publih that Embay to Prinea, who alone received offence by his diimulation: if it were true he had fein'd Love to a peron, whoe Beauty merited a more true paion, and whoe ambition would hardly brook o great an affront;
that for her part he would never be wanting in her devoir, which was ever to bear a greater repect and veneration, then Love towards her Soveraign Prince.

This Anwer brought the amorous Vectorez into the opinion which flatter'd his pasion, he now thought Chryeide had been more civil then cruel, and that having perceiv'd the difference there is between the receiving the adorations or didain of her Soveraign, he had acknowledg'd her errour by that word of repect, which ought to be contrued in the mouth of a Subject, and a woman for an expresion of Love, which the mear modety of that ex forbids them to expres more plainly. He could give himelf no repoe or repit till he waited on her, to be confirmed in his flattering opinion: but the preence of Chryeide which he gues'd o favourable to his interpretation, quickly undeceived him. Not that he was wanting in what he had promied: for at his reception, he treated him as a King: but as oon as he laid by that Magitick Garb to aume the Peron of a Lover, he expres'd all that froideur and coynes, which is practized ordinarily by uch as have not the leat entiment or park of affection. Vectorez was mot enibly netled at this entertainment; and perceiving all his ubmiions and Cajolleries were fruitles, he proceeded to Menaces; and told her at parting, that ince he was better treated when he acted as King towards her, he would henceforth never change that quality, that o he might make ue of the power that preheminence gave him, to obtain that which he refued o proudly both
to his Prayers, and ubmisions.

Thee threats imprinted o much fear in Chryeide's heart, who was acquainted with Vectorez violent Nature if provoked, that he decreed abolutely to eek all poible means whereby he might decently make known her inclination to Gadate: that o obliging him by affection to joyne to her interets, he might be the more able to reit all that Vectorez could indeavour and deign againt her repoe and honour. Gadate who had all the Sentiments of a heart truly generous, quickly perceiving by the looks Chryeide ecretly level'd at him to invade his liberty, what it was he deired from him, would not dipute the Conquet much; but having eriouly conider'd the Merits and Virtue of that amiable Woman: betow'd all his affections on her as a peron whom he was bound to Love and Honour intirely.

On the other hand Prinea, whoe envious jealouie made her continually watch and tudy her ruine, that eemed to rob her of Vectorez heart, whoe fale-hood ince he forook her, had enibly affronted her Reputation, was the firt that dicover'd the affection which thee two Lovers would yet have clouded from the eye of the World, till uch time as they had etled their affairs in uch a poture as to out-bid all fear and oppoition when it were Publih'd. One day whilt he was complaining to the King of that Infidelity, he pretended he had committed againt her, and trove to lure him back to her deires again. She how'd him how hood-winkt
his paions were to dipie her that cherih'd him o tenderly, and to give his repect and cat away his love upon an ingrateful Woman who diregarded him, and from whom it was fruitles to expect any return of affection, becaue he had already made a gift of it to Gadate, who alo loved her mot paionately again.

This Intelligence was the Fire, and Stubble, and bellows which wholly inflamed the Rage and Jealouie that had o long been moothering in the Paionate Kings boome, and which his late viite to Chryeide had already begun to tir and awaken; he intreated Prinea to be the Miniter, as having a principal interet, to ruine and take away that obtacle to her felicity. And he engag'd that provided he would give him more certainty of this intrigue, that he would acknowledge her affection by a jut retaliation of his own, and the reentment of the Injury he would cat upon that ingrateful Creature that had lighted him. Vectorez might have ought long enough in vain amongt all thoe Friends, in whom he mot confided, before he could have met with a peron more careful and exact to perform this Commiion. She immediately learnt by one of Gadate's Servants whom he had bribed with money, the ordinary time when he every day ecretly left his Houe, and he was informed by a Chamber-Maid belonging to Chryeide, her acquaintance of old, that jut at that hour Gadate viited and waited on Chryeide in a private place, where they had the liberty of a free entertainment. This led her afterwards to
the knowledge of the party, to whom they both confided the ecrets which they wrote of their affection, and by whom they ent the paper Meages of their appointments, and as She narrowly watch'd his goings and comings betwixt thee lovers by her many truty pies: one day as he return'd from Chryeide, whither Gadate had dipatched him: She caus'd him to be ceazed on by ome unknown perons, who having earched his pockets, took away a note, by which he intreated him to come to one of her Aunts, where he would be infallibly that evening to meet him.

Vectorez whoe Jealouie had rendred him a mortal Enemy to Gadate, had no ooner knowledge of their Randez-vows, but he reolved to way-lay him himelf, with ome of his Confidents in a place, which he mut necearily pas, that by one blow he might rid himelf of the object of Chryeide's love, and his own vengeance by depriving him of life. He went very early to the place appointed, in a diguie; and ent ome unknown perons, who were very well acquainted with Gadates face, to py, when he entred, and take notice of his habit and peron: for fear leat at his return they hould faten upon ome other by mitake. Thee Scouts aw Chryeide go in and everal other people, without perceiving Gadate, whom one of his kindred had carried thither in her Coach, dres'd in a womans habit; they were yet expecting his coming, when Vectorez excited by his impatient jealouie went to them; and undertanding that they had not
een his Rival yet come by, he fixed his reolve to teal away Chryeide, or rather ravih her thence by force, if Gadate ecap'd his hands. During thee thoughts and deliberations, he taid till all the company came forth of that houe; and perceiving he could not dicover him, againt whoe life the Plot was framed, when Chryeide's Coach had advanc'd ome ditance from him, he preently made after and aaulted it. The Cries and Moans of thoe within the Coach, was all their defence, and though mot times thoe feeble Succours are altogether ineffectual: yet now they were o powerful and uccesful as to preerve them, by alarming Gadate who was not very far of. That Lover preently flew with peed at his Ladies firt doleful Summons, and prompted with the interet of that love, he had in her whom they would ravih from him, he fell upon one of thoe that econded the Kings violence, and having wrung the Sword out of his hand, he ran directly to the throng that had attaqu'd them, who not expecting from one that appear'd to be a Woman, any other reitance but noie and clamours were unawares diordered and amazed at his furious blows.

There Love on either part exercis'd its rage and fury. The King who had the greatet interet in this action, did firt oppoe Gadate: but wanting the aitance of Jutice in this quarrel, he began to give way to his rivals fury, whoe vigerous arme he had already felt: when thoe that accompanied him, leaving Chryeide to ave Vectorez, gave her opportunity to ecape from
them, and took away all means from Gadate to compleat his full revenge. Their number in fine, ore'whelm'd him, and after a brave reitance equal, both to his love and valour, whereby he had laid three at his feet, himelf unk down pierced with wounds amidt his Enemies, Vectorez was in o grand a confuion for this defeat, and o enfeebled by thoe wounds he had received, that not remembring or minding to dicover who this was, he left him in the Street, commanding them to convey away his men, and was himelf preently carried to his Palace, no les covered with blood then hame; and to hide it from all knowledge, he commanded his Phyitians and Chyrurgeons, to give for a pretence that he was not een abroad, that 'twas ome other indipoition which afflicted him, and forbad thoe who had aited him therein, ever to whiper the leat word of it to any other. You may gues with what diquiet he paed the ret of the night, his anger gave him lee repoe then his wounds, and his jealouie quickly uggeted to his thoughts, that the tutelary Demon which had robbed him of his Chryeide, mut auredly be Gadate: who the better to hide his amours, diguis'd himelf under the feined hape of a Woman.

Whilt he was wracked with thee upicions Chryeide, who notwithtanding her danger and fright could not goe far from him, but thorow feare of his diater had conceal'd her elf at the corner of the treet, to ee the event of the
combat returnd as oon as the noie was over to eek for him. The night was not o dark, but that at ome hort intervals the wind weeping the clowds with ome impetuoity left the face of Heaven o cleere and tarry, that by their charitable light, this unhappy lover oon found what he ought, for with o much feare and grief, and which nevertheles he expected, as now appear'd too true. He lay tretch'd upon the pavement clos by a doore towards which he had trail'd himelf, but the los of his blood and trength top'd him before he arriv'd there.

The cries which this woeful pectacle made her at firt direct towards heaven, which he with melting eyes petition'd for jutice againt the cruell aains, were loud enough to be heard in the loftiet tar Chamber of the gods above, who reerv'd the vengeance, urely, to be performed by the hands of Cyrus. Her obs interrupted thoe firt clamours, & letting fall her lookes upon the object of her miery, after he had ome moments fix'd them there, he oftly bow'd her head upon him, calling him with an accent compounded of love and orrow both together, Gadata, Gadate, aid he, my dearet life: and raiing her elf up a little, purued he or rather my dearer death, ince thou repliet nothing, thou art no longer to be counted amongt the living; but if it be true that thou hat loved me, can thy faire oule be gone and leave mine here? and wherefore mut I live ince I have lot him who alone inpir'd me, where is thy oule fled, my Gadate, can it be that which makes me live till: here
take it then again, aid he Kiing his lips affectionately, I breath it back into thee with all my heart.

She felt a little breath remaining in him, which the faint motion of his heart atteted, which made her toop to marke with more attention, whether it were truly ome mall remainder of life yet in him, or the lat knell of her expiring lover: but finding it continued till apparently, I heare thee, aid he, my deare oule, thou anweret me: but is it to take thy lat adieu, or to call me to follow thee? aying this, he oftly laid her trembling hand upon his heart, and finding it beat and throb a little; let us not die my Dear Gadata, ince I yet feel the motions of our oule within thy boome: live for my ake, unles you'l have me traightway die for yours. And having aid this, he perceiv'd her hand was bathed in blood: wherewith being again afrighted, he ought for that wound whence o much blood did iue.

But oh trange! he eem'd to hew, more trouble for this ame wound, then he had done whilt he beleeved him dead, and tearing the linnen he had on her head, he made a hift to top the blood from flowing, whilt with her teares that wah'd and bath'd his face, he trove to call him from his woun'd to life again: but finding her indeavours all in vain, he ent her careful looks abroad to find ome other aitance: when intantly a man preenting himelf, told her, that being moved with her doleful cries, he came to lend her all the ervice he was able, and asking the caue of that funetuous accident? he briefly related the truth of that ad
tory, and then beeeched him, by all that was mot deare to him on earth, to help her carry her deare Gadate intantly to ome neer place, who without peedy remedy would breath his lat. The man whom he believed heaven it elf had ent to her aitance profeing olemnly he hared in her griefes, toop'd down as 'twere to helpe her take him up, when uddenly the barbarous vilain, intead of performing that charitable office, unheath'd a dagger and indeavour'd to plunge it into Gadates heart.

The unhappy blow was o much the more cruel to Chryeide, becaue it deluded the hopes he had joyfully conceived of his timely aitance: yet he immediately flew at him, and being tranported with a kind of fury, cryed aloud, Traitor, thou hat mitaken, if thou wouldt murther Gadate, trike my bret for here his oule is houed, and he does live in me; but thou hat now kill'd only me infernall Monter, in his peron. Love had lent o much trength to Chryeide, and this jut reproach truck o much terror into that bae butchers heart, that he had force enough to tay him, though he mainly truggled to cape out of her hands, till thoe that had bafore fled from the danger, ent ome armed men thither to recue her, who finding her triving with this aain, oon ended that unequal combat, by killing her Enemy. His death contributed very much to Gadates life; Chryeide was no ooner delivered from that Traitor, but he hatily ran to him, and perceiving that he lived yet, and that the lat wound he received was not o dangerous as her feares had
made her doubt, finding her elf too weake, to carry that deare burden alone, which nevertheles he eagerly coveted to doe: he admitted of their aitance that were preent to beare him thence: till the coach he had ent for, met them; in which they laid him, repoing his head upon her panting bret. Whilt they were thus going, as if Gadate had been in a condition to anwer her: he entertain'd him, with what her love, ometimes trembling for feare, and othertimes flattering with hope, did ugget to her thoughts; and being at lat arriv'd at his own dwelling, he would not leave him till the Chirurgians had given her a confident aurance of his recovery, and that himelf having happily recover'd his pirits and knowledge again, earnetly conjured her to goe and repoe her elf.

In the interim, the King full of impatience that he aw no return of the party he had ent to dipatch the poor Gadate if he were yet alive, ecretly commanded another to goe and make a dicovery what had pas'd, who brought him word how he found him dead on the pavement. What ever plaints and moanes the mart of his wounds tore from his mouth & bret, his jealouy and paion troubled him more when he undertood that he whoe valour had carried the prize of Chryeide from his weaker arme, and whom he gues'd auredly to be Gadate, had yet ecap'd. what Demon, cry'd he; for there can be no men o bold and temerary, hath fetch'd away my Enemy, and travering my intentions, hath lain my faithful Miniters? Gods, doe you create
Kings to make them o unhappy, and doe you grant them o much power, to have o little ue, and command of it, when they have need to imploy it. Take back the Crown which you have placed on my head, I will not hold the Scepter: if that be the bar which eparates me from Chryeides love, the advantage of waying it; bringing the more confuion, by the hame for not being puiant enough to ubdue the pirit of a woman, to the ame compliance which he yeilds to one that's but my ubject. How unjut you are, all the power you give me, is it but only to commit murthers and aainations? and the abolute dominion I have over the lives of men, might it not better have been limited only, to reach the wills of thoe that are my vaals? Or had you but econded that violence I undertook by the authority I hold from heaven, which is to have no other law but my own will; I hould acquiece in your decrees: but to deride and better coff at me, or rather in truth, to bring contempt and corne upon your elves, ince I am your own Image here beneath, you bring a woman in the lits whom I cannot overcome, and if you end a man in for her econd, he too mut be diguis'd under the habit of that timerous ex. But no, I wrongfully complain of you; the irregularity of my paion does abue me; let us make open triall of that Soveraignty is given us, that, that alone can be effectual: ince oothings and deceits have proved vain; let Chryeide be intantly ent for, and what reitance oere he make, let her be brought whether he
condicend or not. Some of thoe that were preent in his Chamber, were already putting themelves in a poture to obey him, whom he again top'd by thee words: Stay, aid he, I doe not think on what I undertake: if there were only Chryeide with Gadate to reit me, my paion might be quickly atisfied: but I have love to conquer; nor have I any caue at all of hame, if the highet gods having bowed to his yoake, I alo yeild to his inevitable doome. However let's try to travere his intents in all that can be poible, and have no more repect to that divinity at all that ues o much cruelty.

His Phyitians and Chyrurgians perceiving him much heated with thee boome contets, beeeched him to calme his thoughts a little, leat it hould caue ome inflammation in his wounds, which otherwie were out of the reach of death and danger. He could hardly contain himelf: but reflecting afterwards upon the deign he had propos'd to hide his paion, he quarrel'd with his own rah tongue, for having proclaim'd o much, and trictly enjoyned thoe that overheard-him, never to impart thoe ecrets.

They all oberved this command o religiouly, that none could imagine for what reaon ectorez would not be eene, nor upect him to have conorted in the rape of Chryeide, and the foule attempt againt Gadates life. What ever informations they could make were lot labours; and it would be lock'd up in ilent ecrey till, if he who it rather eem'd had mot caue to cover it ince he had managed all the bloody tragedy, had not reveal'd it firt. Prinea having heard no
news from the King, who had through neglect wholly forgotten her, but only as an intrument that had caus'd his hame and unhappines, and having certain intelligence that ectorez had a full intent to have tollen away Chryeide, was even pin'd to death with grief when he remembred that her elf had procured that happy occaion, as he judg'd it, for her rival; and beginning to hake off the fond opinion of the Kings affection to her, he thought it would be the more compleat revenge for his disdain, and falehood, by rendring him the more hateful to her whoe love he hunted for through o much trouble and danger. And that to this purpoe it would be bet to let Chryeide and Gadate be acquainted that 'twas ectorez who had attempted the rape of the one, and murther of the other; and at the firt viite he made her couin, he revealed the whole ecret to her.

Though Chryeide were truck with amazement, yet he was eaily induced to beleeve it, becaue he was no tranger to the Kings violence and paion; and knowing it was now too late to conceale her affection to Gadate, and his reciprocally to her again, he gave him immediate notice thereof. Gadate who was extremely generous, could hardly beleeve the deign of o black a deed could be hatch'd in the mind of uch a man, who was borne a Prince, and to whom the gods had given o much Authority, only that he might doe jutice to his ubjects. The notice however they had taken of the villain that was lat kill'd, who was well known to be one of the Kings Officers,
before they had carried him thence, was a trong argument of this truth, beides many other particularities which he told him, to which he had not till then lent any obervation, or beleefe.

ectorez notwithtanding to take away all upition, and wipe out all thoe impreions that Chryeide might tamp in his mind, ent to viit him, and let him know, that if he had not been contrain'd to confine himelf to his Chamber, by reaon of a light indipoition, which hindred him from going abroad, he would have come in peron to witnes his orrow for that accident, intreating him only to be careful of his recovery, whilt himelf would take care to eek out his Enemies, to make an exemplary Jutice by which it hould appear that they had mortally offended him in his peron.

To combat thee malitious impotures, Chryeide was forc'd to dicover the ecret of the Kings paion, towards her, to Gadate in that exces which he as yet had not imagin'd, and the tetimony and Seals his letter contain'd which he imparted to him, and what Prinea had related as a farther proof in this point.

The certain knowledge of uch a puiant rival began to diquiet his oul, and would have wholly dicompos'd his mind, if that faire Creature who oon read it by the alterations in his face, had not quickly dipel'd the tempet which his jealouy was gathering, by thee Words; Feare not Gadate, you have no caue to feare, I know what the adnes of your lookes expres, but let not the highet proofes of his love I have revealed, raie any
doubts. If this puiant rival whom you dread, have found no greater obtacle to his love then the dipoitions I had towards you, when by his repects and adorations he endeavour'd to alure my oule to himelf: What can you apprehend now ince he has affronted and wronged me o baely, and that the inclination I had for your deare elf is converted into love: but what love Gadate, alas hall I dare name it, you know it enough already, and the lat evidence I have given you cannot but place your beleef above all doubts, if there were roome for any. What greater proofes can you demand, Speake Gadate, mut I die to gain your full beleefe: Ah, what was there wanting, tell me prethee, did I not eek for death, when I durt cope with him that came to quench that mall remaining parke of life in the treames of your own blood.

I know indeed, reply'd Gadate, that I have nothing to feare, ince you forbid it, But, Madam, I have neither Crown, nor Scepter to reward your affection, nor with my peron can you epoue any thing, but the hatred of a King, who now can make you a worthy Queen. The regret that you hould looe thoe advantages in conideration of me, and that I am not able to recompence that los, but by the Grandeur of an affection, which truly has no paralel (but which nevertheles can procure you nothing ele uitable to it) is that which cats me into o much trouble. That Chryeide hould refue Uectorez, to embrace Gadate, put by a King, to entertain a Subject; is a Prodigy of grace and goodnes which hould urpas, the hopes of ambition it elf, notwithtanding my Deare Chryeide, thee are not only things which I may fondly hope for; but uch as your aurance
crownes me with Mot rare effect of love, but yet produced by a caue more rare: Adorable Chryeide, at leat permit me as an earnet of my affection, to avenge the bae attempt of that ignoble King, you have les reaon to endure the affront he would have acted, then to refue the Crown he protrates at your feet by this meanes you hall no longer have that loathome object of your batred in your Eye, nor I have further caue of any apprehenion. Chryeide would not uffer him to goe on, but aboluttly forbad him to expres any reentment towards the King, who eem'd to repent his crime, ince he confes'd his hame by hiding it. They afterwards vow'd an eternal love, to which they call'd the gods for witnes, and reolv'd to ecure their felicity at oonet by a peedy marriage.

At the ame time that they propounded to roote and etablih their content, ectorez tudied to undermine it. As oon as he was cured of his wounds, he went to viit Gadate, and repeated over to him peronally what he had formerly ent him word off. The Kings anity troubled thee lovers happines, Chryeide eldome aw Gadate; and the feare leat ectorez hould renew his love together with his ineparable jealouy, made her not viit him, but with much caution and ecrecy, till he was able to goe abroad, and viit her himelf, without openly declaring himelf her lover.

ectorez being faithfuly advertis'd of thee enterviews, became o jealous, that not able to uffer another to enjoy that fulnes of happy repoe, which he could by no meanes tate, he reolved to eparate thee two lovers, before they
could have the bleed opportunity to tye themelves cloer by the indioluble and holy knot of marriage which he apprehended above all things, and which he nevertheles foreaw would be inevitable, unles he hatily cat in ome impediment to obtruct it. As he was forecating this ugly deign, a fit occaion preented it elf to him to put in execution; the inhabitants of a remote Province did inolently raie a mutiny; and it being neceary to elect ome peron of eminency and Authority, as well as of ability and courage, to quell thee editious pirits and range, them to their jut Devoir, his jealouy eaily uggeted him intantly to impoe this Commiion on Gadate, thereby to natch him away and part him from Chryeide. He propounded it to his Councel, who oon approved his choice, as the fittet peron of his Court; and not conidering the particular interets that lead him to it, immediately dipatched all the orders requir'd towards this expedition.

This buines did indeed call for a diligent dipoing of affairs: but yet the jealous impatiency that nettled ectorez made him precipitate that departure the more uddenly; o that his rival had carcely time, to et his own dometick buines in order, becaue the King feigned to have received freh intelligence, that without a very quick remedy, that fire of rebellion which kindled more and more, might perhaps uddenly enflame his neighbouring Provinces.

Gadate plainly perceived what poted him from Babylon, and that his deare, Deare Chryeide who
made him part with o much trouble and unwillingnes, was the ole caue; yet he was forc'd to yeild to Soveraign command, and obey the Kings abolute power without delay, leat he hould utterly ruine his hopes and future fortunes.

The evening before his departure, he waited on his Chryeide: where though thee two faithful friends had very much to ay to each other, yet were they o overwhelm'd with grief, that for a long time, they could demand no other expreions but mournful ighes and teares: but when they perceiv'd the fatal moment of their eparation approached, Gadate in fine broke ilence with thee words. We mut part, fair Chryeide; 'tis heavens decree, as well as the Kings will: but what mut we expect in o long and tedious an abence, if we find o much trouble only to ay adieu? A love reply'd Chryeide, which hall never untye the union of our ouls, whatever fortune plot or contrive againt us; love me till Gadate, but as I hall, and doe, love you; and we hall thus triumph over all oppoition, and make them know, our contancy and promis'd Faith, is firmer rooted and founded, then their obtinate and unhandome malice.

That I hould love you for ever reparted Gadate, is to command me a thing from which I cannot poibly decline, ince no object can ever poibly be o lovely as Chryeide, as nothing can be o pleaing and charming as the weet, and, too orrowful remembrance of your preence. Gods, who know future events, and can read all our actions, 'ere we conceive them, or write them in our intentions, trike me with
thunder immediately, rather then uffer me to be fale to her: but no you hall never chatie me for that crime, what power oere you have over us, for ince you cannot hape a beauty more glorious, nor furnih a oul with more perfection, he hall be eternally the only object of my affection and veneration. Yet I mut leave you dearet Chryeide; to pleae the jealous humour of a rival who teares me from you, rather then for that interet of State which is pretended, I mut be my own Enemy by this elf banihment, to humour him, and under the pretence of erving my King and Country abandon you, to the danger of a Tyrant. But let it be o, I mut away, and I leave all to your undaunted contancy; which I dare rely upon, though I foreee what tryals there will be to undermine and hake it; and remember, bet of Ladies, that having promis'd me your intire love, if you now faulter in your faithful reolve, you tain your own white oul, and pot that innocency that yet is cleerer then the unoiled Lilly. But you will never in o highly againt your own celebrated vertue; is it not true Madam? the very thoughts I have dres'd in thee words, a • e th • refore criminal; and I goe from you with th • conolation, and aurance, that whatoever ditance parts our bodies, yet our ouls will ever dwell together, and you continue mine, as ineparably, and as long as I am yours; that to ay to all Eternity, reply'd he, and more, aid Gadate, if it were posible.

A deep and violent igh on either ide, ended this ad dicoure; and they had no more power of peech left after it, but only to give a Melancholly farewel at the lat. Gadate at parting left her his picture, and in a noble Exchange was
inrich'd with hers. If the trouble, and dipleaure of this cruel eparation, diturbed them of that repoe, which leep might otherwie have afforded them: the joy that flowd in ectorez mind, did the ame to him. The pleaing thought of having procur'd their parting kept him till waking; and the impatience of eeing him, though night were almot neere its end, o wrack'd him, that he accued the Sun of loth and lazines, for not driving away the clowds of darknes ooner and appearing in that Horizon, to uher in the long'd for morning, that hould abent his rival.

Hardly was the night dimit, but he ent Gadate word he mut conult with him; not that he had any new buines; but only he thereby meant to rob him of the opportunity of being with Chryeide; and when he was come, he entertained him with a thouand diembled carees and civilities: even till the houre of his departure, and then would ee him mounted and conducted out of the Palace Gates, after which he immediately deired an Aembly of all the Court Ladies, where Chryeide could not but appear.

What diorder and torments, good heaven, did he not uffer, when he beheld him neer, that had abented her choicet friend o far from her? however he diembled the bet he could, not to irritate him, from whom he had already receiv'd uch tetimony of anger and Tyranny, and of whom he feared wore: But to hun his importunities for the time to come, he reolv'd to
banih her elf from the City, and intreated one of her kindred to pitty her misfortunes, and by carrying her into a remote dwelling, where her husband was in the Country to free her from one part of thoe troubles that fit o heavy on her pirit. ectorez, who was informed of her intent immediately ummon'd that ladies husband to the Court; and having taken away the pretence of Chryeides journey, detained her in Babylon; and to engage her the more to that abode, he betowd an office at Court on the Unckle he ojourned with, which tyed and confined her conequently within his own walls. But finding his mot edulous endeavours could gain him no advantage upon her inflexible Spirit, and that whatever art he ued to conquer her, he countermined and made hift to defeate his expectations, he was fired with rage and anger; and having found out that thee two lovers kept a diligent correpondency by paper Embaies, he bethought himelf of a Stratagem, to breed a disaffection in their hearts, by the ame meanes that they made ue of to confirm and cherih the affection they had o olemnly vow'd each other. To this effect he ought to corrupt the fidelity of of a woman to whom Chryeide and Gadate confided the weet commerce of their amours; and having gained her by the brightnes of that glorious mettle, which corrupts the integrity of mot people, he deliver'd up thoe letters which they interchangeably ent to one another, in whoe innocent lines, he quickly read the reolution which Chryeide had taken to fly to my Mater, for
Sanctuary, againt his Perecutions, and injoy that ret in his boome, he did in vain expect from the others retles importunity. He caued Gadates hand to be exactly counterfeited in a Letter, wherein he intreated her not to pur on her deigne with o much hat, and this he cloed up with a Seal of theirs, left in their unworthy She-Secretari's hands, to make this fale Coyn pas the better by that currant tamp. It need not beget your wonder, that Chryeide did not dicover this forgery, Lovers read over their welcome Letters with too much hat and paionate interet to examine o nicely; She, in fine, returned him Anwer, that She waited for his appointment with an impatience, great as her Love.

And to delude Gadate, as they had Chryeide: he caued her writing to be perfectly well imitated, and informing him, that being necearily detain'd at Court for omewhat, that much concern'd their happines: he beeeched him to let her defer her Journey yet a while, that o he might contrive to do it afterwards with the more afety, and les trouble. Thus was the fair intentions of thee two lovers betray'd and frutrated, with as much malice as dexterity; and though Vectorez had more of anger and rage, then love in the paion he cherih'd for Chryeide, yet could he not endure he hould have the leat inclination for any ele. And to make the mot advantage every way of their abence, he gained uch of eithers Friends, as they mot confidently relied upon, whom having once educed, he caued a report to be blown about, that he was
going to have Chryeide match'd to one of his Kindred; and at the ame time, in retribution of my Maters eminent Services, that he would betow upon him the Daughter of a Prince, who reided in that Province, which his late approved Valour and Prudence had happily ranged and etled in the obedience they jutly owed their King.

Thee perecuted Lovers were firt advertiz'd of the odd report that had been raied; and oon after their fale Friends confirmed this faler ame, by their infamous Meages, and withall added, that the hort and feeble reitance that either had made to the firt aault and propoition of renouncing their firt Love, to let in a new guet, which hould be confirmed by udden Marriage, proved evidently that they had given a full aent. This News being convey'd to both, by uch as they highly repected, and heartily believed, made up the fulnes of that trouble, which their long abence had but begun; and as the hopes of either was anchor'd, only upon their mutually worn Faith and Stability, o the newborn jealouie this treachery had brought forth, cat them almot into dipair.

What, — whipred the mournful Chryeide, — Is it poible that Gadate hould prove unfaithful; that Gadate whom a few dayes ince my Love, recued from that death which his Rival was dragging him to. Gods, if you be jut, why do you not how it on this Traytor; where is your Thunder? or for whom do you keep it that can o highly deerve it? ince your elves are witnee of the faith he vowed to me: But no, top yet
a while your avenging hands; upend the effects of your Jutice, perhaps it is not true that he betrayes me, and I may wih your Judgements hould fall on him, who keeps as much Love for me till as I can have deires. Rather trike him that is the Author of my doubts, and upition: Has not that Tyrant yet exaperated your anger long enough to make you dart your Punihments at him? Or may he, becaue a King, ecape unpunihed by Heaven, for thoe black and deep crimes he commits upon Earth? 'Tis he, nworthy he, that certainly till perecutes our harmles Souls, he without peradventure tempts my Gadates faith, with the ame pecious propoition of an advantagious Marriage, as he does mine: But it's no matter, for if that Noble Object of my affection be but truly mine, as he o willingly and olemnly engag'd, o long as I continue inviolably his, he till loves his potles Chryeide, ince contant Chryeide adores Gadate, nor will his Courage and dicretion looe that Victory, which he dare promie hall til triumph over the cured Vectorez's malice and darket Plots.

About the ame time, that this Unfortunate Lady was bemoaning her hard fate, Gadate being aaulted with no les inquietudes, becaue he had no les tendernes and repect for her, expres'd his bitter orrows thus. Whether the beautious Chryeide continue me her incere Love, or not, Said he, (ighing with a profound adnes) Her Infidelity would not excue my breach of promie; and if it be a Truth they write me, yet that Fair-fale-one, deceiving me, deceives her elf far more, it being les evil to be unfortunate then Criminal. But I mut love her till, my heart, aid he, (knocking his hand on his
bret) though he prove incontant: for the Tetimonies he gave me of that excellent affection, which he however proteted to Eternize, proceeding from o divine a peron, are a ufficient Obligation for me not to ceae to Love her, till I ceae to Live; and though he be faithles, yet is he the happiet coppy of Angelick beauty to my eye that Mortality is capable of: and beides, why hould not I conecrate that poor life to her daily ervice, though lighted, which he alone, with hazzard of her own, did recue from a violent udden end? But a • , is it poible Chryeide, that the ole inclination you once had for me, hould • ake you undervalue Crowns and Scepters; and that the violence of the paion which you were pleaed to make me believe hould live within the Grave it elf, hould not now have he trength to reit the cold and ingle propoition of a husband, whom I dare without pride compare with in all repects; and Challenge as inferiour in point and degree of affection?
After they had thus on either part entertain'd their ad thoughts, they dipatched Meages to each other in thee, or the like termes.

body.head: Chryeide to Gadate.
body.p:
I have been inform'd that you were profer'd a Wife where you now reide; and which is more, if I would readily give credit to all that is reported, I mut believe that you are willing to accept her: But I have not this eaie Faith; and till you ignifie your Levity, and Infidelity with your own hand, I hall perevere in the more pleaing opinion that you are till intirely mine, as I am unchangeably yours: Remember, I beeech you Gadate, before what acred Witnes, and with what
repeated Oathes you wore Love to me: But perhaps it was to cover your Crime, that you topt my Journey to you: My preence would ever have reproached you of a diloyalty unworthy of Affection; and that happy Creature whom you deign to epoue, would, no doubt have had more generoity then to betow her heart upon a deceiver, from whom he could hope for no other then the like treachery, that you commit towards her, whom you are engaged to love with as much Contancy, as you have Honour, Reaon or Religion in you.

body.head: Gadate to his Chryeide.
body.p:
It was needles to give me o many Tetimonies of Affection, if you intend to abue me: the charmes of beauty and wit, would have had dominion enough over the Liberty of my Soul, without the prodigal addition of o many flattering vows and promies, to confirm a Love which your change condemns of perjury, if it be true, that you will marry him, to whom you have already given the earnet of your Troth: But — Chryeide, will not your Infidelity become a greater prejudice to your own Soul and Honour, then the performance of your Oathes? And hall I know o much unhappines as to be acertain'd that your heart did not prompt your tongue, and lips when you pronounc'd thoe aurances of an Eternal Amity and Love? Yes Lady, I mut believe it, and undergo the penalty of hame for having o long worhip'd and ador'd an incontant, cruel Woman; and complain only that you defeat and betray the hopes you made my Credulous heart conceive of your incerity, who then behold her as the object of his highet felicity and
blis, who now is become the only caue of his trouble and misfortune. But I forfeit the repect I ow you by thee murmurings, it were not true Love for you, if I hould hinder you of thoe atisfactions; take whom you will then, Chryeide into your Lawful bed, if you can thereby pleae your elf, and epoue true happines in his peron: thee are uch wihes as you cannot forbid or chide me for, and my true Love at leat, inpite of your everity and my ad fate, hall derive this conolation to rejoyce that you are blet, though that be the ubject of my dipair, which ries from the ame ource, and if I importune you in continuing my more then common repect, I hall thereby reap this advantage that my more then Feminine pereverance will be ome mall revenge, for the unfaithfulnes wherewith you treat Your mot Faithful

div.p:
Vectorez caued thee Letters likewie to be intercepted that o thee Lovers might till wander in darknes and errour, and that their dipair might be increaed by the want of true intelligence. Gadate in fine, abolutely perwaded of the infidelity of his Mitris, dipatched me with a Letter equally compoed of love and anger, wherein he deired he would retore his picture, without the leat mention of any reaon that urg'd him to it. Chryeide who had mied the former complaints which my Mater had addres'd to her; believed infallably that he was fale, and that becaue he deired not to leave any tokens of his engagement to her in her poeion, he now ent for this. She firt tore his Letter in my preence,
and afterwards told me, with all the reproaches her violent paion could ugget, that I hould return to my Mater, and aure him, that he would not end back his Picture, but keeping it ever in her eye, that unworthy peron it repreented as he had once been the true Object of her Love, hould now be the Subject of her hate.

But as I was acquainted with the fidelity of my Mater, I could not uffer the unjut reproaches he flung at him, which he as verily believ'd might have been tuck on her, wherefore I calmly and with a becoming repect let her know, that this offence was indeed too enible and groly miapply'd, to lay that incontancy to his charge, of which he was only guilty, ince he might plainly read the verity of his affection, in that he had not ent for that Coppy, but only to take away the reemblance of one, whom he rationally believed could not be pleaing to her that ceaed to cherih the Original.

Thee lat words tung Chryeide to the Soul, and inflamed her with anger, in which heat and tranport, having hatily related all he had heard of Gadate, he unfolded that Letter to me, which Vectorez had counterfeited, wherein he intreated her to defer her Journey to the place he was at, becaue, Said She, My troubleome company might not diturb his freh Amours, and Courthip. To undeceive her of this prejudicate opinion; I reply'd that he thought he had the ame ground to complain of her, and that he had honour'd me with the • ght and perual of the Letter he had ent him, to
excue the retarding of her Journey. Chryeide carce gave me leaure to end thoe words, before She chang'd her Countenance and harh Language, into this weet tone of, — Pardon me, Sir, Said She, If I do tell you, that it's not true I ever wrote to Gadate what you affirm: on the contrary, I burned with deire and impatience to know the reaons why he would top me. And I can aure you in his behalf, return'd I, that he was no les amazed, and at a non-plus, when he read what you wrote. Then I repeated at length all what my Mater had learn'd touching her promie of Marriage, and how he having ent her a Meage, to which her ilence was the only anwer, he began to credit what report had proclaim'd, and what he for a long while before had only let into his ear, which he after ilence could not but uffer to enter into his heart as a real Truth.

What Demon, cry'd She, does thus betray our intents? the trouble and diatisfaction for not procuring his Anwer to me, about the ame Melancholly inquiry, firt brought upon me this fit of misbelief, which I perceive is his chief Malady and ditemper too, proceeding from the ame Caue. Ha! Would he had contracted no more guilt then I in this particular, and you, happy Meenger, if I dare believe what you affirm, how truly bleed am I; What then, it eems Gadate is faithfull till, and yet he could uppoe that I had falified my vowes to him; Let ome body fly to him, if you cannot Pot thither your elf, to eae and inform his Noble mind, leat he become more inful, by longer thinking I am o.

At the ame moment he wrote to him of all
this, and I hurried a faithful bearer away with thoe refrehing tydings, whilt we were gueing afterwards who could be the perons that had o ignobly, and ubtily ruffled the quiet and till then, weet commerce of thee Lovers: to find this out the more facilely, Chryeide ent for that woman, I already mention'd, by whoe management they convey'd all their ecrets, who was not a little urprized at my appearance, becaue he was of my acquaintance. Chryeide, having required an account of the letters they had written to each other, but had not been delivered, and of thoe that had been counterfeited in their tead, this unhappy woman had no les impudence to excue the fact, then he had malice in the acting it, and maintain'd boldly, that her change being only to end the papers, he had punctually delivered all thoe that came to her hands, but could not give any account of what they did contain.

We could not, in fine, get any thing ele from her, and the diligent care we took to gain ome exact knowledge of this cover'd Mitery, pull'd down the lat and heaviet michief on thee Lovers heads, and made way for the Enemies of their happines to compleat the deign of their abolute ruine. This wicked intrument was no ooner freed from Examination, but he went directly and inform'd the King, that it was time to put in practice, what he had contrived, to divert and detroy the inclination of thee Lovers: becaue there was a Gentleman ent from Gadate, who could eaily wipe out thoe apprehenions
and impreions which his feigned Letters might have left upon her Spirit.

The words of this Malicious woman, who feared to be dicovered, oon blow'd his rage and jealouie into a torm, which at firt made him think to end away immediately to have my Mater murthered, but one of his Confidents, les paionate then himelf, to whom he had opened his fowl deign, having wiely pointed out the difficulty, and danger of enterprizing on the life of o coniderable a peron, who was o well arm'd againt all aaults with the Forces he then commanded, moderated omewhat of that firt fury, and reolv'd to watch and py me circumpectly, and learn what time he meant to begin his Journey, that o they might ceaze on my Mater. And likewie he confirmed the old woman in her unworthy imployment, by new preents, whilt himelf contriv'd to pres forward the pretended Match between Gadate and the before mentioned Princes, and Chryeide with his own Kinman.

To this intent he wrote to my Mater, and to the Princees Father to let them know his purpoe was they hould marry before he returned to Court, he ent likewie to Chryeides Friends at the ame time; all he could do, when they brought her the Kings errand, was to implore ome time to conult about it, and to dipatch me uddenly to my Mater: but I was taid in my paages, and my Letters ceazed upon, which d • covered to Vectorez, how Chryeide deired Gadate to come in ecret to one of her Ants houes,
he being a woman that favoured their deign; where he promied to meet in a hort time, thereby a happy concluion of their Nuptials to prevent, that cros match the King o laboured to compleat.

The diligent King, had already preented the peron to Chryeide that was appointed to be her husband, and as well to fathom her thoughts, as to obtruct Gadates intervening, he told her, Gadate was likewie preparing for his epouals, to which he having reply'd, that he that hould poee o Illutrious and Noble a Husband, would be happy above the ordinary rate of Soveraigns, he conceiv'd o trange a jealouie upon the value he et on his merit and affection, that not able to quel the impetuous humour, he abolutely reolv'd to reduce him to the condition of incapacity to be her husband. To accomplih this, he et People in every place where Chryeide or Gadate could poibly pas, who continually watched to prevent their intended rendezvous, with expres order to arret both or either of them. Gadate fell the firt into their nare as being the mot forward and eager; and by a mot inhumane violence (the particulars whereof, I hall tep over, as not o decent to be related) two hours before his Ladies Arrival, they deprived him of the meanes of ever after being an able husband.

Chryeide knew as yet nothing, when he came into the Chamber, where he was hut up; but having undertood the bruitih effects of the Kings jealouie, he reolv'd to make it appear that he
had a virtue above his rage, and proteted openly, that ince Gadates merits had been the onely ubject of her affection, the Kings inhumanity which could not leen or ruine that, hould not hinder her from marrying him; Nay they did compleat the Wedding intantly after, and he ever lived his Contant Wife and Aociate: till Vectorez who inceantly perecuted her with his unruly paion, having been informed one day that Gadate was abent, forcibly entred into the Houe, and having threatned to violate her, if She were not flexible to his rude deires: finding her elf in this traight, that her Honour was inevitably ruin'd, unles She did Redeem it, at the price and forfeit of her precious Life, She with a Generous and Undaunted Reolution caught up a Dagger that lay near, and with a tab buried it in her Noble Bret, Sacrificing thus the fairet Life, to ave the mot exemplary chatity, that age could boat of.

This fatal blow which extinguihed ectorez burning lut, with the prinklings of her more temperate blood, augmented the unhappy Gadate's misfortunes: yet had he the dicretion to bear up againt this welling torrent of Affliction; and though he tetified the highet regret, was due to one o much deerving, and o dear to him, yet did his courage urmount and moderate the firt rapid motions of his dolours, becaue he then found himelf not in a fitting poture to make his reentments Publick. He withdrew himelf nevertheles from the Court, and amidt the throngs of his dipleaure, he knew
o well how to cloak his deigne of revenge under the habit of diimulation, that ectorez was apt to believe, time had effaced the memory of thoe injuries he had acted, and that he might as well confide in his peron as his valour, to trut him with thoe imployments he gave him in his Army, endeavouring to renew his Friendhip by the dignity of thoe commands he heaped on him: But as the affronts and injuries Gadate had receiv'd, were too recent and enible to be put in oblivion, he oon took advantage of the occaion Gobrias offer'd, in the aurance he had to meet in your excellent peron, that Prince whom it eemes the Heavens have ent to protect injured goodnes, and deliver the Ayrians from the Tyrant that o harply opprees them.

Sambaulas, having thus cloed up his tory, Cyrus recented the motions of a particular indignation againt ectorez, and proteted openly that thence forward the interet of his Glory hould not animate him more againt that degenerate King, then the deire of taking a jut revenge, for uch a Friend. He alo renew'd the aurances he had already given to Gobrias, he being then preent, and ought out Gadate to confirm him in what he expected, and hoped for from his protection, who to make the Ayrians know to their orrow, what a loe he hould prove to them, and advantage to Cyrus, he would needs put all thoe places of trength into his hands, whereof he was Mater at that time: but becaue he conjectured, that as oon as ectorez had the leat intimation of his deerting that party, he would
immediately end ome Troopers to plunder and detroy his Country, he meant to prevent him, and propounded to Cyrus to permit him to go with a party of Cavalry, to oppoe the Enemies paage, and ecure his Subjects, whom his preence would hold up in a poture of Loyalty towards him. Yet was it not without ome reluctancy that Cyrus did uffer him to go, only attended by his own Forces: but conidering that a numerous party as that of the Medes and Perians, laden with much proviions, could not arrive there oon enough, he let him et out firt with peed and diligence, whilt himelf dipoed his forces to march after him.

The Souldiers had already conceiv'd o high an eteem of Gadates merits, that they likewie gave tetimonies of their impatience to ait him. Cyrus perceiving them in this heat of willingnes, gave haty order for the Armies March, and having recommended the Lady's and Proviions to Gobrias care in whoe protection and charge he left them with a ufficient Guard, he offer'd the cutomary Sacrifices on uch occaion, and dipoed his Troopes in this following order.

Chryante had the Command of the Van-Guard, and that all the party, might follow conveniently, he placed the Curiaiers, which were arm'd heaviet there, at the head of whom he Commanded the Centureons to March. Artabaze had Command over the Perians that bare Bows and Bucklers; Adramias was ordered to follow with the Median Infantry; and Embas with the Armenian. After thee came Artuchas who conducted
the Hircanians; Thambrades the Sacques on foot, and Damates the Caduians, which two Nations had lately deerted the Ayrians.

All thoe that carried Bucklers, had the right wing, and the Archers or Bow-men the left, with the Centurions at their head. Next thee came on the Troopes that guarded the bagage and neceary proviions. In the Rear Guard, Madate led the Perian Cavalry (whom their Centurions had order to dipoe as the Infantry) Jeroombate the Median: Tygranes the Armenian: and in the Train of all were, the Sacques and Caduians.

This puiant Army being thus ranged, Cyrus bravely mounted upon a white Hore, who by his tately gate, eemed to be proud, of having him for Rider that Commanded o many Worthy's, rode all about to take a review, and after ome Speech to them, he particularly required them to be ilent, as being to March by night, in which there would be more need of their eyes then tongues, and et Scouts abroad, whom he often relieved: fearing too weariom a duty might render them les vigilant. The Souldiers, mean while, had leave to ret themelves, till a March were ounded, but they had been o powerfully animated by their Generals preence, that they waited for that hour, with deire and huge impatiency. Cyrus having again urvey'd the everal Troopes, and called to them all, or the mot part, by their particular names, he begot uch high thoughts in them, of their own worth by uch a fortunate mention and knowledge, that they heartily apired to make him better
acquainted by ome rare proofes, of their deerts and valour: and nothing in effect can be a greater pur to worthy actions, then the ambition and policy to hew, before thoe that are Lovers of uch Gallantry, the proofes of their expected prouee, as their confuion and digrace is greatet, that have uch Heroick Spectators for their Witnes, when they do things unhandomly. Beides, that the Commands given in uch a • ro •• of Men, and more readily executed, when thoe that are appointed, are o particularly nominated by their Chief.

About the midle portion of the Night, when darknes covered the whole face of Heaven, Cyrus gave the word to March, and having provided experienc'd guides to attend on Chryante, who led the Van, he caued them to go lowly forward, whilt he made the others advance after: and then having put them all in a poture to follow, they began to quicken their pace. At the break of day, eeing that the Caduian Infantry, who were in the Rear, were not econded with any Hore, he drew up ome Squadrons to joyne with them, and be aitant in cae the Enemy hould attaque them, and ent out freh Scouts to dicover their Quarters. At the ame time, that he was going to ecure his Friend, the unworthy peron that had formerly betray'd Gadate in his amours, and who had ent that fale Intelligence to Chryeide, how he was foraking her, was conulting how he might ruine him, and give him up into the hands and cutody of the Ayrians. He was well acquainted with his Maters mot
