Important Affairs, who had dipatched him before, to advertize his Friends, that he was hatning to their protection, with a potent Army: But this perfidious wretch, intead of performing that Commiion, ent peedy notice to the Ayrians of Gadates deign, and his approaching Forces; and gave trickt command to the Lievetenant of a well Fortified Catle in their paage, of which himelf was Governour, to admit them, and give them fair entertainment, till he next morning could lead Gadate into that Ambuh he had prepared for him, and wherein he, indeed, inevitably fell.

Gadate being arriv'd on his own pot; and not finding the face of any Enemy or Oppoer, excepting a few Chariots, and ome run-aways, whom his Forlorn-Hope till beat before them, undertook with the mall handful of men he had, to purue a flying party of Hore, who till fought retreating, till they had drawn him and his eager followers into the ambuh they had prepared. He hoped to ave himelf by beating his way into the Catle, which this fale fellow had urrendred to the Enemies, where he had indeed a willing entrance, but with the hazzard of his life, which had been there paid for it, had not the impetuous hat of the firt Court of Guard who flew with fury at him, given him notice, that he was in the hands of Enemies, where he thought to find a anctuary, and had not four or five that corn'd o bae a murther put themelves in a poture to defend him. By their aitance; Gadate had, indeed, av'd himelf without
hurt, and ecap'd from the Catle, had he not unfortunately in his retreat met with the cured fellow that betray'd him, whom he approaching as a friend, from whom he expected that uccour, he o much needed, intead of it, met with an unexpected wound from him in his houlder, which the other would have directed to his heart, who uddenly wheeling from him, purred towards thoe Ayrians that had left the Ambuh to ceaze upon Gadate, who yet feared not to purue them with that inconiderable Remnant of Friends that were remaining: and had there certainly bravely old his life, had not the Enemy been alarm'd with the approach of Cyrus and his whole Army, which made them oon change their ignoble aault upon Gadate, (who had already laid his fale Friend dead at his feet) into a more needfull flight to ave themelves. Their hat, however, could not carry them away o fortunately, but that ome fell in the puruite, and the ret were made Prioners with a great part of the bagage they had deerted, taken.

Cyrus having caued the retreat to be ounded, to Rally his dipered men, who returned to the Joyful Camp laden with Spoyle, was in ome apprehenion for Gadate, becaue he had not een him: whom preently after he pied coming towards him; and whilt he was pleading excue for not ooner arriving to ait him; Gadate was returning him millions of thanks for the uccour that had preerved a Life, which he infallably had otherwie lot, amidt their numbers.

Whilt thee illutrious warriours gave a breathing and refrehing intermiion to their men, the Caducian Prince, who was in the reare-guard, having not arrived o timely as to be at the engagement, thought it omewhat imported his reputation to ignalize the valour of his oldiers, by ome generous enterprize, ince he had no hare in the freh Victory they had obtain'd. To this effect, without communicating ought to Cyrus, he ecretly drew off from his quarters by the favour of the night, and deperately made his approaches neer the, City where the Ayrians had locked themelves up: before which place, he remained ometime urging them to a combat by his bitter threats; but none appeared to anwer him, the Enemy being o fear'd with their lat defeate, they durt not iue out, till being certainly made acquainted, that the Caduians were there alone, they made a vigorous ally, and after a hot fight, which hung a long while doubtfully between them, the Caducians having, in fine, lot their Prince, were ditres'd to a retreat.

The troopes which Cyrus ent to relieve them, met them at their returne towards the Camp, whilt every countenance diplay'd the orrows which fill'd their hearts for their lot Prince, but the judicious Cyrus, to divert the hame of their defeit, receiv'd them with as honorable carees, as if they had return'd victorious and triumphant, and conoling them for their dead General, attributed all to the fortune and giddy chance of warr, which had o unuccesfully
econded their attempt: and afterwards commanded his Chyrurgions to have a very great care of uch as were wounded: there was not one coniderable peron but he did peronally viit, and promied them all, that in revenge, he would not give the Ayrians any long leaures to brag of their advantage. In effect, he went with a trong party to fetch off the lain, in ight of the conquering Enemy within the town: to whom he propounded an equal combat, to redeem the honour of his aociates, of whom he had no little jealouy and epecially, thee now mentioned, becaue he had acquir'd them but of late: but finding that not any appear'd to anwer his ummons, he caued the whole Country to be poiled and pillaged, and commanded to cut off all the tragling Enemies they hould meet, as a acrifice for his compagnions Ghot.

The Ayrians on the other hand, retyr'd toward Babylon, and left him the campagne free: of which when he perceiv'd himelf the abolute Mater, he conider'd, that to oblige the Enemy, and preerve thoe Provinces that had o freely tendred themelves to him, he hould doe well to call back thoe Free-booters he had let looe; thereby to give no jut occaion to the Ayrians, to act the like upon his conquer'd neighbourhoods, when he hould be at too great a ditance from them, to ave them from plunder. To this end having ummoned in his men, whilt they replenih'd all his garrions with neceary proviions, he dipatched a Trumpetter towards
Babylon, to propound to ectorez, that if he loved or regarded the welfare of his people, he was contented not to hinder the labourers from freely cultivating the grounds under his power; till the harvet time, and then the longet word hould reap it, provided that he would engage to give the ame allowance of liberty in thoe Provinces, which the right of Conquets had made him mater of.

ectorez who conjectur'd his own advantage in this propoition, becaue he had the greatet hare of the Country. Subject to pillage, and les forces to defend them from the Enemies frequent incurions, willingly accepted the propoal; and Cyrus likewie aented to a Truce for ome dayes, at the requet of Gadates Mother, who begg'd that time of him, to have the conveniency of putting her affaires in order, land o dipoe of them, as to be in a capacity of following her on whereever he remov'd. This good Lady was accompanied with her daughter Cephia, who gave Cyrus no les caue to wonder at the excellency of her beauty, then her brother had at the effects of his rare courage. And indeed many of thoe that were obliged to approach her with becoming alutations, were much taken with her charming meen, though there appear'd ome Characters and lines of adnes and trouble in her lookes, which gave the beholders a perfect knowledge of ome inclination he left behind, whilt he was forced to waite and abent her elf with her Mother.

This quiet interval gave way to the paion of Cyrus to hew its utmot power: the apprehenions for not hearing any thing of his Birinthea, which had been ilenced by the diverions of war, now ceazed trongly, on his oul. One day as with thee thoughts, he entertain'd himelf on the Margen of a pretty river, which led its current through a hady Grove, having no other company, but uch as were his obliged attendants for his guard, he caued them to tay at ditance, that he might with more liberty give himelf up to his Melancholly reflections, and after a long and ilent thought fullnes, which can be better gues'd at, then dicribed, but which as ince appear'd was altogether fix'd upon his dearet Princes, he pronounced her fair name in a bemoaning accent, which yet had not the liberty to get out of his lips, without the interruption of a thouand ighes that uher'd and attended it.

Whilt he was in this uncomfortable poture, he cats his looks beyond the river and beheld ome Cavaliers, with drawn weapons, that attaqu'd three or four other men in rutique habits, who did defend a woman in the like garb, with more valour then could be hoped for, in perons of their coats; the inequality of the combatants did quickly rowe and call up his generoity, he laid by his thoughts of love to make ue of his courage, and mounting his hore as hatily as he could, he wam him cros the water, together with thee that attended him, but though his diligence were great, he could not get in time
enough to ave the woman from being hurried away; however he poted after thoe Cavaliers, and having demanded, as he pat along, of one of the company that came with the woman, what peron it was, they thus forced from them; he was amazed to hear Abracome cry aloud, (whom he dicover'd by his voyce) that it was Birinthea, they thus ravihed thence. That name hindred all other dicoure, it was alone more then he would have heard, and being led now, more by the violence of his paion, then he was ere while by his valour, it may be aid, he rather flew then rode after thoe theves, that carry'd thence that treaure (he eteem'd above all Diadems) out of his ight and preence, whom he at lat oretook long before any of his company could reach thither.

It were a task next to impoibility to relate; with what fury he et on them: three or four of them intantly made head againt him, to give their aociates the opportunity of getting into a little City neer hand: but he beat thorough them, and as lightning, darting forwards, when he had catter'd thoe oppoing words, he overtook the others jut at their entrance into the gates. Though they were many that reited Cyrus, yet had they need of the firt corps de guard to ait them, but the ret of his followers being joyned with him did o gallantly econd his valour that after they had laid many on the earth, they entred pell-mell with their Enemies, who to avoid their blowes retreated further within the City.

The hurry and confuion was o great, that
few diputed his attempt to get in the City, and as if it had been taken by aault, the report oon came to his ear, that had the chief commanded there. He was o urpriz'd with this alarme, that without taying for his company's to be drawn up, he ran hatily towards the Gate, where he was told the Enemies had made their way: and there found mot of his men flying ome one way, others another, whilt Cyrus eagerly preed thoe that yet durt hinder him. He oon knew by his valour, that he was head of that enterprize: and therefore having reproached the cowardize of his guards, that could not tand againt o mall a power, he made them wheele off, and crying aloud to Cyrus, that it was he mut be firt conquer'd, if they would gain the place; he dicharg'd uch a blow that Cyrus had much a doe to ave himelf, whereby he found that he had now a more dangerous Enemy to deale with: and then, indeed, as if he had before reerved his chiefet trength, he joyned all his courage and reolution to his former hear, to buckle with this freh and vigorous apponent:

Never had Combat been written in deeper wounds, had they not been as skilful to avoid, as they were deparate to give them; nor had they ended this duel but with death, if ome of the Governours Officers then arriving, finding him o overmatch'd by Cyrus, had not overpoured him by their numbers, who having lot much blood, eemed to be only animated with his love, and after a while unk on his hores
neck and then rol'd off, under his feet.

Zorbas, who was this Governour, intead of taking advantage of this fall, was angry with thoe that caued it, whoe generoity not brooking, what his Valour had not purchaed, caued him traigtwayes to be lifted up, and finding him covered with blood that treamed from everal wounds, commanded he hould be carried to the next Captains houe, adjoyned to the gate, where he came in, and there took pecial care to have both him, and all his followers dret by his bet Chryrurgions before he left the place. He alo gave order to have the Gates ecured having waited ome time to ee if any other Forces would appear, not having faith enough to believe that thoe few Prioners could have alone the confidence to force his Guards. After a while he returned again to Cyrus, who notwithtanding the mart of his wounds, and the hame of his Captivity, tetified, he thought nothing troubleome compared to his fears for Birinthea, after whom he often inquired of thoe that were in preence.

Zorbas aborded him o civily, that although he were prepoes'd with thoe griefs, he could not but oberve omething in him, which is not to be met with in ordinary perons, and from which he derived (etting aide his interets) no mall or mean hopes of all the favour that can be expected from a Noble Enemy. Their firt dicoures were nothing but jut and mutual praies they paid each others valours: in fine, Cyrus
prompted by his affection, beeeched Zorbas to let him give him in particular, an account of the reaons that had urg'd and drawn him to this puruite of his men even within his Gates, and Zorbat being firt inform'd that Cyrus might ue the liberty of his Speech without any detriment to his health; after he had cleared the Chamber of other Auditours, Cyrus pake thus to him. Generous Warriour, I hould have reaon to conceal the Caue and Subject of my preent condition. if I were not to relate it to a peron who has the gifts of too many other brave quality's, to be a tranger to the experience of what has thus engag'd me.

Love is that puiant Deity whoe power your Soldiers could not withtand, he fought in my peron, nor hould I ever have admitted the leat thought of violating the Articles of Truce, had I not unhappily beheld her, brought into this City, who alone has the abolute and intire poe • ion of my Heart and Liberty. Judge you, what reaon I had to follow her, and whether it were not tricktly jut, finding her in my Enemies hands, in a time when I was impatient to know her condition to endeavour to ave and recover that treaure of my Soul: but ince my deigne was defeated by your means, 'tis from your only favour that I can hope to attain the bleing of beholding her and to you alone mut I owe the O • ligation for that immene, and more then ordinary avour. You have expreed and practic'd too much the Laws of generoity in my behalf already, to refue this addition of Grace, and I dare trut your Virtue o far as to be confident that you will uffer ome Meeng • r to go and wait on her in the behalf of a Perian
Gentleman; and alo aure her from you, that he may afely disband all her fears, o long as he is under your happy protection.

Who ever you are Anwered Zorbas, though I were not Witnes of your extraordinary Valour, yet to ay you fought under the Standard of that potent God, were alone enough to make me quickly reigne my Sword and yield.

I hould not have offered to oppoe you, had I known what Interet inpir'd and enflam'd your courage, and I do much regret to have reited one that was o bravely buied in his quarrel, who is my Soveraign Lord, no les then he is yours. Dipatch whom you pleae to that honoured Lady, and I will peronally accompany him, to diengage and free her from thoe infamous ravihers, and if you take it for a favour that I hould help you to her ight and preence, I hall expect no other reward, then only that you would obtain the pardon I now crave for my Mens Inolence, which I hall expiate by any atisfaction he and your elf can further demand of them or me, and that you may enjoy the full Liberty of her convere and ociety, I leave you, and o adue, Generous Lover, and would to Heaven, that I could ever hope for the ame happy fate, I now procure you, by this willing Obervance and Civility. — He paed out after thee words, and commanding the Captain that had charge of the Prioners to give them all full liberty to be by themelves, he went along with him whom Cyrus had appointed to fetch his Byrinthea.

This Excellent Lady, who little knew he had uch intereted Protectors o near, was confin'd
to a cloe Chamber, wherein he was lock'd up with a Wench and a Souldier that tir'd not from the door. The barbarous Villain carce gave her liberty to bemoan her condition, or breath a igh, but eeing her in a habit uitable to that diaterous Captivity, he proffer'd his comforts, and impertinent frenzies to abate her orrows, and told her, to dry up her trifling and fruitles tears, that he was but too happy in being valued by him that had brought her to this pas: this inolent Courthip enibly offended her; who mut needs be Mitris of a rare patience to endure it, that knew her elf to be ador'd by the greatet of Princes: but he had reaon in that ditres to uffer all this and more, rather then dicover unreaonably what he was; and Zorbas tep'd into the room, jut when he was defending her elf againt the rude carees of this rough fellow: She was truly joy'd that his preence put an end to the others inolence: but yet another fear tept in to make her fortune les compleat, which was an apprehenion that this was the peron had urpriz'd her for his own bae ends: nevertheles the civility of his mild approach, promied more good, and gave her way to reaume her firt fair hopes; and as he was very dicreet, he had no ooner met her, and performed the mot uuall and becoming Ceremonies of Salutation, but he intreated he would be conducted to a Frie • ds houe, where, he doubted not, but he would find a greater atisfa •• ion, and con • ent, then he could probably expect in uch an invitation.

Though thee words poke of happines he eemed to fear the contrary by her amaze; a udden bahfulnes orepread her face, which carried rather the marks of virtue then of hame in the beholders opinion, and only anwering what he aid, with a repectfull ilence: Whither do you lead me aid he to the other, that proffer'd her his hand to that intent. May I tread confidently where you guide me without offence to Virtue? Or were it not better to let me dye in this ame Place? Ha! My Lord Continued he, turning towards Zorbas, if you have as much true ence of Honour, as you perwade me: leave me not in thee apprehenions, but aure me, before I go, that I hall meet no danger in the Obedience I now pay you.

To remove thee Scruples and Threatning Apprehenions, Zorbas promied faithfully, he hould be treated with all the repect and decency he could deire, or that Country could afford: but his deepet oathes could not gain her belief; o that he went forward with much dread and diffidence, and with a poitive reolution to dye, rather then yield to any dihonour or undecent attempt againt her innocent peron, for which he had no Guard or Security beides that noble intent, as Heroick and Gallant, as he was Chat and beautiful. At her firt entrance into Cyrus's Chamber, whom he as yet knew not to be there, he found her fears increaed by the ight of one in Bed, from which he was teping back by a trembling retreat, fancying they had brought her there for that which he apprehended
a thouand times more then death it elf, but Cyrus perceiving it, inform'd her better by thee words, Fear not to approach me, Madam, You need not doubt you hall hazzard that now; which I endeavour'd to ave at the price of my Life: it was to hinder and prevent the unhappines you tart from, that put me into this wounded condition. In a Word, let it uffice to tell you, that you here meet with him, who in the firt moment of beholding your fair hape, and being blet with an early knowledge of your great quality, and greater virtues, could not deny you his heart and liberty, together with your Fathers forfeited Life, who yet breaths only to tell you, nay and make it appear by more Eminent and becoming Services, that he lives only for you, and to whom you have, by an expres Meage, done the high Favour to command his aitance in the like occaion againt Cyaxares. If my unhappines, Madam, has not permitted me to effect it, as you deired, accue nought but the rigour of my Fate, for whoe perverenes I am at preent too much recompened, ince the Gods have favourably econded my intentions, and have honoured me with the Satisfaction and advantage of igning your decree and ervice with my blood.

Birinthea was o urprized at this accident, that although he knew him by his voice and viage, yet he made it a quetion whether he might afely credit the joyful, but unexpected Intelligence of her eares and eyes. In fine, having fatned her teady looks upon him, and made a more minute urvey of thoe known features: What, aid he, Generous Prince, Will misfortune
never ceae truggling againt our inclinations: Mut I till owe my Obligations ingly to you; and yet be forced to remain ungrateful, Ah, how unjutly fortune rewards your merits, by denying me the power to retribute thoe high favours I am indebted for; thoe worthy ervices you have performed, requires with jutice the love that I had made you hope for; but I am now neceitated to recall it; and therefore employ no more either your care or courage, if you make that your pretence and aime, for my devoir forbids me now to harbour affection towards you; Nay o far is it from that, as I am bound to declare, that its not altogether convenient, I hould admit you to love me. We are both equally unfortunate in this etate; I being obliged to ingratitude, after o great a um of goodnes paid by your valour and clemency to me; and you for having been o liberall of your Noble virtues without the meanet of returns in atisfaction. I might nevertheles, flatter your hopes a new with ome freh pretences, in the neceity I am in, to ingage your protection againt thoe rude hands I am fallen into: but know Sir, at leat, if I cannot repay the acknowledgements you deire of me, yet I can be o jut and reaonable as not to delude you in it. I doubt not but this dicoure begets your wonder: and truly it will not be expected other from him who had uch fair hopes of the contrary: But it requires more time and trength then we are Mater of at preent to make it known, I hould unriddle thee Enigmaes if you were in a itting poture: be careful therefore only of your care, and if my Honour or Life are of any value to you, preerve your own with tendernes.

Preerve my Life reply'd he, After thee killings words, Madam, you impoe impoibilities; before you injoyned me to live, you took away the means, by taking away my hopes. How cruel you are, Birinthea, to wih me to live, and yet forbid me to Love, which are things above my power. Indeed, Said he interrupting him, I deire you would love me with les heat and paion: but you expound my thoughts ill; and you reproach that as a cruelty, which is indeed compaion; Since I command it only for your quiet and eae, to helter you from thoe torms of trouble will otherwie fall upon you. Ah no, reparted he, ceae I beeech you, Madam, to be pittiful in this manner, the peace and repoe you wih me, would be more inupportable a thouand times, then the ufferings of my paion, and to tetifie how dear they are in my eteem, whilt I endure them for you. I will truggle to live and obey you to undergoe them the longer. That cannot be obedience as I expect Anwered She, to deire to uffer, I enjoyn you to live, that you may live happier: but to remove the doubts you may entertain of the veritie of what I have already made known, I perceive it will be necearie I hould relate to you all that has occurr'd in Media and Armenia, that o you may approve my reaons, when I have produced them

Since you departed from Ecbatane your ncle Cyaxares thought fit to come and ee my Mother, whom he had not yet viited in the apartment alotted by him for us, where he paid her more repect and civilitie then formerly he was wont, Phraorte and Arthemia had alo a hare in this honour, and only I, of all our familie, mied
of this Ceremony, detained in my chamber by a light Malady But as I was the peron he chiefly deign • d to wait on, he made a particular enquiry for me, and being informed that I was indipoed, and not in a condition to admit his Societie, it pleaed him to end me a complement by one of my Maids, which I then interpreted an effect of civility.

Pheretime, My Mother, was o highly atisfied with this Viit, that he no ooner left the place, but without delay he came with Phraorte and Arthemia to give me the News, and promie the hopes of a quite contrary treatment then what we ince tated; and two hort dayes, which were required to put me in a condition of health, were thought by her too long to tay from giving him thanks for that Courteie. She went the very next day, together with my Brother and Siter; and not to omit the leat punctilio, She carried my excue for not being in a capacitie of performing that devoir which eemed too weightie to be neglected.

Having quitted him, they went to his Queen, whither he would needs accompany them; and that good Princes gave them o favourable a welcome, and hew'd uch ingular tetimonies of affection, that Pheretime charmed with her carees, and the affable weetnes of her entertainment, begg'd the permiion to repeat her viits frequently: In a hort time afterwards he carried me to kis her hands; and She made me o pleaed with her winning and hearty reception, that it out-bad the indulgence and fondnes of mot Mothers. I cannot expres, indeed, what Repect and Affection this inprired in me towards her, no more then I can tell you her
tendernes towards me: I was her dearet Daughter, o She ever termed me, and I was more Converant, and much more contantly attendant on her, then on Pheretime.

But as the Queen loved me with o great Affection, o the King fancy'd me with no les Paion; and I was compelled at length to make the ones Amity a buckler to defend me from the others Amours. Nor do I well know how to gues what had, ere this, been become of Birinthea, if the Virtue and Dicretion of o generous a wife had not hielded me from the violent attempts of o unutable a Husband, who yet, practied a long reerved ilence, ere he would make her tongue my advocate. We till were harers in all the divertizements and pattimes at Court, no Aembly could be thought compleat that had not brought us in, and thoe that had been unacquainted with our condition, would ooner have judg'd us to be Princees of his blood, then ditreed Captives, and truly I mut needs confes the Noble age we then had, made our condition very upportable, and etting aide, the liberty of reiding at our own home, my Mother till remain'd in the Rank of a Queen; and her Children of Royal Princes. The oft cords of our Captivity admitted but few Preures or Regrets, and Cyaxares took o hearty a delight in chearing and diverting us, that we had carce the leaure to reflect on our late troubles: but as no exces or violence lats long: our fair dayes were oon over-cat with blacknes, and thoe early blooms nipt at their firt pretty blooming; for I then began to know that Pheretime, Phraorte and Arthemia owed all the goodnes and repect paid
them in that Court, to the wild paion Cyaxares till then kept closeted in his heart for me.

One day, when the purity of the air, had tempted me to walk with my Maids in, thoe pleaant allies, thorow the Royal park, which lead toward the brook, he hapned to be very neer me, ere I was aware: which gave him opportunity to overhear what I pake to my Maid named Diomar, who has ever been my cheifet confident, and taking occaion to continue the very ame dicoure rather then eem to interrupt what then my thoughts were buied with, he preented me his hand, and leading me till in the ame walk, as well as words, cunningly wiredrawd them to his own ends, which having engag'd me to attention he proecuted thus.

If all thee pleaing objects in this Park, the pretty children and products of Art and Nature were not inanimate, how glorious would they eteem themelves to be o honourd with your fancy and delight in them: but give me leave to anwer for them to all you ay, the atisfaction you expres'd concernes me, ince I am Mater of them, who am too happy that there is any thing belonging to me has the power to pleae or content you. Your Majety, reply'd I, not knowing whither his dicoure tended, does almot rob me of the meanes to thank you for thoe favours you impart, by indeavouring to perwade me that it is ome advantage to you that I am o well atisfied with thee objects. But my opin • on mut take the confidence to dipute this a little with your civility, and you, I know, will pardon
me, when I dare tell you: that tis ome wrong to your own vertue, to make your felicity conit in my ole approbation, rather then eek for it, in its own proper origine and center, ince none, I humbly think can be expected from me ufficiently correpondent to your great bounty. 'Tis I, that with more reaon hould value it able ing to be in uch a Monarch's power, who takes no other advantage of our Captivity, then the frequent occaions to make known his generoity, and who is o profue of his grace and favours, that we may reckon it a gain to have left our liberty, which cannot be o highly prized by any one, but they would freely forfeit it, to enjoy what you o readily confer each moment.

Spare, Madam reply'd, the King, pare this dicoure for omething that better deerves it, and if I have been o fortunate as to oblige you to tell me o: beleeve Birinthea, that all the cheap obervances you have yet met with, are but the mall effects of that greater inclination I have for the honour of your ervice. But what mut I now hope for after this declaration, can you with jutice dieteem a caue, whoe effects you praie o rarely, Great King, aid I, thoe two things have too far engaged me already: but the acquaintance you have with my preent condition and your own, will tell you, that it is les in my power to correpond with the one then the other, and beides what can you rationally expect from a Princes that has not o much as her own liberty. That he hould, anwerd he to interrupt me, accept of the preent I now make of mine in retaliation, that he would vouchafe to be my Soveraign, and uffer me to be her ervant. You have a mind to prove, reparted
I, whether I am capable of preumption your Majety delights in this tryall, but I beeech you to beleeve, that the honours you have baited your temptations withall, are too weak to violate my Repect and Modety, and I hall borrow o much Humility from my Virtue as to aure you, that I hall never own o great a vanity, ince I am intructed by my own defects to declare, that I have not a tock ufficient to claime the merrit of the meanet favour, I would now thank you for. Thee evaions, Birinthea; are witty, reply'd he, and I perceive that I mut court you rather with effectual ervices then words, and I will follow that method hereafter, and make good what I intend for your atisfaction by more authentique performances, which hall write my affection in more, noble characters, ince you beleeve but lightly when I peak them.

He left me with this compliment, and Diamar, who had taken notice that our convere was too eager to be of an ordinary concerne only, came to me aoon as he was abented, and deired to know, what might be the dicoure; that had called o much colour into my face. I would not hide the truth of it from her, to prevent her judgement by my intructions from being educed by the King, who I was confident would endeavour to corrupt her, and having ummoned all our reaon to aid us in our conultation what to doe in this cae, I reolv'd to diemble, and make the King know, I reckned all this but as gallantry and formal complaiance, and trictly commanded her not to dicover it to any other, and likewie to give me an exact account if ever the King made any dicoure to her concerning it.

Many dayes pat over in which Cyazares aid no more of this paion, whilt he continued to doe us all the good offices could be expected: but in the end being tyr'd with uch a fruitles patience, and purd on by deires, he repeated all thoe former protetations, with uch preing words, and vehement motions, that I apprehended he would have forgoteen all obriety and ence of honor. In this conflict, I had much adoe to manage his reaon, if I treated him civilly he became inolent, if I checqued his inolence, he flew into violence, o that by the frequent changes of our lookes, and the alterations of our voices when we met, the judicious oon conjectur'd the matter of our dicoure, The Queen who is extremely dicreet was one of the firt that gues'd it, and convering with me once in private, relying on the conjectures he had made, he indeavour'd quaintly to know the certainty: but mis'd her deign, for I pretended not to undertand her and turned the current of the inquiry into another channel.

The doubt I dwelt upon whether I hould make known the truth or not to her, held me ometime in upence. I feard he might become my Enemy if I declar'd my elf her rival, and on the other hand, I apprehended that if I hould conclude my privacy was but a token of my confederacy with the King. In the concluion, knowing the olidity of his vertue, I thought mot convenient to informe her fully
of it, and beeeched her, when I had related every title to beleeve that it was made a ecret, only upon the account of freeing her from the trouble uch a report mut needs have left upon the pirit of a Princes that o intirely honourd her husband.

This worthy Queen in lieu of howing any diturbance, told me mildly, She was orry her preent condition proved an obtacle to my advancement, and that the quality of the Kings mife hould block up my way to the Median throne, where my great merti • would have placed me with more jutice, and the Kings poion with more atisfaction, but to repair the wrong her fortune did me, I might afely promie my elf all the favour he could poibly with honour compas for me, above all he remmended the love and practie of vertue to me, as the only aitance I could expect to league with againt her husbands illegal flames and attempts, and he forbad me alo to diclee it either to my own Mother or iter till he found it convenienter.

I was highly atisfied with her temper and goodnes, he bearing o great a hare of the trouble; and to hun the Kings importunate courthip, who perecuted me with a perpetual expotulation, I kept my elf the mot that I could with her, becaue in her preence he could not o well have the liberty of a ecret peech, or more open addres: but when he perceived that I avoided thoe opportunities, he made ue of a new Stratagem and engine, having gain'd and notably intructed one of the Queens maids of her Chamber to ollicite and plead for him, who
was o over diligent in her duty; that I had carce a minute of intermiion when the Queen was abent. I told the Queen of this new intrument, but he was forc'd to uffer her, to keep the King in temper, who nevertheles began to how ome anger, and ometimes borrow'd the threatnings of everity to quell my braving contancy, which beat off all the eaillants he o long had kept in action againt me.

p.hi: What troubles, good gods, did I not uffer, and what coniderations did I not produce to attisfy his paion, the fear he was in to dipleae me did ometimes qualify his fury; but, in the end, being one day come to viit me at the Queens, where I had lodg'd, hearing me anwer him omewhat freely, not as a lave, but a Princes, he likewie grew harpe, and turning away dicontented, he told me, that ince I made no better ue of the honour he was willing to confer, in treating me o civilly, he would thenceforth make me know I was his prioner, and that his proffers were not o depicable, to be thus corned and refued, by a Captive as I was,

div.p:
I protet, had he taid by me after this peech, I would have anwer'd thoe inolencies, in a language fit for one of my birth and breeding: but he withdrew o uddenly, that all I could doe, was to waite on the Queen, where without takeing any notice which was preent, I cat my elf at her feet; and let her know more by my ighs and teares, then any words I could utter, what the now caue of my affliction was; every one much admir'd to ee me in this diorder, knowing
the ingular repect, and favours I o frequently received at Court. She onely knew what orrows did oppres me; and to be the more particularly inform'd, he caued all the ret to withdraw, into the Antichamber: when I had related all the King had threatned, he endeavoured by a thouand peruaions and carees to wipe away my tears: and thinking it no longer neceary, to hide this unhappines from Pheretime; he ent for her with Phraorte and Arthemia. Imagine, Cyrus, what their atonihment was, when they were told the occaion of their coming. Had not the Queen of Media aur'd my Mother of it, it would have hardly gained her belief, but in fine, as it concerned us much to find a peedy remedy to allay the Kings violent heat and reolution, they concluded together, that it was bet for us to remove for a while into the Country, that by my abence I might take away the effect of his anger, with the caue of it, in which time, the Queen engag'd to make it her only endeavour to ooth and reclaim him to his wonted mildnes again. To this purpoe, She proffer'd to carry us to one of her Country Houes, not above a dayes Journey from Ecbatane. This reolution being fixt, to depart within a day or two, I retired my elf with my Mother, who was mightily troubled at this diater, and who would needs be exactly acquainted of every Circumtance relating to this ad tory.

The Evening before the day appointed, Phraorte
being in my Chamber, we were advertized that the King demanded to ee me, I ran hatily into my Mothers, for fear leat he hould urprize me in my own. Pheretime would needs go to receive him, but he acended with o much precipitation, that he entred into her Chamber before he could get out to meet him, and having aluted her very coldly, he came directly towards me, and aid, That ince I had an intent to goe into the Country, he was unwilling the Queen hould rob him of the advantage to procure me that divertiement.

I would have reply'd, but he gave me not the time, for taking me by the hand, he intreated I would follow him. Then Pheretime and Arthemia would have taid me, Phraorte likewie ceazed on a Sword to recue me, but was with held with the ret, whoe trugglings were too weak to oppoe the violence of his Guards, who by his order forced me thence into a Litter that waited at the Gate. He was inexorable to all my teares and prayers, pitty had left the lodging in his heart, for a more rah and reolute guet, o after he had recommended the care of my peron, particularly to thoe were to convoy me, he ent me to a Catle, whither I arrived about two hours after our etting forth. I know not what became of Pheretime, Phraorte and Arthemia, or how they behaved themelves afterwards, having heard no tidings of them ever ince: But for my own part, I was entertained in that Catle, with more repect, then if I had
been the Median Queen; I had Eunuques for m • Guard, and Gentlewomen to attend me: I was conducted to an apartment no les beautifull then plended, where Cyaxares had contriv'd, that I hould meet with all the delights imaginable to charm and dipel thoe orrows and troubles, which are incident to thoe in my condition. Nothing that yields pleaure either to a curious ear or eye was omitted: for when I had ullenly refued to tat of a choice Supper and Banquet, being withdrawn into a pretty Cloet to weep my fate at liberty, they ung o harmoniouly in the next Room, that at any other time I hould both have admir'd, and equally lov'd it, but I was wholly poeed with grief, and beides that portion of vexation, I reented a particular hate and didain for thoe entertainments, deigned to delude and tempt me from my too jut apprehenions and fears of following dangers; if not ruine. This made their ubtil endeavours become o importunate, that it but rais'd up more, thoe Spirits they would have laid, and intead of oothing me, urg'd me to end them word by an attendant, that if their orders were to procure my content, they could not find a more ready means then by their udden ilence.

Night was grown old, when I went to my bed, where I paed the remaining tedious moments of it, in bitter ighs and tears, and not without the dreadful upicions of ome following violence to ucceed from Cyaxares. With the early
Light came an Eunuque into my Chamber, before I could tart up, to bring me the wih of a happy morning from him; and told me, that he had already waited a long time for my riing. It would have been in vain to refue his viit, ince it was as much out of my power, as it was in my will to hinder it; Therefore I converted neceity into Policy, and received him with a more outward how of Civility and Repect, then averion.

As oon as he had Saluted me, he demanded if I were atisfied, with the entertainment I had found, to which I reply'd, That if I might be allow'd the freedom to tell the unfeigned Truth, I hould rather have elected to be treated like a Captive and mean Slave, provided he had not torn me out of the Sanctuary of my Mothers Arms and Boome, then to be the unwilling and unhappy partaker of all his Princely Entertainments, in this eparation, upon which he made this repartie, That excepting the preence of Pheretime, I hould mis nothing of that uual tendernes and care he till had for me.

A • l his dicoure kept, thus, within the confines of modety and repect, till I was ready to go into the Litter again, then he commenc'd, but with a teady moderation to Court me, and declare his love, and he implor'd me to excue the troubles and fatigues of that Journey, to which the neceity of his affairs, as well as his reaon and paion made him hurry me. I heartily inited alo to conjure him, by all the powers of that affection he profes'd towards me, to uffer
either Pheretime or Arthemia to come to me, but all I could obtain was an aurance, that I hould ret in as much ecurity where he would leave me, as if I were till in their eye and Guardianhip.

At length I arriv'd, where he deign'd to lead me, The place was rarely pleaant for its cituation, The Catle being built on a little riing ground, fatned to the foot of Mount Orontus, from whence lies a brave propect Eatward, being a large Champagne, and upon one hand a fertile Vale, whoe border is fring'd with a pure Silver Stream, which wantonizing, with a Serpentine, or indented Figure, and a low tately pace, creepes through a umptuous Garden, where Art has turn'd it to a thouand Rivolets and Fountains, to imbellih that New Eden, whoe united treams meeting, again, together at the lower end of this Paradize make a pleaing murmur, as if rejoycing at each others ight after o long a eparation, and welling to their firt breadth make a Channel that divides this pacious Garden from the well-tored Park: but as there is nothing can make a Prion delightfull, where Golden hackles are no lee ponderous then Iron Gyves, the very retraint putting a tamp of dicontent and averion on all thoe leer diverions, o thee erv'd onely accidentally to augment my griefs. One of the greatet troubles I utain'd in this olitary confinement, was the want of a Compagnon, in whoe faithful bret I might depoi • e my ecret thoughts, and I had ever languih'd in this unhappines,
if the virtuous Queen, your Aunt, had not ent me the bleing of a Letter by an Eunuque, who was intirely her Creature, and for whoe fidelity he was reponible. Naretes, o was he called, in delivering me the Letter, he favour'd me withal, told me the trickt and noble charge he had to be at my devotion and command to the utmot of his ability.

The good Offices this Fellow rendred me, did much deminih my Melancholly, by his means I oft received and returned Meages to the Queen, and my Dear Mother, and I was inform'd, that Cyaxares who had a good while left me, intended hortly to renew his viit. I confes, alo that, had it not been for his Counel, I hould have been more refractory and tubborn at his ummons to receive him. I reolv'd indeed, to let him know my anger, and ditate; but to moderate it o, withall, as not to exaperate his too much; but when he was preent, my lights were not proof againt his paions, he dicovered my Stratagem and defeated it, and had certainly proceeded to violence, if Naretes had not prudently interpos'd, and tept between my virtue and his lut, o that for my part, I believe, I owe the preervation both of my Honour and Life to that faithful Eunuque, ince the King hould never have rob'd or deprived me of the one, but with the other. Naretes amuzed him with the promie of tempting me to a compliance, as flexible as his deire was olicitous, if he would but allow him a convenient time to effect it, Cyaxares
conented, though with ome reluctance, to this tryal; but he precribed him o exact and hort an interval, that in the urgent neceity, not knowing what to act to divert this ugly fate, I remembred that you had left Abracome in Ecbatane, to erve me, in any thing my fortune might challenge of you.

Can I tell you without a bluh, Cyrus, that you were the firt I cat my eyes and hopes upon, as the Protector of our hatterd Family. Your generoity, from whoe plentifull tock I had already gathered o much benefit, and the fair Amity you had vow'd with honour to me, created a mot probable belief in me, that as you alone were mot able, o you would be mot ready and wiling to recue her, who eemd to tand a favorite in your eteem. Upon thee, hopes I wrote that Letter, which came afe to your hand • , upon that Subject, and addreing it covertly to my Mother; by Naretes aitance, he gave Abracome Commiion to convey it to your elf, which he performed with that faithful diligence, that has obliged us both extreamly to him. It was ome time, before I received the news of your los, which that truty Servant brought me, and this was obtructed by the jealouies of a woman, whom the King kept as a py upon me, who had given him o many hints of ditrut for you, that he once more ecretly convey'd me to a place unknown to any of my Relations. Naretes was a while upended through fear from giving my Mother any notice of it, but redoubling his deign
to ave me, as Cyaxares did to ruine me, he cat about till he had news of Abracomes return, and foreeeing the need he hould tand in of his peron and aitance to compleat his project of freeing me, his indutry happily light upon a handome plot to bring it about.
Birinthea, would have puru'd her Hitory, when Zorbas entred the chamber, and told them that the General of the Medes and Perians had ent in a Trumpetter, to demand his prionners.

The remainder of Cyrus's company, who could not get into the City time enough with him, being returned to the Camp with Abracome, quickly gave intelligence of his being taken: Tygranes, Artabae, Gadate, Gobrias and the chief Officers of the Army, being aembled peedily to conult about this important accident, reolv'd firt to keep ecret the abence of their General, whom they thought Zorbas could not well detain, and end to redemand him as a private Officer, whom he could not with-hold without a breach of the Articles of truce.

To induce Zorbas the more to retore him blind-fold, and prevent the curioity he might have to eek the knowledg of him, they intreated a Lady, whom he lov'd paionately, and who was at that time in their power and Camp, to write a Ticket to him, which that generous Lady, to recompence the inetimable obligations he owed Cyrus, immediately traced in thee words.

Zorbas, if the opportunity of doing me a favour be pleaing or welcome, hardly can you ever expect to meet with a fairer then this, or make a greater or happier advantage of it then by returning thoe Perians peedily to the Camp, that are now in your hands, whom you cannot jutly detain, as not being prioners by Article, and whom you hould deliver, becaue I request it.

Though this Ticket were not igned, Zorbas was o happy in the acquaintance of the Characters, that he no ooner received and read it, but he immediately went to Cyrus; to whom he aid; hewing him the paper, that he was hugely orry to part with him o oon, and wanted the due time to confirme o trickt an amity as he much long'd to contract with him, but that the decree he held in his hand, had hatned him to come and let him know, he was at liberty with all his party to returne when they pleas'd: provided his wounded body could admit of a remove. Cyrus not being able to conceive from whence Zorbas had o uddenly received thee orders, beeeched him to tell it; and Zorbas after he had read it, aur'd him, it came from a peron o much his Soveraign, that he would count his life but a mean los, if compar'd to her favour; and therefore could conult no reaon but hers in what concerned his obedience towards her, which he would never forfeit, whilt in his power to performe; and therefore earnetly intreated him to let her know at his return, how diligent
and zealous he had been to accomplih her injunctions.

Cyrus having reply'd, with as much generoity as Courthip, that this was the leat ervice he could pay to requite o much civility, deired him, that on the next morning he might free him from the trouble of his unhandome, becaue unhealthy company; by reaon of his wounds: Zorbas however conented not to it, till the Chyrurgions had aured he might be removed without danger, and having ended his complements with Cyrus, he renew'd them by a freh addres to Birinthea, haping a thouand excues for his mens inolencies, and pray'd her to declare what atisfaction he thought fit to demand, knowing an ordinary death was too cheap a jutice and payment for o daring a crime, wherefore he left them to her entence. This Princes, whoe mercy wayd above all other entiments, told him, that it would eem to relih of ingratitude, if after uch choice obligations, which wip'd out all the other cores of injury, he hould be o unjut as to demand their lives. Wherefore as he had reaon to be concern'd in all that related to him, o he not only would profes it, but evidently prove it by begging their lives of him, as a particular grace and mercy.

The night was now much wated, and therefore Zorbas having anwerd in a few words, that he might abolutely dipoe of the lives and fortunes of thoe inolent fellows, took his leave, and commanded the mitris of that houe
where they lodg'd, to prepare a bed with all things convenient for Birinthea, who immediately retyr'd, to prevent any candal might be taken, if he made any longer tay with Cyrus. Zorbas likewie dipatch'd away the Trumpetter to the Perian Army, to take order againt the next morning for fetching away his prionners, and gave them pecial charge of the letter he return'd in anwer to his Lady.

In the mean while, our Heroe's exceive joy for the ight of his dear Princes, was o great it quell'd for ome time the alarm which the beginning of her dicoure had disquieted and threatned him withall, and as one highly atisfied with his own properous affection, he conumed the remainder of that night with the pleaing fancies of happy lovers. But then the adder remembrance of thoe les promiing peeches entring again into his mind, when the firt light of day peep'd into his bed; Ah, cry'd he, Am I o much a fale friend to my elf, as yet to flatter my hopes, did not Birinthea tell me, that he could not love me? Nay which is more, that he ought not to encourage or uffer me to love her? Great gods, wherefore then did he come to eek me out? Does he expect the protection of one whoe affection he cannot entertain? and does he cat her elf into his armes, whoe flames he mut and will banih out of her heart? How unjut and cruel are you Birinthea, if you intend eriouly to re • ect my fair pretences, ince you know I cannot cherih life, but as you cherih my love: But in fine, what is it you aime at? Mut I employ the unlucky reidue of
my power to advance the properity and blis of ome triumphant rival? Mut all my Army fight to tear of my own glorious Wreaths and Crowns, and et them on anothers prouder head? What meane you, Birinthea, by thee ervices you claime? But —O how impudent is this curioity and trugling? and how offenive to that repect and reverence I owe you; pardon dear Princes, come lets obey, and erve her with a religious and blindfold ubmiion, and whether life or death be the ucces, bow under fate, ince he commands the triall; he is my Soveraign and may dipoe of all my Fortunes, and it mut needs be as glorious, as it is doubtfull now to Cyrus, to have contributed towards her felicity, what ever be the event.

He was diturbed with thee perplexing reflexions, even whilt he lumbred, till ome attendants came to his bedide to tell him, if he had repoed enough, he might be going thence as oon as he deired. The firt inquiry he made, was for his Princes, and to be inform'd whether he were yet ready, but undertanding that Zorbas entertained her till his upriing, he ent to excue his lazines, and being dreed and his wounds lookt to, which were the leat of his paines, they carried him in a chayr to the place where Zorbas yet convered with Birinthea, and there having paid his bet civilities and thanks for the favours received at the Governours hands, who repented he was no more prodigal of them, ince the occaion of adding to the tore was now removing from him, they mutually
embrac'd and bad farewel, and Cyrus was placed in a litter which waited him, whilt Birinthea was not paring of her compliments to court Zorbas, who attended and helpt her into the Chariot he had prepar'd, and all thoe Perians that were in a fit poture to accompany them, had uch conveniency as made their journey no les eay, then joyful, in regard of their liberty, to them.

Cyrus and Birinthea would have taken their lat adieu of Zorbas, at the Gates, but he would needs convoy them till they meet the little troop which hatned to fetch and guide them to the Camp, which were but few in number to avoid all upition and inquiry. Then they repeated — Myriads of new protetations and vows of never dying friendhip, and made their clos embraces the lat ceremonies and eals of future amity. When Cyrus had pas'd the verge of that River, where he firt dicover'd the ravihers of his dear Princes, Tygranes, Artabae, Gadate and all the prime Officers of his Army, who waited at the wood-ide, came to congratulate his afe return. The Souldiers, all this time, knew nothing till their General was in his Tent, then it was publihd openly and they declar'd by their loud welcomes and acclamations, the hearty joy for his return o fully, that by it may be gues'd, what trouble and dicontent would have poes'd each oul, had they not lived in the more happy ignorance of his late abence.
